mole.review: while i was blissfully enjoying my soyrizo, guacamole and tofu mole burrito, i blurted out, "five stars" in between moans of pleasure.  a friend i was with asked me, "are you always such a positive yelp reviewer?" to which i laughed because i've had a few people comment on my superfluous 1 and 2 star reviews (which, i think, is not a reflection of my own negativity but a product of south orange county living).  the salsa was AMAZING!  and creamy and delicious.  even the pickled jicama spiced with chile was delicious.  the prices are even decent and if i hadn't decided to fix it up so much it would have been under $5.  of course, with all my fixin's it ended up being $8.  still not terrible for a big burrito with plenty of heart and soul.  i was full enough to be happy the entire hour and a half that bryan and i spent walking around the mission looking for our lost car.

excerpts: basically there are plain, arroz y frijoles, veggie, grilled veggie, marinated tofu, soyrizo, mole, chile verde, carne asada, pollo, camarones, prawn and prescado choices for either burritos, quesadillas and 2 tacos.
and to super size it
their grilled veggie tacos are devine.
their grilled veggie tacos are devine.
i also tried the mole, which was a bit watery for my taste.
overall, it is pretty good and i will definitely visit again.
also, the salsa is really fabulous and flavorful.
the decor is nice and clean, unlike a lot of similar places in sf mission area.
i will recommend it!
also it is close to 24th street mission bart.
mole.author: Cindy L.
mole.review: oh my can i give it a 6 stars? i am so addicted to this place. i always come here after steph snyder's class at yoga tree valencia. it's pretty much a ritual. the price is unbeatable. 2 tacos for 3 bucks? it's fabulous. basically there are plain, arroz y frijoles, veggie, grilled veggie, marinated tofu, soyrizo, mole, chile verde, carne asada, pollo, camarones, prawn and prescado choices for either burritos, quesadillas and 2 tacos. and to super size it, you can add sour cream, cheese and guacamole for 99 cents! woo wee! their grilled veggie tacos are devine. i also tried the mole, which was a bit watery for my taste. overall, it is pretty good and i will definitely visit again. also, the salsa is really fabulous and flavorful. the decor is nice and clean, unlike a lot of similar places in sf mission area. i will recommend it! also it is close to 24th street mission bart.

excerpts: I like the tofu mole, my friend likes the marinated tofu.
We fight about which is better, but really, they're both quite good.
mole.author: Rosie R.
mole.review: Attention vegetarians: Yummy, yummy tofu burritos here.  I like the tofu mole, my friend likes the marinated tofu.  We fight about which is better, but really, they're both quite good.

excerpts: Another favorite of mine is their vegetarian mole burrito!
mmm....I'm hungry!
mole.author: christine t.
mole.review: Love their salsa--I pick up a jar once a week and score major points at home!!!  Another favorite of mine is their vegetarian mole burrito!  mmm....I'm hungry!

excerpts: Papalote is a healthful change of pace from the usual Mission fare, offering meats not drenched in lipids, refried beans without lard and various vegan ingredients like grilled marinated tofu, mole tofu and soyrizo.

The lettuce, tomatoes, cilantro and other auxiliary ingredients are always fresh, and the award-winning house salsa, which is made from scratch every day, is dangerously addictive and worthy of its reputation as the best salsa in the city.
mole.author: Eugene P.
mole.review: Papalote is a healthful change of pace from the usual Mission fare, offering meats not drenched in lipids, refried beans without lard and various vegan ingredients like grilled marinated tofu, mole tofu and soyrizo. The lettuce, tomatoes, cilantro and other auxiliary ingredients are always fresh, and the award-winning house salsa, which is made from scratch every day, is dangerously addictive and worthy of its reputation as the best salsa in the city. Unfortunately the meats -- namely, the chile verde, carne asada and grilled chicken -- tend to be dry and a bit tough, possibly because it appears that the pork, beef and chicken are cooked with virtually all their fat trimmed away; even so, they are well-seasoned and thus quite enjoyable, especially when dispatched in a super burrito, which keeps the moisture level up by way of sour cream, cheese and guacamole. Omnivores not interested in smothering their meats in such heavy condiments may want to steer toward the marinated seafood options: prawns grilled with lime juice, sauteed shrimp and sauteed fish. Papalote may not provide what most would consider traditional Mexican food, but it does offer satisfying, heart-smart innovations in Mexican cuisine.

excerpts: had the chicken mole burrito which was juicy, and flavorful, and took away any doubts i had about mole in a burrito outfit.
the salsa alone is worth a trip, it is creamy with rosted (tomato?) pieces.
i found myself going back a few days later, and sampled the chili verde tacos.
the meat was a little dry, but a healthy addition of the salsa made the taco perfect.
i couldn't tell for sure if the tortillas were fresh, but i would bet that they are.
the jicama salad with orange garnish is a fantastic touch on each plate.
decent prices as well, and a nice mexican beer selection.
mole.author: Lesley S.
mole.review: only been here twice, but so far this is a three star taqueria. had the chicken mole burrito which was juicy, and flavorful, and took away any doubts i had about mole in a burrito outfit.  the salsa alone is worth a trip, it is creamy with rosted (tomato?) pieces. i found myself going back a few days later, and sampled the chili verde tacos. the meat was a little dry, but a healthy addition of the salsa made the taco perfect. i couldn't tell for sure if the tortillas were fresh, but i would bet that they are. the jicama salad with orange garnish is a fantastic touch on each plate. decent prices as well, and a nice mexican beer selection.

excerpts: Three, you always see these Postmates/Grubhub/UberEats/Eat24 people hanging around, waiting to pick up a Pork Chile Verde no sour cream extra guac spinach wrap for some techie who does the software programming for Postmates/Grubhub/Uber.
chile verde.author: Ringo M.
chile verde.review:
I'm gonna say something really snobbish. Ready? Here goes.

I don't like Papalolte because it's a hipster-infested burrito place.

Oops i mean hipster-invested.

Oh you know it's hipster because: 

One, everything in the restaurant is spanking clean. 

Two, they have this signature creamy salsa that all silicon techies like to irrationally rave about in their work patios. 

Three, you always see these Postmates/Grubhub/UberEats/Eat24 people hanging around, waiting to pick up a Pork Chile Verde no sour cream extra guac spinach wrap for some techie who does the software programming for Postmates/Grubhub/Uber. 

Four, remember that delicious salsa mentioned above? Yeah they sell it separately in a jar. 

Five, and probably the most evident indicator of Papalolte's hipster affiliation, a burrito costs like $10 to $11 #damndaniel

My good friend, Salty P, swears by this place though. He loves pouring that creamy salsa on each bite of his carne asada while convincing us that Papalote is actually the best burrito place in Mission. But we can't trust this guy to give an unbiased opinion. Salty P. wears a beard, rocks an expensive vest, and has like, 5 hydroflask bottles ("i need it").

Although i might not like Papalote, i do recommend it to my vegetarian friends though. I know other burrito places offer vegetarian options, too, but Papalote takes their vegetarian menu seriously. Unlike other places, you can be sure that the oil used for the veggie options is kept separately from the meat. You can sleep easy knowing that a piece of meat may not have snuck its way into your Soyrizo Burrito. How can we be so sure? Because unlike other burrito places, Papalote actually has something to lose. They got a chain store down at Fulton.

So yeah, if you don't have any dietary restrictions and/or if you're not a hipster, then i would go Cancun and El Faro instead. But if you are a vegetarian and/or keeps a leather notebook in your butt pocket, then Papalote is the place for you :)

excerpts: One of my girls swears by two menu items: the mole and the chile verde.
I've tried both, and
I'm a much bigger fan of the CHILE VERDE because the pork makes my taste buds dance a happy dance.
I get it as a salad to cut down on carbs and because the jicama and fresh salsa pair so well with the salty pork and the awesome green serrano sauce, which I drizzle errywhere.
chile verde.author: Adele F.
chile verde.review:
Holy. Guacamole. Papalote now has a "buy 10 burritos get 1 free" frequent rewards card.

This is new! As of a few weeks ago! I could have gotten so many free burritos by now!

Aside from free burritos, what makes this place great?

1) Convenient. I live a block from this location. And when my friends and I are feeling like lazy bums...sorry, since we ARE lazy bums, we call in bulk to-go orders, wait 15 minutes, and send over volunteer tributes to pick up our stash.

2) Quality. Their meat is GOOD. Tender. Moist. And they are so generous. One of my girls swears by two menu items: the mole and the chile verde. I've tried both, and I'm a much bigger fan of the CHILE VERDE because the pork makes my taste buds dance a happy dance. I get it as a salad to cut down on carbs and because the jicama and fresh salsa pair so well with the salty pork and the awesome green serrano sauce, which I drizzle errywhere. I've also tried their carne asada burrito and breakfast burrito, both of which are bomb. Oh, when they say scrambled eggs, they really mean pulverized eggs--it's pretty awesome.

3) Customizable. Tacos, burritos, naked burritos, quesadillas, salads--meat/tofu vehicles of all types. Last I checked, their "make it super" option, which adds sour cream, cheese, and guacamole was only $1. Seems like the prices now are more expensive per online source?

4) Crack sauce. When I first tried it, I wasn't a big fan because it's spicy. It's still spicy, but I've learned to better ignore my screaming pain receptors. There's something about eating crunchy tortilla chips with a creamy sauce that makes everything taste way better. I love this combination so much that I always save my leftover chips and sauce for future snacking. I even save my friends' leftover chips and sauce. My boyfriend thinks I'm crazy, squirreling away all of those mini sauce containers in our fridge. I think I'm GENIUS. They sell jars of this stuff, and I'm getting it FO' FREE.

5) REWARDS CARD. This perk deserves to be repeated. FYI: valid for burrito purchases only.

Downside: seating. It looks like a seat-yourself situation, but one of the waitstaff will usually be around the dining room entrance to keep an eye out for tables. The room holds about 20 people, so you might have to wait for a bit during rush hours.

But srsly, Papalote is dope-alote. Time to reap some free burritos.

excerpts: But the chile verde burrito with refried beans.
OH MY GOODNESS.
Flavorful and addictive.
Even the leftovers tasted wonderful.
It is really messy because the chile verde is really wet
chile verde.author: Traci H.
chile verde.review:
Ok now I understand the craze that is Papalote.

For hipster Mission, it's reasonably priced (e.g., 2 people can eat for $20), but yeah it's just a burrito.  But it's a good one.  

People rave about the chips and salsa (yes the burritos come with it) and yeah the salsa is like crack.  The chips have been hit or miss.  Sometimes it feels hard and tasteless, but it's just a shovel to get the salsa in my mouth.

I made a big mistake...I ordered a steak naked bowl with no beans.  It was dry and tasteless.  The steak is meh.  Skip it.

But the chile verde burrito with refried beans. OH MY GOODNESS.  Flavorful and addictive.  Even the leftovers tasted wonderful.  It is really messy because the chile verde is really wet so I just dug right in with a fork and knife instead.

Frequent burrito card so why not come back more.

Order and pay at the cash register and then you sit with a number and they bring your food.  One of the cash registers is for phone orders only so if you're doing takeout, it's pretty easy.

Bathroom on the far side of the restaurant.

And head down the street to Arizemendi for a little after meal scone ;-)

excerpts: Had the chile verde super and was not disappointed...
Drinking food!
The chips with their own sauce at the start though mmmmm need more of that salsa...
Worth a trip past the usually burrito joints for an altogether more relaxed experience in the mission
chile verde.author: Reg B.
chile verde.review: They are now doing their own sauces and it's been so long since I made the trek up the taqueria, I had forgotten the lay out! The menu seemed slightly changed? But nevertheless was excellent... High quality fare... Had the chile verde super and was not disappointed... Drinking food! The chips with their own sauce at the start though mmmmm need more of that salsa... Worth a trip past the usually burrito joints for an altogether more relaxed experience in the mission

excerpts: Ordered the Chile Verde burrito.
It was mushy flavorless mess, 'Pico de gallo' was a few tomatoes.
This place does not stand up to the hype.
chile verde.author: Jim W.
chile verde.review:
Ordered the Chile Verde burrito. It was mushy flavorless mess, 'Pico de gallo' was a few tomatoes. This place does not stand up to the hype. The worst burrito I've had in the mission... probably because of the vegan beans. 

I heard that the salsa was the best in SF. It also has no flavor. A little spicy but that's it; the only thing that stood out was the unique consistency.

Oh and if you want extra of their horrible salsa it's 50 cents. Ridiculous.... i just paid $12 for a burrito, c'mon.

excerpts: Chile Verde here is really good too!
chile verde.author: Aaron C.
chile verde.review: Best. Salsa. Ever!!!    Ask for the house salsa, not the pre-canned stuff, when you order your food.   The triple threat is an evil burrito!!!  Chile Verde here is really good too!

excerpts: But the rice is mushy, the chile verde has a funky off taste and isn't particularly tangy or spicy.
Come for the chips & salsa, but don't stay.
chile verde.author: Lulu L.
chile verde.review:
Most overrated burrito in town?
Their salsa is the best, and the service is great.
But the rice is mushy, the chile verde has a funky off taste and isn't particularly tangy or spicy. 
Come for the chips & salsa, but don't stay.

excerpts: Lunch today: Regular nachos, chile verde tacos, steak burrito, two diet cokes, free chips and their signature
roasted chili salsa, $36.
Two people.
I took one taco home- a lot of food.
My son raved about the food and he is picky.
I liked that the pork in my chile verde was tender and NO GRISTLE.
Hate gristle.
Also really like the heat on the chile verde.
Their roasted chile salsa is yummy, too.
So, yes, go and enjoy!
chile verde.author: Carol E.
chile verde.review: Lunch today: Regular nachos, chile verde tacos, steak burrito, two diet cokes, free chips and their signature roasted chili salsa, $36. Two people. I took one taco home- a lot of food. My son raved about the food and he is picky. I liked that the pork in my chile verde was tender and NO GRISTLE. Hate gristle. Also really like the heat on the chile verde. Their roasted chile salsa is yummy, too. So, yes, go and enjoy!

excerpts: The chile verde was pretty bad.
Despite having some heat, it was otherwise bland from the flavor side.
The pork was fake-tender.
By that I mean, you could break of pieces easiily with a fork, but it was still dry.
Clearly it had been simmering for too long in too high of heat.
Even I, the home cook, know this - poor technique in the kitchen.
The scary part?
I asked the cashier if she recommended the chile verde or the chicken mole, and she said chile verde.
He looked at the ticket in his hand, which I also saw, and it clear said "Chile Verde, Guacamole.
He seemed very confused.
My friend also pointed out that on her (separate) order, she had asked and paid for 2 extra salsas and those were not brought out either.
He seemed confused and flustered.
Eventually we got everything we needed
but it wasn't
like he was bringing out multiple plates of food at once.
He literally was only carrying my tacos in one hand and the ticket that clearly stated "Guacamole" in the other.
Also, on an unrelated note - flies in the air.
chile verde.author: Naoko M.
chile verde.review:
I was looking forward to finally going to Papalote and I have to say the hype is not worth it. Is the salsa delicious? Absolutely. That's about all I can say.

My gripes:
1) You can't "mix and match" your tacos - meaning, if you want to try two kinds of meat, you have to end up with 4 tacos. See, typically I go to taquerias and get 2 or 3 tacos, each with a different protein so I can sample. Much to my dismay, when I asked about this the nice lady said I have to get the 2 tacos.  That's kind of crappy.

2) The chile verde was pretty bad.  Despite having some heat, it was otherwise bland from the flavor side.  The pork was fake-tender. By that I mean, you could break of pieces easiily with a fork, but it was still dry. Clearly it had been simmering for too long in too high of heat. Even I, the home cook, know this - poor technique in the kitchen.  The scary part? I asked the cashier if she recommended the chile verde or the chicken mole, and she said chile verde. I'm terrified of how crappy the mole might be.

3) The tacos come covered in lettuce and tomatoes. What?  Why? There's so much of it too. I appreciate wanting to promote eating veggies and all, but I came here to eat a taco - with meat.  Not ok.

4) Guacamole - was also bland. I had to add some salt. There was no limey zip, and I'm not even sure how but I didn't really get the flavor of avocado. 

5) Service - When the gentleman brought out my tacos, I asked about my side of guac. He looked at the ticket in his hand, which I also saw, and it clear said "Chile Verde, Guacamole." He seemed very confused. My friend also pointed out that on her (separate) order, she had asked and paid for 2 extra salsas and those were not brought out either. He seemed confused and flustered. Eventually we got everything we needed but it wasn't like he was bringing out multiple plates of food at once. He literally was only carrying my tacos in one hand and the ticket that clearly stated "Guacamole" in the other.  Also, on an unrelated note - flies in the air. Not ideal.

This place is probably great for vegetarians/vegans who otherwise can't get Mexican food, but for us meat eaters, don't bother.  

2 stars for the salsa. Good news is you can buy jars of that stuff and never eat anything else here. That's probably my go-to plan from now on.

excerpts: Had the chile verde burrito.
That salsa they give you on table more like a sauce is awesome.
Would hav bought a bottle if i wasnt flying home and knew damn tsa people would keep it.
But lets get real.
chile verde.author: Jim G.
chile verde.review:
Would rate as 3.5 stars if yelp let me
now  why low rating, well burrito was delish.  Great taste.   Had the chile verde burrito. That salsa they give you on table more like a sauce is awesome.  Would hav bought a bottle if i wasnt flying home and knew damn tsa people would keep it.  But lets get real.  Despite great flavor, there was very little meat in it mostly rice and beans.  $11 for a burrito and can of coke come on now.  Get over being on tv.  Shave $3 off that price and you are 5 star material.  Crossed off my bucket list.

excerpts: I usually order either tacos or naked burrito with shrimp or Chile Verde.
Consistent, fast, and delicious whether you're ordering out or eating there.
Best salsa EVER!
chile verde.author: Sophie S.
chile verde.review: Favorite Mexican restaurant by far! I usually order either tacos or naked burrito with shrimp or Chile Verde. Consistent, fast, and delicious whether you're ordering out or eating there. Best salsa EVER!

excerpts: My friend and I waited patiently and ordered a Chile Verde Super Burrito (chicken simmered in chile verde with rice, black beans, guacamole, cheese and sour cream).
chile verde.author: Lauren B.
chile verde.review:
You can Papalome any day!

Ahem...moving on.  This place came highly recommended by many people.  So I went with high expectations.  The place already had a pretty good line at 6pm on a Thursday.  My friend and I waited patiently and ordered a Chile Verde Super Burrito (chicken simmered in chile verde with rice, black beans, guacamole, cheese and sour cream).

The burrito itself was fantastic, the guac tasted like it was whipped or something and the overall flavors of the burrito itself were delicious and filling, while using a minimal amount of oil so I didn't feel gross afterwards.

However - I did take away one star since my friend and I waited for 40 minutes and after we kept seeing others get their food, I went in to inquire about the burrito status since my hanger   pains were setting in. The guy at the counter laughed and was like "It looks like they lost your slip, no worries - ok?"

While it was not an issue per say, I was pissed because I was hungry and after all was said it done it took us 50 minutes to order and get our food. Not to mention the guy just laughed about it - not cool. Next time I will be calling ahead - since their burritos are too delicious to ignore.

excerpts: My two lunch friends had the pork chile verde tacos and the fish burrito.
The tacos looked good, but seemed to be piled high with garnish which seemed a little weird.
If I order the tacos in future, I'll get them with just meat and tortilla.
The fish burrito looked like a winner and my friend swears by it, so I'm either getting that next time or trying the machaca which is hard to find in the Bay Area!
chile verde.author: Jason W.
chile verde.review:
Oh man, that orange salsa.... SO GOOD! I buy it by the jarful at Whole Foods and dump it on everything at home. Sure it's expensive, but it's way better than Frontera or any of that other hoity-toity stuff that tries to pass for gourmet salsa. Based on the quality of their salsa, I was very excited to try the Papalote restaurant in the Mission today!

Papalote is a small restaurant on a largely residential block of 24th street. It's conveniently located a couple of blocks from the 24th & Mission BART stop and also a block away from a good friend's house. If I'd known it was this close, I would have gone numerous times already! Inside the restaurant are a handful of tables next to a large window which offers a good people watching view of the street outside. You order at the counter up front and then take a number and sit down.

I ordered a carne asada burrito with beans and rice. The burrito was about average in size, but that's ok because I don't like overeating these days. The contents were very tasty with plenty of grilled beef and flavorful rice and beans. I only had one funny bit of gristle in the burrito, so I would call that a rousing success for the Bay Area. They also give you tasty chips and a cup of their salsa before the meal. HOWEVER, if you want more salsa to go with your meal, it costs an additional fifty cents for each refill. WTF?! Most places load you up on salsa without an additional charge. This is something they really should consider since it seems a little chintzy of them.

My two lunch friends had the pork chile verde tacos and the fish burrito. The tacos looked good, but seemed to be piled high with garnish which seemed a little weird. If I order the tacos in future, I'll get them with just meat and tortilla. The fish burrito looked like a winner and my friend swears by it, so I'm either getting that next time or trying the machaca which is hard to find in the Bay Area!

Papalote is a very clean, stylish restaurant. Food gets delivered quickly and the staff are all super nice. I'll definitely come back again, but maybe I'll bring my own Papalote salsa from home if they're going to charge me for salsa!

excerpts: We ordered the mole chicken tacos and chile verde with pork.
The tortillas were super soft and not dried out.
The tomatoes and lettuce on top were very fresh.
The chile verde was just YUMMY!
The mole was a bit over powering and thick.
This is the best taco in town!
Will come back again for sure!
chile verde.author: Irene C.
chile verde.review:
Order at front and get seated.  They'll bring you warm tortilla chips and "salsa" to your table.  The "salsa" isn't your typical chopped tomatoes and onion but very spicy roasted tomato dip.

We ordered the mole chicken tacos and chile verde with pork.  The tortillas were super soft and not dried out.  The tomatoes and lettuce on top were very fresh.  The chile verde was just YUMMY!  The mole was a bit over powering and thick.  This is the best taco in town!  Will come back again for sure!

excerpts: Last time I was there, I switched it up and got a Chile Verde (pork) burrito.
chile verde.author: Alyssa G.
chile verde.review:
I like that Papalote is easy to get to from work, for a quick bite at lunchtime. Parking is usually pretty easy, both metered and residential. There is always a lot of people around, and it may take a while until you get your order placed. Always helps to know what you want when they're ready to take your order.

Last time I was there, I switched it up and got a Chile Verde (pork) burrito. It was humongous and very good, topped with guacamole, sour cream and the works.

I usually go for the prawn quesadillas, that is my usual menu go-to item at Papalote. All their items are well under $10, which makes me a fan!

TIP: must try the chips and homemade salsa, it's got a fiery, roasted taste to it. Delicious!

excerpts: I usually get the chile verde burrito
and it's messy but amazing.
The salsa is very addictive, it's no wonder they sell it by the jar.
chile verde.author: Jared G.
chile verde.review: I come here quite a bit and love the food. I usually get the chile verde burrito and it's messy but amazing. The salsa is very addictive, it's no wonder they sell it by the jar.

excerpts: Chile Verde burrito was not at all what I expected.
It had no heat at all, but rather sweet.
The rice had a weird texture, it felt almost al dente??
chile verde.author: Ly T.
chile verde.review:
I really don't understand why ppl are going on and on about this place. In a town like SF where there are plenty of Mexican/burrito joints, methinks this place is totally overrated. But I just had to try it and experience it for myself, esp if they threw down Bobby Flay...

The place is a little small but the tables turn pretty quick, as it's not really a place where you stick around and chit chat with your friends without getting dirty looks from ppl waiting for a table. Props for having an effective system waiting for a table which allows you to preorder your food and having it arrive shortly after being seated.

Overall, the meal was pretty disappointing. The only good thing really, were the loaded nachos.  

The chips that came with the burritos tasted dry and stale. The touted salsa, was underwhelming. That's what I really didn't understand. There was no real taste, except a somewhat mild lingering taste. Sad to say, all of us added a little salt to enhance the flavor. I guess we all expected a little more. 

Chile Verde burrito was not at all what I expected. It had no heat at all, but rather sweet. The rice had a weird texture, it felt almost al dente?? Palatable by me given that I added the slime colored habanero sauce they had on the table (i thought habaneros were orange??), but a total thumbs down by the hubby, who usually eats most everything.

We've had better burritos, both in size and taste, elsewhere in the city and for a better value as well. Who knows? Maybe they were having an off night? Sorry Papalote, I guess you're not meant for us.

excerpts: I got the chile verde pork tacos, and I made them super for 99 cents more.
The plate was definitely larger than I thought it would be, and I think the super-ness made it too hard to actually eat the tacos by hand.
I had to use a fork to pare them down a bit before I could even get them to the point where I could pick one up to eat it.
That said, the chile verde was good, but felt like the rest of the toppings weren't awesome.
chile verde.author: C S.
chile verde.review:
I got the chile verde pork tacos, and I made them super for 99 cents more. The plate was definitely larger than I thought it would be, and I think the super-ness made it too hard to actually eat the tacos by hand. I had to use a fork to pare them down a bit before I could even get them to the point where I could pick one up to eat it. That said, the chile verde was good, but felt like the rest of the toppings weren't awesome.

I ate at the restaurant, and after a short wait, we got a table. The server brought each person a small bowl of chips and a small container of salsa. The salsa was great, spicy and a good appetizer.

excerpts: Pork chile verde:  should've been named Green Pork in Garlic Sauce cause that's all we could taste.
Not the tangy, intangible yum of tomatillos.
Not the zing of chili.
Hell, not even pork-flavored.
Care to guess what you COULD taste?
chile verde.author: Ben S.
chile verde.review:
2.5 stars

The pollo asado burrito remains delicious on account of their special marinade and the grill flavor.  Every bite yum.  
But what if I came in one day with the family and we tried something different... perhaps one of their plates?

Pork chile verde:  should've been named Green Pork in Garlic Sauce cause that's all we could taste.  Not the tangy, intangible yum of tomatillos. Not the zing of chili.  Hell, not even pork-flavored. Care to guess what you COULD taste?  Fail.

Chicken Mole:  was rich as mole negro should be.  The sauce is deeply flavored BUT way over-chocolate-y, covering up practically all the chili pepper flavors.  The chicken breast was tough, overcooked to the point in which it required earnest effort to cut with a fork. 

Spanish omelet:  good cheesy goodness with mushrooms and bell peppers throughout but it suffered from overcooked eggs.  Browned scrambled egg has a particularly strong flavor and if you dig it, you'll be pleased.  I find it just short of revolting.

Conclusion:  stick with the burrito at $7.50 and pass on the $13 plates.

excerpts: The chicken burrito was a bit dry, but the chile verde pork was better.
chile verde.author: Solomon W.
chile verde.review:
Yes, I took friends here just because I saw it on Throwdown.  I knew I had to get the salsa here, but we also tried some of their various dishes.  This place is cool for not over-advertising their fame, and also keeping their restaurant very local and quaint.  We had to wait a few minutes to even sit down for some quick-paced Mexican grub.

The food here is served in large portions, but the prices are quite up there.  They are known for their sun-dried tomato salsa, but it is somewhat one-dimensional in my opinion.  It lacks the freshness of salsa (they sell it by the bottle), and it has too much American jazziness to it.

The best thing by far is the fish, in any form.  The white wine and butter sauce is exquisite, and the fish is extremely moist and tender.  The quesadilla option is a bit pricey, though.

The chicken mole kind of stunk.  The sauce was pretty heavy on the sweetness; it could have used more chiles.  The chicken was not super moist, and it was $13.  The chicken burrito was a bit dry, but the chile verde pork was better.  The CV had a tangy, hearty sauce that paired well with the tender pork.

There is nothing to really rave about here, but I guess it is worth a shot if you are into unique salsas and stuff.  The food is a little pricier than normal, but it does the job, and there are offerings to satisfy everyone.

excerpts: The chile verde super burrito my boyfriend got did come hot, but was very unoriginal and bland as well.
You would think the place acclaimed as the "best burrito in America" would have more to offer than overpriced, everyday burritos.
Overall, we thought this place was hugely overrated and overpriced.
DO NOT go here if you are expecting a world class burrito, plenty of other taquerias in the mission offer much more and at a better price point.
chile verde.author: Ainslee S.
chile verde.review: My boyfriend and I went here because it was rated the "best burrito in America". Umm what? Like most of the other reviews said, the burrito was BLAND and overpriced. My pollo asada super burrito came cold. The chile verde super burrito my boyfriend got did come hot, but was very unoriginal and bland as well. You would think the place acclaimed as the "best burrito in America" would have more to offer than overpriced, everyday burritos. Overall, we thought this place was hugely overrated and overpriced. DO NOT go here if you are expecting a world class burrito, plenty of other taquerias in the mission offer much more and at a better price point.

excerpts: I ordered a chile verde (pork) burrito, with guacamole and sour cream, on a spinach tortilla.
It was delicious, with the ingredients well mixed in the burrito (a big selling point).
I added a little of the well-spiced salsa provided with my chips to the burrito and it really hit the spot.
The pork was cooked that day, and fairly tender.
The guacamole wasn't spectacular in its own right, but mixed well with the flavors of the burrito.
And there was some form of pickled vegetable in the burrito that was just the right touch.
chile verde.author: Naveen A.
chile verde.review:
I went here after it was ranked the #2 burrito joint in SF by the 7x7 magazine.  (El Farolito was first.)  The burrito was gigantic, and tasty, and a good half of it is still around for dinner.

Overall, this isn't really a place you go to for ambience--even though it has it, and beer--but moreso for awesome food:
Food: 5
Service: 4
Price: 4

Clearly, food carries the day.  I ordered a chile verde (pork) burrito, with guacamole and sour cream, on a spinach tortilla.  It was delicious, with the ingredients well mixed in the burrito (a big selling point).  I added a little of the well-spiced salsa provided with my chips to the burrito and it really hit the spot.  The pork was cooked that day, and fairly tender.  The guacamole wasn't spectacular in its own right, but mixed well with the flavors of the burrito.  And there was some form of pickled vegetable in the burrito that was just the right touch.  The burrito was gargantuan, though, so I brought most of it home.

The only detractors are as follows.  There isn't enough salsa to go around, and according to another review, you have to pay for extra.  Also, it may be that I was unreasonably hungry, but I felt the 10+ minutes I waited for my burrito was a bit more than needed, even for fresh ingredients.  Lastly, at $9.30 for a super burrito, there are cheaper places with quality that's just as good.

Nonetheless, it's scrumptious, plain and simple.  Worth going, worth the price.  Word to the wise: from the look of the place, you'll have to wait for a while to find a table during peak times.

excerpts: So, instead i was torn between the mole burrito or the chile verde.
Per the cashiers recommendation, i chose the chili verde.
chile verde.author: Anthony D.
chile verde.review:
excited to check this place out after finding out it beat out bobby flaw on throwdown, i made the journey to experience 'the best burrito' in san francisco last sunday. BAD IDEA!

what a waste of time and hype. First off, the 'triple threat' cost $20, seriously, 20 bucks for a damn burrito, not in this life time. 

So, instead i was torn between the mole burrito or the chile verde. Per the cashiers recommendation, i chose the chili verde. While waiting i was brought some chips and salsa. 

Heard the salsa was great, what a disappointment. It is the better type, i think habanero; however, it just wasnt anything special. If you want a real good orange salsa, try Iguana in SJ, definitely the best. I mean my friends mom could make a better one in her sleep, and she probably has.

Back to the point. well i was given the salsa with some chips, which were store bought (not the great house made ones at REAL mexican restaurants). Once my burrito arrived I asked for some more salsa, since I used the other on the chips they gave me. The worker told me I only get 1 salsa per order and I would have to pay if I wanted any more!! ARE YOU SERIOUS?!? Youre telling me the salsa that came with my chips was the only salsa I got to use for both my super burrito and my dipping my chips? WAT A JOKE! 

any other legitimate mexican restaurant usually hands salsa out like its halloween or even keeps them in self serve so you can basically dip your burrito in before you eat, lol. Not this place, their are like the salsa nazis for some bland lame duck salsa. 

Havent even gotten to the burrito. So, i could barely even taste the green chili and the pork was rather dry and cut too large. I mean i have had chili verde cut that large before but usually its been simmered in sauce so long that it just melts in your mouth, not this one. Felt like I was eating over cooked chicken. 

Only good marking this place gets is they allow the option of getting spinach tortillas and whole black beans. Although, DEFINITELY NOT worth $9 PLUS, the extra cost of salsa!!

BOOOO!

excerpts: I normally get the Chile Verde burrito which is excellent ($7.50) until I saw an episode of Throwdown with Bobby Flay.
Now I've been eating here for awhile and was never aware of the Triple Threat until the episode with Flay.
Told myself that I was gonna try it next time around instead of my usual Chile Verde.
Looked at the online menu and there was no Triple Threat.
Had the little lady call in an order for us.
One TT and one Chile Verde.
25 mins later, I show up to pick up my order and the nice young lady at the counter
tells me the total is $32.
I looked up at the menu board and there's a small plastic sign taped to it that reads Triple Threat
Burrito $19.99.
But $20...gonna stay with the Chile Verde.
chile verde.author: Rick C.
chile verde.review:
Ever eat a $20 burrito? That's what the the Triple Threat burrito will cost you. Shrimp, chicken and carne asada in a single burrito that's no bigger than a regular burrito. I normally get the Chile Verde burrito which is excellent ($7.50) until I saw an episode of Throwdown with Bobby Flay. Now I've been eating here for awhile and was never aware of the Triple Threat until the episode with Flay. Told myself that I was gonna try it next time around instead of my usual Chile Verde. Looked at the online menu and there was no Triple Threat. Had the little lady call in an order for us. One TT and one Chile Verde. 25 mins later, I show up to pick up my order and the nice young lady at the counter tells me the total is $32. I looked up at the menu board and there's a small plastic sign taped to it that reads Triple Threat Burrito $19.99. WTF? 

It was a Wednesday night and the place was unusually packed...alot more than usual. All of the staff members were wearing Throwndown shirts and they looked really overwhelmed by the crowds of people coming in and the telephone ringing off the hook. Even after calling the order in 25 minutes ago, I still had to wait another 15 minutes to get my food. 

The TT was good and the different meats in it had a nice balance that worked together. Maybe $10-$12 would have been a reasonable price. But $20...gonna stay with the Chile Verde. 

My beloved Papalote is now a rerun on the Food Network. Great for the owners (well deserved) but sucks for the regulars who now have to deal with the crazy crowds (not that it wasn't crowded before). At least, I can tell people I had a $20 burrito...once.

excerpts: Since I can't inject the stuff intravenously (or can I?), I ordered a chile verde burrito with black beans to serve as my salsa delivery mechanism.
It was pretty decent - well proportioned and plump with freshness.
The meat was tender and juicy, and the beans were solid by my book.
chile verde.author: Mike W.
chile verde.review:
Beware of the crack salsa. Once the orange stuff hits your mouth, you'll be lost forever. A little bit of smoke, a good amount of heat, some tang, and a rich creamy feel. I don't know what's in it. I know many have tried to duplicate it and they have failed. Frankly I don't care. I just want more. More!!!

Since I can't inject the stuff intravenously (or can I?), I ordered a chile verde burrito with black beans to serve as my salsa delivery mechanism. It was pretty decent - well proportioned and plump with freshness. The meat was tender and juicy, and the beans were solid by my book. The burrito lacked the sinful greasy qualities of traditional Mexican, but I still enjoyed it (and my heart thanks me).

You'll like the food as long as you're not holding it to traditional expectations, but seriously it's all about the salsa here. It's damn good!

excerpts: The chile verde is also great.
One cool thing is that the cooks all speak in Mayan (I asked them).
Somehow I didn't know that it was still spoken.
I'm giving it three stars.
I would probably give it four
but I rarely feel like going there.

One reason is that  50-80% of the customers at the other mexican restaurants are mexican or el salvadoran, but even though I pass Papalotes at least twice/day I don't think I have ever seen a latino customer.
chile verde.author: John S.
chile verde.review: This is the closest restaurant to my house. The salsa here is very good and very different from other mexican restaurants. The chile verde is also great. One cool thing is that the cooks all speak in Mayan (I asked them). Somehow I didn't know that it was still spoken. I'm giving it three stars. I would probably give it four but I rarely feel like going there. One reason is that  50-80% of the customers at the other mexican restaurants are mexican or el salvadoran, but even though I pass Papalotes at least twice/day I don't think I have ever seen a latino customer.

excerpts: Chicken mole tacos and chile verde burrito pleeeeeaaase!
chile verde.author: Keika L.
chile verde.review:
I feel so fortunate that I live on the same block as this restaurant. 

Chicken mole tacos and chile verde burrito pleeeeeaaase!

excerpts: Our meals were brought to us, I ordered the Chile Verde Burrito and Gil
had the chile verde quesadilla.
I have to say, the burrito was pretty good, was not bland, actual big pieces of pork in the burrito and there was that "creaminess" in the burrito that I tasted in the hot sauce.
The only comment that Gil and I both had was we couldn't tell this was Chile verde.
chile verde.author: David P.
chile verde.review:
My friend Irv kept bragging about this great Mexican restaurant near Hayes Valley and I found Papalote on Masonic and Fulton thinking it's the same place but decided to try the mission restaurant instead, still with me? there's a point to this.

I drag my friend Gil to Papalote to check this place out, it's a bit out of the way for me (Civic Center) and him (16th st) especially with plenty of good Taquerias around. We stood in a short line, ordered our food and waited at a table for two. We were given two bowls of warm tortilla chips and a very creamy and spicy sauce to dip them in. I liked it because it wasn't the typical "Pico de gallo" and it did have some kick but not enough so people that fear spice would cry like little babies.

Our meals were brought to us, I ordered the Chile Verde Burrito and Gil had the chile verde quesadilla. I have to say, the burrito was pretty good, was not bland, actual big pieces of pork in the burrito and there was that "creaminess" in the burrito that I tasted in the hot sauce. The only comment that Gil and I both had was we couldn't tell this was Chile verde. 

Would I come back? Yeah, if I was in the neighborhood.

So back to why I came to this place, I sent a text to my friend Irv and said, "I'm at Papalote, it's pretty good" he txts back with "Where?" Thinking he's having a senior moment, I explain it's the place he's been going on and on about. He replied, "That's Nopalito on Buchanan". DOH! I was at the wrong restaurant!!! So we had a good meal and a good laugh at my expense amongst friends!

excerpts: I recommend the chile verde chicken burrito and the mole chicken burrito.
I like the way the mole chicken is prepared here.
It is not overpowering or too thick.
I like the way the mole chicken is prepared here.
It is not overpowering or too thick.
chile verde.author: Joyce L.
chile verde.review:
LOVE this PLACE! 

The homemade salsa is something I randomly will crave. It is good. 

I recommend the chile verde chicken burrito and the mole chicken burrito. I like the way the mole chicken is prepared here. It is not overpowering or too thick. The tacos are also nice because they come with a lot of lettuce and tomatoes--yay more veggies!

The Triple Threat, which won in Bobby Flay's recent throwdown, is close to $20. I personally don't like eating that much meat in a burrito--so I don't think it's worth it.

excerpts:
A generous serving of chips topped w/ cheese, sauce, and egg and served w/ beans and rice on the side
- Chile Verde burrito - a fat burrito, enough for two people.
chile verde.author: Amy H.
chile verde.review:
Chilaquiles!

After walking by a few months ago and seeing someone chow down on a huge plate of nachos through the window, I knew I had to come back and check this place out sometime. I actually had no idea it was featured on Throwdown until the day before we went.

We arrived at 11:45am and it was totally dead. But our friends weren't here yet so we walked around the corner for a cup of coffee. 20 minutes later we walked back and there was a huge line out the door. 

So it's definitely not worth all the hype but the food is still pretty decent, and it's not your typical greasy Mexican joint like one would expect.

- Chips and Salsa - I thought the chips were just average - I've had better. The salsa is fantastic though - creamy and orange with a bit of kick.
- Chilaquiles - "breakfast nachos", great for sharing as I don't think I can handle an entire serving. A generous serving of chips topped w/ cheese, sauce, and egg and served w/ beans and rice on the side
- Chile Verde burrito - a fat burrito, enough for two people. Consisting of just meat, rice and beans, it was tasty, but nothing to go crazy over. I didn't bother with the Triple Threat, and don't see how an extra 10 bucks and three different types of meat would have made it that much better.
- Chicken tacos - the chicken had a good seasoning, but the rest of the taco was pretty plain. Served on two flour tortillas w/ lettuce and tomatoes.

I would come back for the salsa and chilaquiles alone, and at least I know next time I can definitely skip the burritos/tacos.

One last note - the service is great and the staff was so friendly. With crowded tables and a 20 minute line out the door they could have easily been stressed out. But they all had a great attitude, were attentive, and thanked us with smiles on our way out.

excerpts: One Chile Verde Burrito, also really good.
Juicy tender meat with tangy sauce.
chile verde.author: Otis D.
chile verde.review:
In the interest of full disclosure, I went to high school with the owners more than two decades ago.  I'm in the city for a bit and I haven't been in the Mission in a long time and hey, what was that place those guys own?  That's when a Google told me about the Food Network thing so it must be pretty decent.

There were three of us.  I had chicken Mole tacos.  Really good mole. I haven't had good Mole since I moved from L.A.  One Chile Verde Burrito, also really good.  Juicy tender meat with tangy sauce.  The third was an order of chicken tacos. 

I see others on here have mentioned the Salsa.  That stuff may haunt me between visits to S.F. that will hopefully include time to swing by again.   Starts off tomato with roasty smoked flavor and finishes with a good chile spice.  Not a fire eater spice but not for "mild please" weenies either.  And somehow it manages to seem creamy.  I'd like to buy it by the gallon jar.

Congratulations Miguel.  I dig your place and wish you continued success.  And the beer geek in me likes that you have Chimay Rouge in the cooler.

excerpts: The Carne Asada, Chile Verde, and Pollo were all very tasty.
Put a dollop of the salsa and you'll be in purgatory.
chile verde.author: Hebert J.
chile verde.review:
They definitely lived up with the hype of Awesome Burrito and Salsa. It's no wonder this place is always crowded. Don't be fooled by the lack of Latino customers in the resto, because they will still please your craving. 

Burrito - The Carne Asada, Chile Verde, and Pollo were all very tasty. Put a dollop of the salsa and you'll be in purgatory. I love it! 

Shrimp Taco - the shrimp were not fresh and this taco creation with bell peppers just didn't please my palate at all. (the only turn off)

Salsa - You can taste the freshness of the roasted tomatoes and the spiciness of the pepper. It has a great kick. The only salsa that can top this is La Vics in San Jose. I love it! 

Chicken Adobo meat - one of the staff gave me a small sample taste of their secret choice of meat. It tasted more like Paksiw to my Filipino tongue than Adobo. It's still pretty tasty but I'd rather have white rice with it. 

Price - It's more expensive than other taquerias in the Mission but it's worth it. (They need to be more generous on their salsa!) 

Staff - The owners were mingling with the people in line and all the staff members were genuinely nice!

excerpts: I personally love their Carne Asada and Chile Verde Burritos.
They are very flavorful, and not heavy at all:
A combination in a burrito that you would think would cause a paradox that would unravel space-time.
However, it all works to me, and it doesn't feel I ate a truck when I leave.
chile verde.author: Satoru Y.
chile verde.review:
A white-washed tacqueria owned and run by Mexicans; go figure...it's still great.

If other taquerias in the city, like El Castillito, were home-slobs sporting a greasy wife-beater, then Papalote would be their alluring and demure cousin.  I remember the first time I stumbled upon this modern-looking, hipster tacqueria on a night roaming the Outer Mission.  Hipster places springing up in the Mission is akin to pissing on gremlins: I guess only children of the 80's may get this reference.  I was mildly surprised by the interesting 'Mexicant' menu, including healthy options like soyrizo and vegan mole. I was even more surprised after having a burrito there, that I not only liked it...I loved it.

Myself, being a carnivore, love all of the meaty servings that they have to offer.  I personally love their Carne Asada and Chile Verde Burritos.  They are very flavorful, and not heavy at all: A combination in a burrito that you would think would cause a paradox that would unravel space-time.  However, it all works to me, and it doesn't feel I ate a truck when I leave.  Also, their Salsa is deserving of all the accolodates that it receives.

Delicious and health-conscious food, reminds me of what I miss about the city the most.

excerpts: I like the chile verde, but I want some carnitas and/or al pastor.
I guess they are trying to do a lighter version of burritos, which is okay, but I'd still rather have the carnitas at La Taqueria or the pastor at El Toro.
Still, they make good tasting food, the salsa is great, and the no cockroach thing is always a plus.
chile verde.author: Andy M.
chile verde.review:
Papalote has several features that set it apart from other Mission burrito joints:
1) it seems very clean and seeing a cockroach is highly unlikely
2) the space is slightly modern and interesting
3) I get the distinct impression that roving mariachi bands never come in here (I could be wrong)
4) They just plonk the burrito down on a plate - no foil

I miss the foil (it keeps the burrito from exploding out the bottom), and I do like roving bands of mariachis. I also wish they had more meat options, and no, "soyrizo" does not count. I like the chile verde, but I want some carnitas and/or al pastor. I guess they are trying to do a lighter version of burritos, which is okay, but I'd still rather have the carnitas at La Taqueria or the pastor at El Toro. Still, they make good tasting food, the salsa is great, and the no cockroach thing is always a plus.

excerpts: A Chile Verde burrito and a Carne Asada quesadilla.
The pork in the burrito was incredible!
chile verde.author: Gabriel R.
chile verde.review:
This is my first experience here and this is how it went:

Short wait in the cold. No problem though as it reminded me of home. Read the easy menu and went for it. A Chile Verde burrito and a Carne Asada quesadilla. The pork in the burrito was incredible! Seriously, not like shredded chicken at other places in town, but big tasty moist pieces that were fantastic for a $5 meal. The steak in the quesadilla (a little on the small side) was done extremely well. Typically, strips of steak tend to get overcooked and tough but these folks did it right with every piece. 

The salsa that was brought to the table was different. Incredibly tasty and just enough spice. I had never had anything like it and would buy the stuff by the jar...better yet, by the case! 

Can't wait to go back again.

excerpts: The chile verde is delicious and now my favorite item on the menu.
chile verde.author: Liz P.
chile verde.review:
Everyone raves about the salsa and rightfully so.  Others bitch that  if you want extra, you pay extra.  Please, it's fifty cents more and worth every penny.  Unlike any other salsa I've tasted.  Hotness varies each visit.

I find the food hit or miss.  The carne asada is bland and tough.  Shrimp tacos are the same.  Tortillas are the stiff, packaged variety.

The chile verde is delicious and now my favorite item on the menu.  I've tasted the fish tacos and not a fishy taste or smell about them.  A friend gives raves to the veggie burrito.  The chilaquiles are divine.

Papalote is located in what I call N'mission -- on the edge of Noe and the Mission.  If you're not into kids, then beware of the Noe Stroller Set.  They can overtake the place with often times not so well-behaved children.  Or clueless parents.  And why oh why can't they leave their strollers on the sidewalk?  The place is tiny enough.

Only a few tables in the joint, so you usually have to hover over diners like a vulture and swoop in as soon as one is free.

excerpts: I had the carne asada burrito and my wife had the Chile Verde (pork).
Excellent burrito, great size, perfect makeup of ingredients.
I preferred my wife's to mine but both were of the highest order.
Their salsa is so good I would eat it on a shoe.
chile verde.author: Ross H.
chile verde.review: Seen it on TV and was hyped about going here (even walked 4 miles to get there) and it didn't disappoint. I had the carne asada burrito and my wife had the Chile Verde (pork). Excellent burrito, great size, perfect makeup of ingredients. I preferred my wife's to mine but both were of the highest order. Their salsa is so good I would eat it on a shoe.

excerpts: I recently tried the chile verde quesadilla and it was soooo good.
It would be my new favorite except that it's pork, and I don't really eat pork.
The pork pieces were tender and delicious though.
chile verde.author: Darcy V.
chile verde.review:
I go here at least 3 times a week and as Nish pointed out, probably much more than that. Papalote means kite, and the restaurant (you can sit down) is cheerfully painted and hung with beautiful elaborate handmade kits that look like frogs, bugs, etc... and a world class collection of Latin and other music is playing at all times.

Food: The fish tacos are fantastic, and I love the prawn quesadilla, rice and bean taco, fish quesadille (seriously the only time fish and cheese can be used together) and nachos. I recently tried the chile verde quesadilla and it was soooo good. It would be my new favorite except that it's pork, and I don't really eat pork. The pork pieces were tender and delicious though. Maybe next time I'll ask if they can leave out the pork pieces and just heap on that yummy green sauce.

For 99 cents, I always "super" my order because the guacamole rocks. You can't even get an avocado at the market for 99cents, and they give a generous portion. The salsa is smoky and just the right amount of kick to it. It's worth the 50 cent charge to get another helping! The chips are thin, crisp and always served warm. Yum. 

Service:  awesome. "Perdito", who flashes his ever cheerful silver accented smile, is already filling my "pepsi regular" when I walk in the door. When the owner Miguel is there he always takes a moment to say hello.  Update: the Pepsi machine is "out of order" apparently because of a tiff with an incompetent supplies. Miguel refuses to do business with the guy and as a result, I'm going through some kind of Pepsi withdrawal. The homemade horchata is good, but sometimes I want that chemical kick of Pepsi. Rrrrrrrrrrrrrrr. Judith, the girl at the counter is always friendly and polite and acts like it's totally normal that I eat there every day.

excerpts: My favorite burrito is a super with chile verde pork and refried beans (the black beans are great
but I grew up on refried).
chile verde.author: Harlen W.
chile verde.review:
So the food is tasty enough to warrant a 5th star, but the burritos cost $10.  Ten dollars, in case you were thinking I mistyped that because you assume that only an airport or Disneyland would even think of charging $10 for a burrito.  The burritos are average to small in size so, no, they aren't bigger to justify the price.

So yeah, if you have decided to tolerate the $10, the ingredients are simple but definitely delicious and good quality.  The salsa is an amazing pumpkin seed concoction with a mild, but noticeable bite and my friends and I often buy a jar with our food.  My favorite burrito is a super with chile verde pork and refried beans (the black beans are great but I grew up on refried).

excerpts: The pork Chile Verde was also quite good, with distinct flavors of tomatillo, cilantro and citrus in the sauce.
chile verde.author: Avery G.
chile verde.review:
After hearing so many good things from friends, colleagues and even sources like Chow Magazine, I was excited to give Papalote a shot when my co-workers decided to head there for lunch. Finally, I would have a chance to sample their "practically-orgasmic" salsa!

Papalote is a taqueria with partial table service. You order your food at the counter, grab a drink, pay your way, take a number and head over to a table in the side room and eagerly await the server with your taco, burrito, quesadilla or other standard taqueria fare... which is exactly what I did. 

The chips (still warm) and salsa were brought almost immediately - and for all intents and purposes, they were the highlight of the meal. The rich orange salsa was spicy, sweet and had a complexity of flavor not commonly found in the condiment. The texture was smooth with black flecks - possibly from black pepper or from the skin of roasted pumpkin or peppers (yep - the secret ingredient, I have been told, is pumpkin seeds). This salsa's only competition for #1 in San Francisco is by Orale Orale.

The steak for the Carne Asada (which got very high marks from my co-workers), as well as the chicken, is cooked to order on a grill instead of scooped out of a steam table bin... and though I didn't sample it, the meat certainly looked good: appropriately charred and tender.

The pork Chile Verde was also quite good, with distinct flavors of tomatillo, cilantro and citrus in the sauce. Unfortunately, this filling, when combined with refried beans, cheese, rice and guacamole and wrapped in a tortilla, didn't meld into that cheesy-goopy goodness that makes an excellent burrito. It was good, but not great. Certainly not on par with Victor's or Mexico au Parc - which just goes to show you: even if every component of a dish is excellent, sometimes it doesn't come together properly to make something amazing. This time, the components were better than the sum of its parts.

$8.89 for a super burrito, chips, salsa and a bottle of grapefruit soda. 3 stars for now, but I will certainly be back to try a carne asada quesadilla.

excerpts: I had a green chile verde burrito
and I ATE THE ENTIRE BURRITO,
auhghghahghghghg, blah blah blah...vomitous, etc.

The burrito was good, you know, like average for mexican food but holy crapola was that salsa that I drowned my slab of lard in tasty, mmmhhhh, my lunch date wasn't lying when she said she sometimes ponders slathering it all over her body to attract men....
now, if you'll excuse me I need to go to the bathroom and throw up, and then apply this wonder tonic...
chile verde.author: Claire C.
chile verde.review:
You know how you go somewhere to eat and the food is so good and you're so starving that you shove an entire burrito and platter of chips and salsa in your mouth and then 10 minutes later you like, totally HATE mexican food and the thought of a taco makes you feel like vomiting? Yes?  Well, that's how I feel right now at this exact moment.  

I am, however, an extremely sophisticated human being and am able to distinguish between the "hatred coma" and my "true feelings" about a restaurant, and my true feelings about Papalote are this, "HOLY CRAP THAT'S SOME GOOD SALSA."  I had a green chile verde burrito and I ATE THE ENTIRE BURRITO, auhghghahghghghg, blah blah blah...vomitous, etc.  The burrito was good, you know, like average for mexican food but holy crapola was that salsa that I drowned my slab of lard in tasty, mmmhhhh, my lunch date wasn't lying when she said she sometimes ponders slathering it all over her body to attract men....now, if you'll excuse me I need to go to the bathroom and throw up, and then apply this wonder tonic...

excerpts: chile verde super burrito ordered herr, bloods.
chile verde.author: Victor B.
chile verde.review:
chile verde super burrito ordered herr, bloods.

2 things stand head and shoulders above all other burritos:

1. the sauce: great spice, delicious flavors. try it.
2. the something-or-other spice in the burrito. there was some flavor in this bad boy that made other burritos bow down to it as other rappers do to ice cube, WC, and mack 10 from the westside connection.

excerpts: I go there for their awesome salsa and chile verde (which I never order anywhere else).
But, I had to take off two stars because it's been a nightmare to go there ever since the were featured on Bobby Flay, even calling in and picking up takes forever.
The phone line is always busy and I've had to redial, as if I was trying to win a prize on the radio.
Of course, I had to try the triple threat but save your money and get something else because it's definitely not worth $20!
It's good but
not THAT good.
chile verde.author: Marleen C.
chile verde.review: I've been going to this place before it was featured on the Food Network.  This is one of my favorite taquerias in the city.  I go there for their awesome salsa and chile verde (which I never order anywhere else).  But, I had to take off two stars because it's been a nightmare to go there ever since the were featured on Bobby Flay, even calling in and picking up takes forever.  The phone line is always busy and I've had to redial, as if I was trying to win a prize on the radio.  Of course, I had to try the triple threat but save your money and get something else because it's definitely not worth $20!  It's good but not THAT good.

excerpts: Also contributing to the loss of the star is that their chile verde, although good, is not nearly the best in the City.
Try Taqueria Mana for that.
chile verde.author: Josh B.
chile verde.review:
FIRST! not.

The big debate in SF is of course where the best burrito is made. It ain't here.

But 'lote is good. My main problem is their fucked up salsa. I can't decide if I like it, or if it's so alarmingly weird that I should just hate on it for sheer principal. Let's go with "it's good salsa." But I'm deducting a star because I had to the think about it.

Also contributing to the loss of the star is that their chile verde, although good, is not nearly the best in the City. Try Taqueria Mana for that.

excerpts: Chile Verde burrito, chips and salsa and a diet coke for under $10!
But not sure is worth waiting 15 mins outside in the cold for a table...darn food network hype.
kudos to papalote however!
a must visit as a sampling of the mission for tourists or locals!
chile verde.author: Michael K.
chile verde.review: Yum! Chile Verde burrito, chips and salsa and a diet coke for under $10! But not sure is worth waiting 15 mins outside in the cold for a table...darn food network hype. kudos to papalote however! a must visit as a sampling of the mission for tourists or locals!

excerpts: Chile Verde tacos - so so.
Not worth $5.15 for two, at all.
No service complaints, but no warmth either.
Salsa obviously delicious.
Should have spent $1.50 on chips+salsa and left it at that.
chile verde.author: Will T.
chile verde.review:
Kind of silly art and an overly clean space say C'MON WHITE KIDZ.
Chile Verde tacos - so so. Not worth $5.15 for two, at all. No service complaints, but no warmth either. Salsa obviously delicious. Should have spent $1.50 on chips+salsa and left it at that.

excerpts: But have to say that the chile verde left much to be desired.
Atmosphere is nothing great-
your typical mission hole.
often hard to get a table- with a weird system of having to order first-
so you don't actually know if you're going to get a table.
The service is quick enough, but not friendly, etc.
Still worth checking out!
chile verde.author: Steph C.
chile verde.review: I think everything about this place has already been said. Stick with the burritos and you'll be in good shape. The carne asada is great- tender and tasty chunks of meat. But have to say that the chile verde left much to be desired. Atmosphere is nothing great- your typical mission hole. often hard to get a table- with a weird system of having to order first- so you don't actually know if you're going to get a table. The service is quick enough, but not friendly, etc. Still worth checking out!

excerpts: Really really good Chile Verde chicken burrito.
Their  tortillas are great, thick, lovely pancakes of goodness.
The chipolte salsa is addictive.
Sure, its not the run down place that you expect from one of the best burritos in the mission, but then again...
chile verde.author: Matt C.
chile verde.review:
Really really good Chile Verde chicken burrito. Their  tortillas are great, thick, lovely pancakes of goodness. The chipolte salsa is addictive. Sure, its not the run down place that you expect from one of the best burritos in the mission, but then again... Why's that a bad thing?

-1 for the crowding, lack of table sitations, that can occur.

excerpts: I got the marinated tofu, which was pretty good, but she got the chile verde, which was...
wow.
So tender, and flavor for days.
It's a cute little place, but I could see it getting CROWDED on busy nights.
chile verde.author: Ed M.
chile verde.review:
I couldn't get enough of the salsa! Damn, I'm craving it right now. 

My friend and I were just walking around the neighborhood looking for eats when their colorful  dining area sucked us in... I got the marinated tofu, which was pretty good, but she got the chile verde, which was...wow. So tender, and flavor for days. It's a cute little place, but I could see it getting CROWDED on busy nights.

excerpts: There are many yummy filling options, e.g. carne asada, chile verde, pescado, vegetarian, gambas, etc., that you can apply towards burritos, tacos and quesadillas.
You can also order entrees that come on a plate and are accompanied by rice, beans and tortillas.
Today I had the carne asada entree plate for lunch.

And said lunch companion was gleefully happy with his chile verde super burrito, which he said was one of the best burritos he'd ever had, due to the tasty and tender pork concoction that I regretably forewent.
chile verde.author: Kimberly Q.
chile verde.review:
There are a ton of reviews that I don't need to rehash.  You walk in and, though the counter service is friendly, you should know pretty quickly what you want to order, as there is usually a line of hungry people behind you.  

There are many yummy filling options, e.g. carne asada, chile verde, pescado, vegetarian, gambas, etc., that you can apply towards burritos, tacos and quesadillas.  You can also order entrees that come on a plate and are accompanied by rice, beans and tortillas.  Today I had the carne asada entree plate for lunch.  It came with two good-sized pieces of steak that were grilled to order.  They were, in my opinion somewhat dry due to overcooking but were admittedly tasty.  They were accentuated by the guacamole that came with my lunch companion's super burrito that he did not want.  And said lunch companion was gleefully happy with his chile verde super burrito, which he said was one of the best burritos he'd ever had, due to the tasty and tender pork concoction that I regretably forewent.  

The place was pretty clean and comfy.  I'd come back, but I did not leave the place dreaming of my next venture in.

excerpts: I had the Chile Verde tacos, which is a marinated pork.
chile verde.author: Tien H.
chile verde.review:
I had the Chile Verde tacos, which is a marinated pork. 

As soon a I got it, I reached for the hot sauce but decided to take a bite first. We had just gotten back from Mexico and I don't think I could have handled a disappointing taco; it would have broken my heart. 

Luckily, I was not disappointed and it was the juiciest, most flavorful taco. I put the hotsauce down and didn't even look at the salt/pepper for extra flavor.  The food was absolutely delish and I'm a huge fan. Will definitely come back!

excerpts: I have actually never ordered anything else... but my boyfriend really likes their Chile Verde (although El Metate's is better and cheaper).
Oh, I almost forgot, Awesome salsa!
chile verde.author: Liz A.
chile verde.review: I don't know about all this triple threat nonsense... sounds like a boy burrito to me... but, If you want a really kick ass fish burrito, this is the spot.  Now kick ass-itude don't come cheap... for a burrito that is.  This puppy will set you back like $10 ( I'm used to $5 burritos at El Metate)  but no other place comes anywhere close to being this good.  I have actually never ordered anything else... but my boyfriend really likes their Chile Verde (although El Metate's is better and cheaper).  Oh, I almost forgot, Awesome salsa!

excerpts: We got the chile verde burrito and the soyrizo burrito.
I suppose they deserve props for offering lots of vegetarian options to wean people off meat.

The chile verde was just all right--big hunks of slightly dry and stringy meat in a not very flavorful sauce; the soyrizo spicy and as you might expect; both burritos running over with no structural integrity--the kind of SF burrito that ordinarily is wrapped in foil, but perhaps they are trying to avoid the foil here
and so you eat it with knife and fork.

The chile verde was just all right--big hunks of slightly dry and stringy meat in a not very flavorful sauce; the soyrizo spicy and as you might expect; both burritos running over with no structural integrity--the kind of SF burrito that ordinarily is wrapped in foil, but perhaps they are trying to avoid the foil here
and so you eat it with knife and fork.
chile verde.author: Ryan C.
chile verde.review: All right, but I'd rather have a $3 taco truck veggie burrito than one of these. Yes, the salsa is great, so maybe I would go here and just get chips and salsa. We got the chile verde burrito and the soyrizo burrito. I suppose they deserve props for offering lots of vegetarian options to wean people off meat. The chile verde was just all right--big hunks of slightly dry and stringy meat in a not very flavorful sauce; the soyrizo spicy and as you might expect; both burritos running over with no structural integrity--the kind of SF burrito that ordinarily is wrapped in foil, but perhaps they are trying to avoid the foil here and so you eat it with knife and fork.

excerpts: I had a chile verde (pork in green serrano sauce) burrito that was excellent -- large chunks of juicy, flavorful pork throughout, well spiced, moist and just really good.
Plus excellent, smoky and slightly creamy salsa served with warm, freshly-fried chips.
Only minor letdown was the horchata, which was lukewarm (despite the ice in the cup), on the watery side and a bit too sweet.
But that's a quibble -- this place was a winner
and I'd definitely go back.
chile verde.author: J. P.
chile verde.review: Went for a quick lunch and left very satisfied. I had a chile verde (pork in green serrano sauce) burrito that was excellent -- large chunks of juicy, flavorful pork throughout, well spiced, moist and just really good. Plus excellent, smoky and slightly creamy salsa served with warm, freshly-fried chips. Only minor letdown was the horchata, which was lukewarm (despite the ice in the cup), on the watery side and a bit too sweet. But that's a quibble -- this place was a winner and I'd definitely go back.

excerpts: The Carne Asada and Chicken are great, but for a special treat, try their mole or Pork Chile Verde.
Tres Bien.
chile verde.author: Andy T.
chile verde.review:
As a child growing up in San Diego (15 minutes north of the border), I was practically weaned on good Mexican food. I have to admit, I was definitely skeptical reading menu items like "Tofu Soy-Rizo", but my fears melted away when I dipped my first chip into the salsa - oh, that glorious salsa, as man has never made it before.

People will argue that this is Yuppified Mexican, and it probably is since there is no brain or head on the menu - in my mind though, this is actually a good thing. They only serve the freshest ingredients, the best cuts of meat in all of their dishes, and I could go there for every meal.

The Carne Asada and Chicken are great, but for a special treat, try their mole or Pork Chile Verde. Tres Bien.

excerpts: I had a chile verde burrito with black refried beans- super style, my friend had the soy-rizo burrito and they were both so unique in flavor.
Really really uniquely different.
chile verde.author: Sean W.
chile verde.review:
Delicious, fresh tasting and oh so delicious. The only negative was standing in the long line out the door, and the tiny space for dine-in. meh.

I had a chile verde burrito with black refried beans- super style, my friend had the soy-rizo burrito and they were both so unique in flavor. Really really uniquely different. (??)

Delicious.

excerpts: For the meats my personal favorites are the prawns (nice smokey addition to the burrito), chile verde (good size chunks of pork and tasty sauce) and chicken mole (I hate chicken breast, but
the mole sauce is so nommiful that it covers the dryness of the chicken).
the mole sauce is so nommiful that it covers the dryness of the chicken).
chile verde.author: Kelly C.
chile verde.review: Papalote's has ruined me for burritos anywhere else. Theirs are, by far, the best I've encountered in the Bay Area. I thought La Bamba in Mountain View did an awesome burrito; I was wrong. Papalote's super burrito is at least twice as tasty and all kinds of nommilicious. Their salsa is a little spicy by my standards (which are average-ish), but it's so delicious that you don't mind the burn. For the meats my personal favorites are the prawns (nice smokey addition to the burrito), chile verde (good size chunks of pork and tasty sauce) and chicken mole (I hate chicken breast, but the mole sauce is so nommiful that it covers the dryness of the chicken).

excerpts: I think their burritos (my favorites are chile verde and soyrizo) are far superior to their tacos, which tend to have too much lettuce.
Their nachos are also great.

In fact, the only reasons I'm rating them four stars instead of five are the 1) recent 13% price increase; 2) long wait/table scarcity during peak times; and 3) small, close together tables that necessitate having to sit too close to greasy poser hipsters (though some of them are cute) when dining in.
chile verde.author: Steven W.
chile verde.review: I LOVE Papalote and I have been coming here at least once a week for three years.  There really isn't much else to write.  I feel as if the restaurant offers traditional Mexican food minus some of the cuisine's more negative aspects (e.g., lard).  I think their burritos (my favorites are chile verde and soyrizo) are far superior to their tacos, which tend to have too much lettuce.  Their nachos are also great.  In fact, the only reasons I'm rating them four stars instead of five are the 1) recent 13% price increase; 2) long wait/table scarcity during peak times; and 3) small, close together tables that necessitate having to sit too close to greasy poser hipsters (though some of them are cute) when dining in.

excerpts:
good
chile verde ques is very good
carne asada super burrito is good
chile verde.author: Christopher L.
chile verde.review:
horchata is GREAT
guac is bleh, chips are awesome
chicken is crazy dry and gross
shrimp tacos are good
chile verde ques is very good
carne asada super burrito is good

excerpts: I had a chile verde burrito, which tasted okay, but was also really runny, so I ended up needing a fork and knife to eat it.
I don't see any reason to go here over another place.
chile verde.author: Jonathan G.
chile verde.review: It seemed like it was supposed to be a nicer joint, but the food did seem much different than what I would get at any other taqueria in the neighborhood. I had a chile verde burrito, which tasted okay, but was also really runny, so I ended up needing a fork and knife to eat it. I don't see any reason to go here over another place.

excerpts: The chile verde pork was very tender.
There was Yucatan hot sauce, which is always a plus.
And there was spiced up jicama served as the side, which was deliciously refreshing.
Basically, overrated white washed Mexican food, which is fine as long as you know what you're in for.
chile verde.author: Daniella C.
chile verde.review:
There's something really off about this place for me. Maybe it's the soyrizo burrito on the menu, or maybe it's because the people who rave about it are usually vegetarians or hipsters. Those are two groups you generally can't trust in regards to good Mexican food. And yeah, I know, I know I'm not first generation, Lily, but I'm fairly certain that authentic Mexican food does not include shrimp sauteed in white wine and butter. And where do they get off charging three dollars for a plain taco? Maybe I'm being harsh because I think seafood tacos are a waste of time and stomach space, but white wine? Oh, and they have tofu on the menu. I like tofu as much as the next gal, but man... And I've only seen the place packed with white people, the kind with dreads or people who look like they just got out of yoga class.
