I had heard about their adobo burrito, but I was more curious to see if the Triple Threat lived up to its name. Based on a Bay Area DJ group, this is goodness X3 with the incorporation of carne asada, shrimp, and chicken. Only thing I couldn't believe was the price. It costs under $20. Holy shh..! My friend and I decided to split one, and also ordered some super nachos. That was already plenty, yet they threw in some chips and salsa with our order. I was able to get a bit of everything with each bite. The nachos were awesome as well. We barely got through half of it because of the Triple Threat. Once finished, I washed it all down with a horchata. I can honestly say that theirs is excellent; not watered down and has just the right amount of cinnamon. It was nice to taste a bit of history, but I think I'll try something different, and cheaper, next time.

excerpts: we ordered the pescado burrito, carne asada entree plate, carne asada burrito, chicken nachos and a couple of tacos.
the burrito have a toasted flour tortilla that does not hold shape and fell apart all over the plate.
the meats were decent with not much flavor.
ive had way better at many other places.
carne asada.author: Toby F.
carne asada.review: I went here with my family after reading all the good reviews on yelp. sorry to say, the yelpers have let me down. this place is very popular with an endless supply of customers, but i am baffled to why. my experience was that the food was satisfactory at best. we ordered the pescado burrito, carne asada entree plate, carne asada burrito, chicken nachos and a couple of tacos. the burrito have a toasted flour tortilla that does not hold shape and fell apart all over the plate. the meats were decent with not much flavor. ive had way better at many other places. the fish was not very well seasoned and the beans were bland. too much rice was used as stuffing the burrito so they wouldnt have to complement it with as much meat/fish. the staff was nice but rushed and spread very thin. this place is probably so popular because of its appearance with bobby flays show throwdown and their awards. they probably lean on those credentials and with its high demand dont put out the quality they used to at one point. oh yeah, very expensive for taqueria food, even for san francisco!

excerpts: You cannot go wrong with the plain old rice and bean burrito, but if you can have meat the chicken and carne asada burritos
should be your choice.
carne asada.author: Aamir V.
carne asada.review:
Papalote is the be-all, end-all of burritos in the Mission.  Fresh?  You bet.  Tasty?  Of course.  Salsa worthy of a pligrimage?  Absolutely.

You cannot go wrong with the plain old rice and bean burrito, but if you can have meat the chicken and carne asada burritos should be your choice.  They also have some other intriguing options like soyrizo, so make sure you schedule multiple visits.

The nachos are mediocre - pass on those.

I hate that they ration the salsa, but it's understandable.  That stuff is truly amazing.

excerpts: the salsa gets 4 stars for sure and the carne asada burrito wasn't bad either.
i wasn't blown away by the burrito, but the salsa more than made up for it with just the right amount of heat.
carne asada.author: Gordon F.
carne asada.review: the salsa gets 4 stars for sure and the carne asada burrito wasn't bad either. i wasn't blown away by the burrito, but the salsa more than made up for it with just the right amount of heat.

excerpts: I was afraid that the meat wasn't going to be good or that I was going to be stared down if I ordered Carne Asada
carne asada.author: Megan K.
carne asada.review: I used to be on the fence about this place. I was concerned about the Vegan and Vegetarian elements of the menu. I was afraid that the meat wasn't going to be good or that I was going to be stared down if I ordered Carne Asada...so I ordered fish. The fish tacos (white fish sauteed in white wine sauce) are fabulous-- make sure to add avocado for pep. They got me by for a while and then Papalote started to die on the vine for me. BUT THEN-- I decided to get some balls and order the meat. It's amazing. It's lean. It's flavorful. It's everything you want in a Mexican meal. The salsa is fresh and tastes so rich it's as though it has a stick of butter in every ounce. You should go to Papalote--really.

excerpts: We're talkin' about a fresh raw piece of carne asada or chicken put on the grill especially for your burrito.
That's what Papalote is about.
Some people prefer McDonalds french fries over real freshly sliced potato french fries.
So if you wan't McDonalds, go to the taqueria down the street.
They're food is clearly fresh and delicious and some people aren't used to that.
They're salsa is also incredible.
carne asada.author: Adrian N.
carne asada.review: I go to this place often, as i live a block away.  ever heard of a taqueria where you're tacos, burritos and quesadillas are MADE TO ORDER?  Really.  I am not talking about a scoop of pre-cooked meat from a bucket and onto the grill.  We're talkin' about a fresh raw piece of carne asada or chicken put on the grill especially for your burrito.  That's what Papalote is about.   Some people prefer McDonalds french fries over real freshly sliced potato french fries.  So if you wan't McDonalds, go to the taqueria down the street.  They're food is clearly fresh and delicious and some people aren't used to that.  They're salsa is also incredible.  For those veggies and vegans out there, this place is also the spot.  The only down side is it can get pretty busy and the line can sometimes be out the door.    I've called a few times to place an order and they've screwed it up more than once.  But they're food is still damn good.

excerpts: my baseline burrito at each new joint, is a carne asada super burrito with no rice and no sour cream and this was an absolute knockout here.
i loved that fact that they had refried black beans so that kicked up the flavor big time!
and i'd be remiss by not mention their salsa here.
holy moly
this is good!
i was slathering this stuff on chips and everything edible.
it's very smoky and almost has a very tandoori type of flavor!
i can't wait to go back and try out some camarones :-)
carne asada.author: Swarup B.
carne asada.review: i was torn about making this a 5 star place but the fact they slightly messed up the wife's order brought them down to a 4.  that aside, the burrito here is the best i've had in the city.  it topples la corneta as the king for me.  my baseline burrito at each new joint, is a carne asada super burrito with no rice and no sour cream and this was an absolute knockout here.  i loved that fact that they had refried black beans so that kicked up the flavor big time!  and i'd be remiss by not mention their salsa here.  holy moly this is good!  i was slathering this stuff on chips and everything edible.  it's very smoky and almost has a very tandoori type of flavor!  i can't wait to go back and try out some camarones :-)

excerpts: basically there are plain, arroz y frijoles, veggie, grilled veggie, marinated tofu, soyrizo, mole, chile verde, carne asada, pollo, camarones, prawn and prescado choices for either burritos, quesadillas and 2 tacos.
and to super size it
their grilled veggie tacos are devine.
their grilled veggie tacos are devine.
i also tried the mole, which was a bit watery for my taste.
overall, it is pretty good and i will definitely visit again.
also, the salsa is really fabulous and flavorful.
the decor is nice and clean, unlike a lot of similar places in sf mission area.
i will recommend it!
also it is close to 24th street mission bart.
carne asada.author: Cindy L.
carne asada.review: oh my can i give it a 6 stars? i am so addicted to this place. i always come here after steph snyder's class at yoga tree valencia. it's pretty much a ritual. the price is unbeatable. 2 tacos for 3 bucks? it's fabulous. basically there are plain, arroz y frijoles, veggie, grilled veggie, marinated tofu, soyrizo, mole, chile verde, carne asada, pollo, camarones, prawn and prescado choices for either burritos, quesadillas and 2 tacos. and to super size it, you can add sour cream, cheese and guacamole for 99 cents! woo wee! their grilled veggie tacos are devine. i also tried the mole, which was a bit watery for my taste. overall, it is pretty good and i will definitely visit again. also, the salsa is really fabulous and flavorful. the decor is nice and clean, unlike a lot of similar places in sf mission area. i will recommend it! also it is close to 24th street mission bart.

excerpts: Enroute to the appointment my friend ate his "shrimp burrito"-oops, in checking the order we in fact got 2 carne asada burritos and one triple threat.
Don't know how our original order translated to this...but to be fair we checked the reciept and we paid for what we got.
We just did not get what I asked for.
carne asada.author: C. W.
carne asada.review: A friend and I made the mistake of going to Papalotes the day after the throwdown with Bobby Flay. There were only 2 or 3 people ahead of us. We arrived at 2:00pm. I place our order to go(by now there was a line of about 25 people behind us): 2 triple threats and a shrimp burrito. I really hadn't looked at the prices, but when the cashier ran up the total to 42.00 I about had a heart attack. I paid it. Then we waited, and waited and waited and waited some more. Finally got our order. It was now 3:00. We had an appointment, so I did not check our order. Enroute to the appointment my friend ate his "shrimp burrito"-oops, in checking the order we in fact got 2 carne asada burritos and one triple threat. Don't know how our original order translated to this...but to be fair we checked the reciept and we paid for what we got. We just did not get what I asked for. Yes, a triple threat is $20.00, but like what has been written about here before,they are the same size as the steak burrito. I will never order the triple threat again. It is really a rip. It tasted good, but not worth the price.

excerpts: Unfortunately the meats -- namely, the chile verde, carne asada and grilled chicken -- tend to be dry and a bit tough, possibly because it appears that the pork, beef and chicken are cooked with virtually all their fat trimmed away; even so, they are well-seasoned and thus quite enjoyable, especially when dispatched in a super burrito, which keeps the moisture level up by way of sour cream, cheese and guacamole.
carne asada.author: Eugene P.
carne asada.review: Papalote is a healthful change of pace from the usual Mission fare, offering meats not drenched in lipids, refried beans without lard and various vegan ingredients like grilled marinated tofu, mole tofu and soyrizo. The lettuce, tomatoes, cilantro and other auxiliary ingredients are always fresh, and the award-winning house salsa, which is made from scratch every day, is dangerously addictive and worthy of its reputation as the best salsa in the city. Unfortunately the meats -- namely, the chile verde, carne asada and grilled chicken -- tend to be dry and a bit tough, possibly because it appears that the pork, beef and chicken are cooked with virtually all their fat trimmed away; even so, they are well-seasoned and thus quite enjoyable, especially when dispatched in a super burrito, which keeps the moisture level up by way of sour cream, cheese and guacamole. Omnivores not interested in smothering their meats in such heavy condiments may want to steer toward the marinated seafood options: prawns grilled with lime juice, sauteed shrimp and sauteed fish. Papalote may not provide what most would consider traditional Mexican food, but it does offer satisfying, heart-smart innovations in Mexican cuisine.

excerpts: Fear not because your carne asada burrito has arrived with that mango salsa on the side!
One savory  cube per perfectly balanced bite, of course.
(You can't waste the little gems, which are clearly rare given how much is on each plate.)

I would almost initially dock a point for them not giving you more of that salsa, but once you master the burrito, you realize they give you the perfect amount as to not drown out all of the other excellent flavors.
They throw a piece of meat on the grill  when your order it, cooked to your desire.
None of that scoop-out-of-the-bin jargon.
To be honest I haven't had any vegetarian here because when I think about Papalote, I smell that grill, get hungry and head over.
Tall boys of PBR contribute to the 5 star rating as well.

I don't usually wait long (I have not had a bad experience other than learning peak hours the hard way, but I've learned to get around that), but I am also not one of those people who shows up 10 deep at a place with like 4 tables and counter seating.
You know who you are!
carne asada.author: J W.
carne asada.review: Oh man...The salsa for the chips is pretty unique and what I would consider to be more "pasty" than chunky. But it's good and weird in a way so you keep going back to it until your warm, fresh chips are gone. Fear not because your carne asada burrito has arrived with that mango salsa on the side! One savory  cube per perfectly balanced bite, of course. (You can't waste the little gems, which are clearly rare given how much is on each plate.) I would almost initially dock a point for them not giving you more of that salsa, but once you master the burrito, you realize they give you the perfect amount as to not drown out all of the other excellent flavors. They throw a piece of meat on the grill  when your order it, cooked to your desire. None of that scoop-out-of-the-bin jargon. To be honest I haven't had any vegetarian here because when I think about Papalote, I smell that grill, get hungry and head over. Tall boys of PBR contribute to the 5 star rating as well. I don't usually wait long (I have not had a bad experience other than learning peak hours the hard way, but I've learned to get around that), but I am also not one of those people who shows up 10 deep at a place with like 4 tables and counter seating. You know who you are!

excerpts: But the super pollo asado burrito in a spinach tortilla hit the spot and then some.
The salsa is legitimately one of the best I've had (and I've been eating Mexican in the Bay Area for 30 years!)
pollo asado.author: Mi-Yung R.
pollo asado.review:
Came in last weekend after a long walk up and back from Twin Peaks, so I was famished and anything would have satisfied me. But the super pollo asado burrito in a spinach tortilla hit the spot and then some. The salsa is legitimately one of the best I've had (and I've been eating Mexican in the Bay Area for 30 years!) and the guacamole was outstanding. 

It's a little cramped at the counter where they take the orders, but seating is decent. Not a place to linger but that's not the point here. Since we arrived on foot, I can't speak for parking, but it's in the Mission neighborhood so it would be silly to expect easy parking.

Price wise it's comparable to any other burrito joint, but for the money, I'll be back for the 'sabores'!

excerpts: When you get the chicken burrito or deconstructed bowl, be sure to ask for the adobo chicken, not the pollo asado...
the adobo is shredded and so tender, while the pollo asado I believe is just diced roasted chicken.
pollo asado.author: Janet H.
pollo asado.review:
Not quite sure why this place only has 3.5 stars, but I've learned to overlook Yelp ratings once in awhile. There are many Mexican restaurants in the area, so reviewers are probably just comparing to the classics like El Farolito and La Taqueria... but I personally loved Papalote because of its naked burrito with adobo chicken. 

I seriously would've never known of this place until a yoga friend of mine was eating it before class. It looked so tasty that I got it the next day before yoga class (slightly bad idea)... yes, it is on the pricier side and added up to $13 but it is a meal for 3 days. I had it for lunch yesterday, and then lunch today... and I still have a good amount of rice and beans left that I can pair with other protein for dinner tonight. 

Papalote was also featured on Bobby Flay's show, which is pretty cool. The food is flavorful and I enjoyed every bite. It even comes with a generous serving of guacamole! Bonus points for their amazing complimentary salsa for their chips!

When you get the chicken burrito or deconstructed bowl, be sure to ask for the adobo chicken, not the pollo asado... the adobo is shredded and so tender, while the pollo asado I believe is just diced roasted chicken. Luckily they were able to change my order last minute when I realized there was a difference. 

I'm going to yoga again on Tuesday and I'm planning on getting another naked burrito. It's that good!

excerpts: The Carne Asada & Pollo Asado burritos are pretty good too, sans shrimp.
The single meat burritos are about $10, which is a little pricey.
pollo asado.author: Joy W.
pollo asado.review:
About six years ago, Flay challenged Papalote to a burrito contest and the triple threat burrito triumphed. I wish I knew what Papalote was like before it was featured on Throwdown. Was the triple threat always $20? Back then, $20 was a lot of cash for a burrito and it still is now, but at least that burrito hasn't been affected by inflation in these past few years. Also, the hype has calmed down compared to those crowds after the episode first aired. 

Triple Threat - chicken breast, carne asada, prawns:
It's loaded with 3 types of proteins, but I don't feel threatened. The taste and quality is on par with most burritos, so in comparison, the price tag sure is steep. The grilled prawns were the best part. They're tender and springy with a nice char. Plus, the prawns are left whole instead of chopped up beyond recognition. The chicken and carne asada are nicely seasoned, too. 
It is a very large burrito, so if you need a reason to justify spending $20, you can share it or split it between two meals. It's also a good decision if you have a tough time choosing between poultry, beef, & seafood, or if you're just curious to try it, but it is not a must have.

The Carne Asada & Pollo Asado burritos are pretty good too, sans shrimp. The single meat burritos are about $10, which is a little pricey. Adding cheese, guac, or sour cream are each $1. Kind of a bummer, since burritos usually include cheese. If you're going to add one, you might as well add all 3 for $2, resulting in a very creamy burrito. 

Of course the roasted tomato salsa is excellent. It is the true threat here. This thick & creamy, robust, orange sauce is like a flavor explosion of smokey, sweet, savory, spicy, and slightly tart. This salsa is excellent on their thin, warm chips, as well as on everything else. Jars of Papalote's various salsas are available for purchase in various local markets. 
Overall, I'm satisfied with the food, but the prices are high relative to other Mexican joints in the Mission, so I give it a 7.25/10.

excerpts: My pollo asado burrito was too soggy for my preference and also just lacked flavor.
I found myself adding a lot of hot sauce just to add some taste.
Not to mention the food is overpriced.
Go to el farolito or as my coworker suggested, La Palma, for really good authentic Mexican food.
pollo asado.author: Liz C.
pollo asado.review:
Don't agree with the hype. 

Good for vegans (so I would come back if I had that eating preference), but so overrated otherwise. My pollo asado burrito was too soggy for my preference and also just lacked flavor. I found myself adding a lot of hot sauce just to add some taste. Not to mention the food is overpriced. Go to el farolito or as my coworker suggested, La Palma, for really good authentic Mexican food.

excerpts:
good, but not authentic
- Salsa is unique, love that they give you chips/salsa with your order - worth trying this place for this only
- Pollo asado, carne asada are both "good", not amazing or authentic tasting
- I've only done takeout so never had to wait
pollo asado.author: Melody T.
pollo asado.review:
Another 3.5 rating - went for the 4 stars as the salsa deserves that extra 1/2 star.

- "Americanized" Mexican food (imo)
- Tastes good, but not authentic
- Salsa is unique, love that they give you chips/salsa with your order - worth trying this place for this only
- Pollo asado, carne asada are both "good", not amazing or authentic tasting
- I've only done takeout so never had to wait

excerpts: Their pollo asado is marinated perfectly and works well in their super burrito.
pollo asado.author: Robby F.
pollo asado.review:
Seriously!  That salsa is sooo good.  Their pollo asado is marinated perfectly and works well in their super burrito.  Friendly service, generous guacamole portions, sweetly pickled jalapeños, just all around good food.

Keep up the good work!

excerpts: Usually, I go with the Pollo Asado Super Burrito.
Although a little bland on its own, but the salsa definitely kicks it up a notch.
Combine that with Reed's ginger ale and that's a wonderful meal.
pollo asado.author: Dennis L.
pollo asado.review:
The closest thing to La Victoria's orange sauce! Although I think they call it a chipotle salsa, every time I take a bite, it still reminds me of the orange goodness from SJ.

Parking at both locations can be rather difficult but the proximity of bars makes this location my favorite of the two. Seating can be limited, but customer turnover is fast so you can usually count on having a seat by the time you've ordered and your food is ready. The tables are stacked next to each other so different combinations of group sizes feel like a game of Diner Dash. Occasionally, other diners may overhear or eavesdrop your conversation and chime in. 

Usually, I go with the Pollo Asado Super Burrito. Although a little bland on its own, but the salsa definitely kicks it up a notch. Combine that with Reed's ginger ale and that's a wonderful meal. For the really adventurous ones, you can opt for the chicken/beef/shrimp super burrito. That shit cray!

excerpts: The pollo asado burrito remains delicious on account of their special marinade and the grill flavor.
Every bite yum.
But what if I came in one day with the family and we tried something different...
pollo asado.author: Ben S.
pollo asado.review:
2.5 stars

The pollo asado burrito remains delicious on account of their special marinade and the grill flavor.  Every bite yum.  
But what if I came in one day with the family and we tried something different... perhaps one of their plates?

Pork chile verde:  should've been named Green Pork in Garlic Sauce cause that's all we could taste.  Not the tangy, intangible yum of tomatillos. Not the zing of chili.  Hell, not even pork-flavored. Care to guess what you COULD taste?  Fail.

Chicken Mole:  was rich as mole negro should be.  The sauce is deeply flavored BUT way over-chocolate-y, covering up practically all the chili pepper flavors.  The chicken breast was tough, overcooked to the point in which it required earnest effort to cut with a fork. 

Spanish omelet:  good cheesy goodness with mushrooms and bell peppers throughout but it suffered from overcooked eggs.  Browned scrambled egg has a particularly strong flavor and if you dig it, you'll be pleased.  I find it just short of revolting.

Conclusion:  stick with the burrito at $7.50 and pass on the $13 plates.

excerpts: But our soyrizo, pollo asado, and chicken mole quesadillas were taking an eternity.
The soyrizo quesadilla was excellent.
The chicken mole fantastic.
But again, the wait cost us better seats for movie night.
The chicken mole fantastic.
But again, the wait cost us better seats for movie night.
pollo asado.author: Jenny K.
pollo asado.review:
Hm. This is a tough one for me. The food is so fresh and tasty and the salsa insanely good, but the service, incomprehensibly long wait and nickel-and-diming are absurd.

We came here to grab some food  to-go before Dolores Park Movie Night. Little did we know that it would take 30 MINUTES for our order to be ready. Does it really take that long to make three quesadillas? Really? 

The lady at the cash register is also not friendly. She is the Mexican Food Nazi with scary eyebrows to match. We adore the salsa (shit, I could drink the stuff it's so freakin' good!) and asked for extra chips to go with the jar we were buying. She shook her head, "No extra chips," and told us each little scoop cost $1. $1!!! 

We stood around and watched order after order (by people who ordered AFTER us, by the way) go out the door. But our soyrizo, pollo asado, and chicken mole quesadillas were taking an eternity. 

When we finally got our food 30 minutes later, it was almost worth the wait. ALMOST. The soyrizo quesadilla was excellent. The chicken mole fantastic. But again, the wait cost us better seats for movie night. And let's not forget that the food is over-priced. 

I am going to have to try the one on Fulton. It's closer to where I live and I am hoping the service and wait are better than the Mission location.

excerpts: My husband ordered his usual--a prawn and chicken quesadilla, and I ordered my usual--a veggie burrito.
Our total came out to be around $29!
What's even worse is that my husband's quesadilla was so tiny (only two pieces) and barely any prawns in there.
They didn't even put his quesadilla in a box, they just wrapped it in foil, which caused the food to get all messed up and sloppy.
We typically don't mind paying extra for top quality food,
prawn.author: Cin W.
prawn.review:
I've been a longtime customer of Papalote; however, they're really going downhill.  Their food is just ok, but extremely overpriced.  I get it..that they supposedly use fresh ingredients and all that but, come on.  We hadn't been there for a while, but finally decided to order for pick-up a few weeks back.

My husband ordered his usual--a prawn and chicken quesadilla, and I ordered my usual--a veggie burrito.  Our total came out to be around $29! What's even worse is that my husband's quesadilla was so tiny (only two pieces) and barely any prawns in there.  They didn't even put his quesadilla in a box, they just wrapped it in foil, which caused the food to get all messed up and sloppy.  We typically don't mind paying extra for top quality food, but like I said, the quality is not even that great anymore. 

I really like the owners--Miguel and Judy (I think), so I feel bad writing this review.  But I feel really ripped off and I feel like they totally just jacked up their prices while diminishing their quality.  Also, this place is always filled with damn hipsters and techies (who are extremely annoying).

excerpts: The prawn burrito was excellent, I had every intention of eating half and taking home the remainder.
Well let's just say that idea went out the window after the first bite.
Did I forget to mention that I had Wolfed down more than my share of the delicious guacamole.
prawn.author: Manny G.
prawn.review: The prawn burrito was excellent, I had every intention of eating half and taking home the remainder. Well let's just say that idea went out the window after the first bite. Did I forget to mention that I had Wolfed down more than my share of the delicious guacamole. My wife had the Carne asada burrito, it was good nothing to write home about. The dude next to me was eating the mole burrito and that will be my next item I try.  Parking can be a challenge and the seating area is tight during the lunch rush. Be patient it is worth it.

excerpts: Two of us went for lunch, I ordered 2 prawn tacos, and guess how many prawns were inside:
two.  haha!
This place is GROSSLY OVER RATED!!
Maybe the ownership changed?
Dunno
but I won't be back to find out.
prawn.author: Hoo.asked. U.
prawn.review: Really disappointing. Two of us went for lunch, I ordered 2 prawn tacos, and guess how many prawns were inside: two.  haha!  This place is GROSSLY OVER RATED!!  Maybe the ownership changed?  Dunno but I won't be back to find out.

excerpts:
All Mexican taquerias use fresh and healthy ingredients when they make their food

I ordered a Prawn Burritos and added zucchini, eggplant, carrots and mushrooms, it cost over $16.00.
prawn.author: D. B. M.
prawn.review:
USA Today featured Papalote Mexican Grill as one of the 10 great places to bite into a big burrito, SF Weekly readers voted it, Best Burrito in '07, '08, '09, '10, SF Bay Guardian best burrito and best Mexican Restaurant, what are these people talking about, they need to have their taste buds checked.

I was born in Mexico and have had Mexican food all my life and I have to say what a disappointment Papalote Mexican Grill was. I don't know what makes it "Fresh And Healthy, From Scratch!" All Mexican taquerias use fresh and healthy ingredients when they make their food

I ordered a Prawn Burritos and added zucchini, eggplant, carrots and mushrooms, it cost over $16.00. Let tell you I was very it was bland, bland, bland as it had absolutely no flavor except a hint of garlic. My burrito had about five prawns, black beans, semi-raw vegetables, lots of rice and no mushrooms. The burrito was of an average size and if it wasn't for the rice, it would have much smaller. So this was my first and last time I will be purchase food at Papalote Mexican Grill. The Mission has less expensive Mexican Taqueria that offer better food like Pancho Villa.

excerpts: The prawn quesadilla was tasty
prawn.author: Jess C.
prawn.review:
Papalote drew much of its fame from winning the throwdown against Bobby Flay on Food Network. Their salsa was so famous that they decided to bottle and sell it; and I have to admit it was good and very unique because it's heavy on the creamy side, thick, and completely blended through.

The food was good.... depending on what you order. The carne asada quesadilla was OK, the cheese was a little too gritty for my taste. The prawn quesadilla was tasty but it was 25% prawns, 75% tortilla and cheese. 

I would recommend the carne asada burrito and douse that baby with their famous salsa (ask for easy on the beans). The rice-meat-beans proportion is perfect (unlike the heavy on the rice/beans at Cancun or Farrolito), and the serving size is generous. 

Note: Not a fan of the stale chips.

excerpts: so I decided to head here for a naked prawn burrito.
The ingredients were quite yummy, loved the beans but there were only 4 prawns.
Mind u the prawns are not even that big, probably a bit bigger than a quarter.
Besides that it was quite filling.
I agree kinda pricey but everything tastes pretty fresh.
People that work there are quite nice as well.
prawn.author: E S.
prawn.review: Been wanting a burrito bowl so I decided to head here for a naked prawn burrito. The ingredients were quite yummy, loved the beans but there were only 4 prawns.  Mind u the prawns are not even that big, probably a bit bigger than a quarter.  Besides that it was quite filling.  I agree kinda pricey but everything tastes pretty fresh. People that work there are quite nice as well.

excerpts: I ordered the prawn tacos (comes with 2 prawns in each with lettuce/tomatoes/jicama).
Ingredients were made fresh with not a lot of fuss.
prawn.author: Ya Y.
prawn.review: I ordered the prawn tacos (comes with 2 prawns in each with lettuce/tomatoes/jicama). Ingredients were made fresh with not a lot of fuss. We also ordered the chicken super nacho. Yummy!!! If you like fresh ingredients, this is the place for you. Not the best tacos/nachos I've ever had but decent. We were also served chips and their signature Papalote dip which was very good. Consistency of ranch but very flavorful.

excerpts: EXCELLENT prawn burrito.
The only reasons for 4 stars instead of 5 are long waits and tiny, stuffy dining area.
The sidewalk is huge--
it'd be awesome if they added outdoor seating.
prawn.author: Cassandra J.
prawn.review: EXCELLENT prawn burrito. The only reasons for 4 stars instead of 5 are long waits and tiny, stuffy dining area. The sidewalk is huge--it'd be awesome if they added outdoor seating.

excerpts: The grilled prawn and lime tacos on soft corn tortillas, camarones (shrimp tacos cooked in butter and wine), chilaquiles and Papalote's incomparable salsa

(I've gingerly transported jars of Papalote salsa, bubble wrapped for good measure, to the East Coast to distribute amongst lucky friends but nothing beats fresh salsa at the Mission location) are all killer.
Add a strawberry agua fresca and I'm good to go.
prawn.author: Cheryl L.
prawn.review:
I love Papalote and always make sure to bring out-of-towners whenever friends come to visit.

The grilled prawn and lime tacos on soft corn tortillas, camarones (shrimp tacos cooked in butter and wine), chilaquiles and Papalote's incomparable salsa (I've gingerly transported jars of Papalote salsa, bubble wrapped for good measure, to the East Coast to distribute amongst lucky friends but nothing beats fresh salsa at the Mission location) are all killer. Add a strawberry agua fresca and I'm good to go.

excerpts: prawn - not much prawn (maybe 3 in each taco?)
but the flavor on the prawn was all there.
it didn't add much to the taco.
prawn.author: Kapo T.
prawn.review:
not a big burrito fan, coming here, i ordered the tacos. i shared two orders with a friend so we can each try different ones. 

prawn - not much prawn (maybe 3 in each taco?)  but the flavor on the prawn was all there. it didn't add much to the taco. can skip next time. 

fish - lots of fish in each taco and it adds to the taco when you take each bite. you don't have to search for where each piece of fish is cuz it's in your mouth every time you take a bite! will definitely order this again next time i am here! 

salsa - my friend comes here for salsa and make sure she gets extra. i can see why. the salsa is available for purchase by jar also. this salsa has enough kick in spiciness and it's more blended than chunks of tomatoes, etc. Maybe i'll buy a jar next time so i can enjoy it at home! 

Will definitely try other tacos next time around!

excerpts: Burritos are good, but absolutely outrageous price for the "prawn" tacos.
You get two for $9.25 but they won't even make it a block to my apartment.
Tortilla gets completely soggy and falls apart (hint: in L.A., they put two or three tortillas on to-go tacos
so they hold their shape.)
Yeah, I'm a San Francisco native, but I know about good tacos.
The kicker?
FOUR EFFING "PRAWNS".
TOTAL.
Yes, two per taco.
I dug and dug beneath mountains of lettuce.
FOUR PRAWNS.
prawn.author: Anna B.
prawn.review:
Burritos are good, but absolutely outrageous price for the "prawn" tacos. You get two for $9.25 but they won't even make it a block to my apartment. Tortilla gets completely soggy and falls apart (hint: in L.A., they put two or three tortillas on to-go tacos so they hold their shape.) Yeah, I'm a San Francisco native, but I know about good tacos. 
The kicker? FOUR EFFING "PRAWNS". TOTAL. Yes, two per taco. I dug and dug beneath mountains of lettuce. FOUR PRAWNS. Absurd.

I'm so angry I'm not ever going back, and I used to eat there 2-3 times a week.

excerpts: I had prawn burrito and guacamole.
They forgot my guac & wasn't easy to fix with the cashier when I had to come back (after driving away).
A male employee came out and resolved quickly.
The guacamole was warm & missed any flavor, probably in top 5 worst guacamole ever.
The burrito was okay in the flavor area, but really mushy.
The combination didnt offer any texture variety.
Wouldn't eat here again.
prawn.author: Anna H.
prawn.review: Did takeout since there is no parking at all around this one!! I had prawn burrito and guacamole. They forgot my guac & wasn't easy to fix with the cashier when I had to come back (after driving away). A male employee came out and resolved quickly. The guacamole was warm & missed any flavor, probably in top 5 worst guacamole ever. The burrito was okay in the flavor area, but really mushy. The combination didnt offer any texture variety. Wouldn't eat here again.

excerpts: My girl on the other hand who ended up getting the prawn super burrito ($12.95), received only 4 small very over cooked prawns in her burrito, she was pissed.
prawn.author: Pizzle D.
prawn.review:
Well I felt a little duped after eating here. 

I had located this little hole in the wall using yelps reviews and photos of the food. I ran across Dungeness crab enchiladas and was sold. Upon looking over the menu board there was no crab or enchiladas any where in sight. Oh well, must have been a special, no big deal. I had a carne asada super burrito which I thought was quite tasty. My girl on the other hand who ended up getting the prawn super burrito ($12.95), received only 4 small very over cooked prawns in her burrito, she was pissed. It was a lot of rice and beans for $13.
On the other hand I felt as though I received a healthy amount of carne asada and enjoyed my burrito well enough.

excerpts: I got the prawn super burrito (with guacamole, cheese, sour cream) and rice, black beans, and salsa.
Since I let it sit for a minute, the bottom got all soggy
* (tee hee), so I had to fork-n-knife it; it felt so, so wrong.
prawn.author: Adena B.
prawn.review:
The boy and I were craving a burrito, so we stopped at the first place that had parking nearby (can you blame us? Damn you, Mission!)

PAPALOTAY! I just like saying it. It means "kite," right? Awesome.

We sat down in the cramped joint (make friends with your table neighbors!) with our respective Mexican beers and were immediately served up with some chips and creamy salsa. We each got burritos in a whole wheat tortilla and it completely changed the dynamic of what I'm used to, but not in a bad way: it was delicious!

I got the prawn super burrito (with guacamole, cheese, sour cream) and rice, black beans, and salsa. Since I let it sit for a minute, the bottom got all soggy* (tee hee), so I had to fork-n-knife it; it felt so, so wrong. The boy got the standard carne asada burrito, but was able to pick it up and eat it the proper way; he said it was excellent. 

All in all, very pleased with the quality of the food, but not really with the prices; with tip, I think I dropped a little less than $20 for a burrito and a beer. Worth it though, since the service was great, too.


*Most people came in to pick-up since they had called in. With the soggy-bottom debacle, I'm not sure if I'd be comfortable doing that. Besides, the line moved pretty quickly.

excerpts: My prawn burrito had 4 prawns.
Not enormous lobster like jumbo prawns.
Just medium to regular sized prawns.
prawn.author: Brian W.
prawn.review:
This used to be my favorite Mexican place in the city. It is now my least favorite. My prawn burrito had 4 prawns. Not enormous lobster like jumbo prawns. Just medium to regular sized prawns. As if that weren't enough, three of the four shrimp were at the bottom of the burrito, leaving me to navigate through five shrimpless bites of burrito nothingness.

After this experience I feel like this guy was talking about Papalote: https://medium.com/comedy-corner/fd08c0babb57

I want my money back.

excerpts: Papalote is known for their Triple Threat Burrito and have high reviews on the prawn burrito, but I went with the Marinated Tofu.
Typical me for always doing something different from the general population.
If I were to return, I will stick with what people like and try the prawn burrito.
prawn.author: Elaine Y.
prawn.review:
After hearing all the reviews about this place and seeing it on Bobby Flay's show, thought it was time to give this place a try. I might have hyped this place up too much and I was a little bit disappointed. One mistake I made was to order something that the reviews were suggesting. Papalote is known for their Triple Threat Burrito and have high reviews on the prawn burrito, but I went with the Marinated Tofu. Typical me for always doing something different from the general population. The burrito was good, but it wasn't as good as the regular chicken burritos that I have had elsewhere. It feels like it's missing some sauce. It was really nice that Papalote is so generous with their ingredients and packed the burrito with beans, rice, sour cream, gracamole, and meat, but it tasted a bit on the dry side.

Their chips and salsa is good. Their house salsa is definitely their specialty. They sell them in jars at the restaurant. If I were to return, I will stick with what people like and try the prawn burrito.

excerpts: The bf & I ordered: 2 prawn tacos, 2 carne asada tacos (.99 cents extra to make them "super), & two bottled drinks.
prawn.author: Fancypants X.
prawn.review:
When I first heard about Papalote's $19.95 burrito, I was like, "we should be running them outta the Mission instead of blowin' them up with 1000's of reviews." I get it, we're in America & the owners are well within their rights to embrace a little American greed & capitalism, but not at my expense.

So, after a little internal struggle ("Don't patronize them, there's better two blocks away & they don't rape you with their prices! But it could be oh-so-good. Why would Bobby Flay challenge them if it wasn't? Don't do it! DO IT!") I finally went  *hangs head in shame*

The bf & I ordered: 2 prawn tacos, 2 carne asada tacos (.99 cents extra to make them "super), & two bottled drinks. Total: under $21--well that wasn't too painful at all! 

The salsa is definitely unique--it is creamy without chunks of tomato. I tasted a lot of heat but not a lot of real, tomatoey flavor. It's a nice change from regular salsa. When the tacos arrived, we were surprised (not to mention disappointed) at how it is Fresh Mex instead of authentic Mexican. Zero grease, zero salt. It's very similar to La Salsa (maybe the lack of Latino patrons should have tipped us off...) There was nothing wrong with the flavors but it's obvious that this place caters to a specific demographic who's palates are not ready for some dirty, real, greasy Mexican goodness. Papalote is definitely a non-offensive, very polished version of Mexican food & no me gusta.

excerpts: I usually go for the prawn quesadillas
, that is my usual menu go-to item at Papalote.
prawn.author: Alyssa G.
prawn.review:
I like that Papalote is easy to get to from work, for a quick bite at lunchtime. Parking is usually pretty easy, both metered and residential. There is always a lot of people around, and it may take a while until you get your order placed. Always helps to know what you want when they're ready to take your order.

Last time I was there, I switched it up and got a Chile Verde (pork) burrito. It was humongous and very good, topped with guacamole, sour cream and the works.

I usually go for the prawn quesadillas, that is my usual menu go-to item at Papalote. All their items are well under $10, which makes me a fan!

TIP: must try the chips and homemade salsa, it's got a fiery, roasted taste to it. Delicious!

excerpts: We ordered a prawn burrito to share.
Now, I know prawn burritos are always more expensive than say Carne asada but at $11.25 for a prawn super, it should be pretty darn good.
I asked them how many prawns come on a prawn burrito and the said 4.
Now, if these were true jumbo prawns (8-10 count/lbs), that would have made sense.
prawn.author: Aaron B.
prawn.review:
Ok, this is sad to write but here goes. 

Part of me wants to give three stars but this is more of a 2.5. However, when you miss the basics, you get dinged. 

Papalote had great reviews so we went for a burrito. The space is clean and comfortable. I liked the creamy salsa but had issues with our burrito. 

We ordered a prawn burrito to share. Now, I know prawn burritos are always more expensive than say Carne asada but at $11.25 for a prawn super, it should be pretty darn good. 

Papalote got right what many places don't - flavor.  The ingredients and recipes were good. What didn't work for me was composition. They were nice and offered to cut the burrito in half because the cashier realized we were sharing. When the burrito came out it looked great. 

It was the right size, had been toasted after rolled (good call!) but something was missing. Prawns for me, rice for my wife. 

In my half of the burrito, there were no prawns. I took it to the counter (after unrolling on a search for shrimp) and told them there was nothing there. My wife had found three inside her half. I asked them how many prawns come on a prawn burrito and the said 4. Now, if these were true jumbo prawns (8-10 count/lbs), that would have made sense. They seemed like regular size shrimp to me.  Plus they were put in whole instead of being cut in half which would have helped the composition. 

My wife's half had primarily beans and prawns but no rice. 

A burrito is like a sandwich - very simple. But simple foods require precision to be REALLY good. It was sad that they skimped on the prawns and that the ingredients weren't balanced. They had a 4 star burrito in the making. The staff was genuinely apologetic however there was no recovery. I didn't make a big stink about it but I certainly left rather disappointed. I'd try them again but would probably go for tacos where composition isn't an issue. If you want a burrito, don't get prawns.

excerpts: It's clean, at least and perfect if you like spending about $10 on a dry prawn burrito and wait 20 minutes to receive it.
prawn.author: Athena S.
prawn.review:
A man who was trying to woo me said, " No way!  You work in the Mission?  I know the BEST place to get authentic Mexican food."

I was all ears.  "Papalote!" He was so enthusiastic I figured he must've owned the place.

"Really? Seen it, just never tried it.  Is is better than La ____?"

"Oh hell ya! Promise you!"

His confidence was charming.  The place, not so much.  

It's a great spot if you want to pretend to be in the Mission. It's clean, at least and perfect if you like spending about $10 on a dry prawn burrito and wait 20 minutes to receive it. 
Better ones can be found at Whole foods if you're too afraid to go to a real taqueria in the Mission - you know, the ones Mexican people actually eat at.

2 burittos, 2 beers & some guac he insisted on ordering because it was 'awesome' - $43. Really?

excerpts: The only knock against the place are the Prawn tacos.
Unfortunately you get only two prawn per taco, so it's not going to take care of your hunger.
Better off ordering the prawn burrito since the other fillings will ensure you're satisfied.
prawn.author: Pico S.
prawn.review:
Great place for burritos and fish tacos. Of course, the sauce is amazing along with the service.

The only knock against the place are the Prawn tacos. Unfortunately you get only two prawn per taco, so it's not going to take care of your hunger. Better off ordering the prawn burrito since the other fillings will ensure you're satisfied.

excerpts: I always get the prawn burrito with grilled veggies and its amazing!
Writing this review is making me want to drive there right now and get one!   2 hr drive for a burrito!
Haha
prawn.author: Michaela T.
prawn.review: Salsa here is a little creamy, so delicious so different!   The triple threat is huge and soooooooooooo good but a bit expensive,  almost $20 for a burrito!   I always get the prawn burrito with grilled veggies and its amazing!  Writing this review is making me want to drive there right now and get one!   2 hr drive for a burrito!  Haha

excerpts: your fish and prawn tacos, your mole sauce, your burritos...
prawn.author: Peter S.
prawn.review:
sadness...

I used to love you Papalote...you were cute, better than your average taqueria...your fish and prawn tacos, your mole sauce, your burritos...all had a little something extra, an attention to detail, maybe the fresh greens on the taco, the slices of radish, it was worth a couple extra bux.

But just like a good TV show, success has robbed you of everything that made you special.  Now all I see is:
-- OK Food, still good, but seems to have lost that something extra...no longer better than the cheaper taquerias one block away
--Crowded/long lines/noisy, people constantly standing around waiting, staring at you to finish so they can have your seat
--$$$ - No longer worth the extra few bucks

OH, and my tacos fell apart, they now use one corn tortilla instead of two - did that 2 cents per tortilla really save you that much money  Papalote? 
It pains me to see how success has ruined a formerly great little place.  I'll always remember you the way you were....sadness

excerpts: And don't think the regular prawn burrito will give you any more bang for your buck.
For $11 (w/ sour cream & guac), you can expect a grand total of 3 prawns.
Worth it?
prawn.author: Jaymar C.
prawn.review:
I'm gonna go ahead and say I hate this place.  A lot of The City dwellers might cry, but it is what it is.

Now let me start by saying that the food is not bad.  It's actually pretty good.  Solid.  Definitely not life-changing though.  That said, $20 for that triple threat is grand larceny.  It's obnoxious.  If I'm dropping over a dub on a burrito, then it had better be gigantic or mind-blowingly delicious... ideally, both.  The triple threat was neither.  It was merely hefty and good.  Worth $21?  Hell no.  

And don't think the regular prawn burrito will give you any more bang for your buck.  For $11 (w/ sour cream & guac), you can expect a grand total of 3 prawns.  Worth it?  Another emphatic, hell no.   

Papalote's food is not bad.  Really.  But their prices are insulting.  For that kind of money, I would much rather go to Chipotle.  Yup, McDonald's-owned, quasi-Mexican, burrito-bowl-serving Chipotle.  Definitely a better value.

excerpts: I get the "naked burrito", and have had chicken, carne asada, and prawn.
The carne asada was the best, with lots of steak and a generous portion of guacamole (but they charge quite a bit to add it).
Their signature salsa is fantastic, spicy, and unique.
I was disappointed that the prawn only had 4 pieces of shrimp, but it was delicious.
I'm somewhere between 3 and 4 stars on this one, but I'm giving them an extra for good service.
Everyone who works there is really nice!
prawn.author: Rachel A.
prawn.review: I like Papalote a lot because of its convenience, but it is on the expensive side.  I get the "naked burrito", and have had chicken, carne asada, and prawn.  The carne asada was the best, with lots of steak and a generous portion of guacamole (but they charge quite a bit to add it).  Their signature salsa is fantastic, spicy, and unique.  I was disappointed that the prawn only had 4 pieces of shrimp, but it was delicious.  I'm somewhere between 3 and 4 stars on this one, but I'm giving them an extra for good service.  Everyone who works there is really nice!

excerpts: Then we shared both a prawn and a steak quesadilla.
prawn.author: Lesly S.
prawn.review:
My husband moved to SF to pave the way for us to live out our California dreams, and when I finally got to town he went out of his way to take me to Papalote. It was across town from our apartment, but he assured me the Zipcar trip was completely justified. This coming from a man who didn't touch Mexican food with a 10-ft pole before we met. Luckily my years of quesadilla indoctrinations worked, and now I love it here as much as he does.

The salsa rocks. I demolished a bowl without really noticing. Then we shared both a prawn and a steak quesadilla. Again, simple, and delicious.

The bathroom... it looks like it would be disgusting thanks to the dark paint ahd the insane asylum looking scrawls on the walls, but its actually quite clean.

excerpts: I ordered a super prawn burrito and a horchata.
Wait...what?
No horchata?
I had one last time
I was...
ok...nevermind.
A prawn (all right, that's normally pricier) super burrito and an Orangina for $13-something?
prawn.author: Ellis A.
prawn.review:
Ok, I'm gonna preface this review by saying I came here FAMISHED (since it was way past my dinnertime), and diverted since my first choice of taqueria was closed. Needless to say, I was already a little annoyed when I arrived...though it was nice to meet up with some of my friends (I digress).

I walk in and WHOA...ok...the counter is now on the right, vs right in front of you when you walk in. I didn't see a menu on the wall (they actually hung it up when I sat down to eat), so I ordered from a printed post card looking thing that they had a stack of.

I ordered a super prawn burrito and a horchata. Wait...what? No horchata? I had one last time I was...ok...nevermind. Give me an Orangina.

It was about 8:30 at this time, and the dining room was popping. There were open seats strewn about, but nothing really available to have three people (me and my two friends) sitting together. And what's this "Please Wait to be Seated" sign have to do with anything? That's weird. I don't see any staff seating anyone.

So, I saw some built-into-the-wall countertops and we decide to pull some chairs up to it. "I'm sorry, but you can't eat there." Says an employee of the place. So....hrm....maybe there should have been a sign. I'll admit I was thoroughly confused. We eventually waited for some other seats to open up (oddly, like 8 people left at the same time), and sit down. The table was still kinda dirty even though it was wiped down (food debris and what looked like some hair). I'm too hungry to care and brush stuff off with the number tag they give you with the order and I sit down.

A few minutes later, they bring the food out. I eat, chat with my friends, then bail.

Experience: 2 ("Ermm....hurhmm)
I would normally give a 3 to taquerias with their functional decor and spartan surroundings. But, the dirty tabletop, and counters that you can't eat on just didn't mesh well with my already annoyed mood. Yes, I'm sure my mood is influencing my rating here. But then again, even El Farlito with their plastic/cafeteria-style seating has clean table surfaces (every time I've been there). The bathroom, for the most part, is clean; save for all the patron-contributed art from pretty much floor to ceiling.

Value: 2 (A little steep for what you get...)
A prawn (all right, that's normally pricier) super burrito and an Orangina for $13-something? Really?

Food: 3 (It's fine)
The prawns tasted a bit toasty/overcooked. But, I give them bonus points for having black beans. The portion is pretty on par with your standard Mission District burritos (read: big enough that a fork and knife are standard issue...though it's hand-holdable, still).

Overall: 2.33 (Ugh...down to 2)
I don't want to give this place a 2...as I had an okay experience here last time. But, when you go into an establishment, you don't want to feel worse than you did when you walked in. Granted I was already annoyed, but this experience made me more annoyed tonight. Maybe just my luck of the cards and perfect storm alignment of mistakes by the establishment. Yes, in Yelp terms "Meh. I've experienced better."

excerpts: 4 stars for the prawn burrito.
3 stars for the prices.
prices: $11.30 for a prawn burrito with avocado (to go) is expensive.
It should be $9 total.
(of course if you're on route to your 2.5 million noe valley house, not having to walk 2 blocks out of your way is worth $11.30, but for the rest of us please bring the prices down).
None of the ingredients are organic, or pesticide free, thus the cost of that burrito is probably $4.50 thus at least a 5 dollar profit (after labor)!
I also recommend la corneta's super baby prawn burrito, and the seitan burrito at herbivoire, both of which are less expensive, and you will not wait as long.
prawn.author: Nip B.
prawn.review:
4 stars for the prawn burrito. 
3 stars for the prices.
2 stars for the wait. 

suggestion regarding the wait: get a digital sign which shows which orders are ready. clearly the owners are rich by now, so they can do a little research and figure that out. 

prices: $11.30 for a prawn burrito with avocado (to go) is expensive. It should be $9 total. (of course if you're on route to your 2.5 million noe valley house, not having to walk 2 blocks out of your way is worth $11.30, but for the rest of us please bring the prices down). None of the ingredients are organic, or pesticide free, thus the cost of that burrito is probably $4.50 thus at least a 5 dollar profit (after labor)! whoa. 

food: they do make a good burrito, the salsa is key. it's filling but not too filling. the chips are cheap fried chips, could be of better quality. 

I also recommend la corneta's super baby prawn burrito, and the seitan burrito at herbivoire, both of which are less expensive, and you will not wait as long.

excerpts: My fav is the prawn burrito.
prawn.author: Jeffrey H.
prawn.review:
Hands down my favorite burrito joint in the city, and I have eaten my fair share of bean, rice, and meat in a tortilla.

Employing the golden ratio of guacamole to sour cream, Papalote combines fresh ingredients to create a superior taste experience. Unlike other taquerias whose burritos flavors are mushy and muddled, Papalote's burritos are flavorful and delicious - each ingredient stands out on it's own. 

A few tips:

1) My fav is the prawn burrito. Get it super with cheese, guac, and sour cream. 

2) The salsa is totes amazeballs. You can even buy a jar of it to take home. 

3) Call in your order 10 minutes in advance to have your order ready when you get there!

4) Even though it sounds enticing and delicious, forget the Triple Threat burrito on the menu.  It's $20 and has carne asade, prawns, and chicken, but is no larger than a normal burrito and not worth the premium price.  I suppose I'd pay a few bucks extra for the combination of meats, but it doesn't make sense to charge a ridiculous amount of money for a regular-sized burrito.  Maybe I ordered it on an off day, but it was the one and only time I've been disappointed with Papalote.

excerpts: I think it might be less to just buy a prawn burrito, add chicken & carne asada, and make it a super though I'm not sure.
prawn.author: John D.
prawn.review:
It's obvious that the 'comedian' brother came up with the price for the Triple Threat because that was funny as hell!  But hey, I'll go along with the absurd price and fall into the tourist trap.  Turns out it's the customers who are the joke since it's not even that good...

Like many others, I came to this place after watching Throwdown a couple days ago.  For those who want to come here for the Triple Threat burrito, the 1st thing you will notice is the $19.95 price which might be worth it if it used Kobe beef though I just wanted to try it once.  I think it might be less to just buy a prawn burrito, add chicken & carne asada, and make it a super though I'm not sure.

I really do think this Triple Threat burrito is overrated, especially because of its price.  I found myself eating each of the meat separately because together it is over-seasoned with each of the marinade and sauce getting lost within each other.  Individually, the meat tastes great: perfectly grilled and marinated so well.  But together, there is just too much going on.  The secret sauce is good (maybe a rip off of La Vic's orange sauce) though, with some heat and tangy.  So it may be that it's better to just get a burrito with just 1 type of meat and hope it's not bland.  The food here is fresh though.

There are other places in the Mission where you can get just as good of a tasting, fresh burrito that's more authentic for half the price.. so I won't be coming back here.

small dining area, so might not get a seat
service is good, but phone your order in so you don't have to wait a while
parking isn't too hard to find, metered

excerpts: Today, I ordered a super prawn burrito and
after the first 4 large bites, I returned to the store thinking I had recieved someone else's order.
Why?
Because all I got in each bite were BEANS.
prawn.author: Avi S.
prawn.review:
The last three burritos I ordered here were absolutely awful.  Today, I ordered a super prawn burrito and after the first 4 large bites, I returned to the store thinking I had recieved someone else's order.  Why?  Because all I got in each bite were BEANS.  Where were the prawns, the sour cream, the guacamole and cheese that comes with the "super?".
Turns out there were a few over cooked dried prawns in there.  But I never found the sour cream.  And I found a bit of mushy guacamole and cheese clumped at the bottom.  But mostly beans, and blandness.  Don't burritos usually have a tasty salsa as well?

Yuch.  I was truly disappointed, for the third time in a row.  Not sure what people like, maybe it's because it's kinda "granola" and that's what a certain mission crowd likes...

excerpts: I decided to order something different this time, the Prawn Burrito under the specialty burrito section, thinking that would give be more Filipino-like.
Upon first bite into the prawn I was thinking.. this is really special, great taste with great grilled aroma.
However, as I continued I found out the rest of the prawns were overcooked and tasted a bit bitter, probably from over-charring on the outside.
prawn.author: Chad S.
prawn.review:
Came here for a couple of reasons: (1) I was told that this is a place for Filipino-style Mexican food and I was eager to learn about Filipino food, and (2) this place had been featured on the Food Network (Throwdown with Bobby Flay).  I decided to order something different this time, the Prawn Burrito under the specialty burrito section, thinking that would give be more Filipino-like.

The prawns were coated with lime juice and grilled.  Upon first bite into the prawn I was thinking.. this is really special, great taste with great grilled aroma.  However, as I continued I found out the rest of the prawns were overcooked and tasted a bit bitter, probably from over-charring on the outside.  In the end, I didn't get either of the two things that I came here for - not feeling any Filipino side of it and not sure what made this place so special to be featured on the Food Network.

P.S. I did really enjoy the spicy and creamy saucer that came with the free chips.

excerpts: She orded the lime-seasoned prawn burrito, but the seasoning was so bland that she actually thought they'd given her the wrong burrito!
It was like watching someone pick the wrong door on a game show over and over again: bite after bite with not a prawn in sight.
prawn.author: Jay S.
prawn.review:
An experience that has shaken my faith in the taste of my fellow San Franciscans. I just cannot understand the hype around this place. It wasn't bad, but I don't think I'd come back here- it's just not a good value.

I've tried Papalote's food before. I have vague memories of eating there before I lived in SF and I'd had their takeout at a friend's house before. I don't remember being blown away by it, but I don't remember hating it either. Then again, I'm from Socal, so Mexican food is one category in which SF tends to let me down.

Fast forward to last night. We get there and, though the wait was somewhat long, the staff was so friendly and attentive that it wasn't a bother at all. 

I ordered the soyrizo burrito (not particularly adventurous, but it's what I was in the mood for). It was just okay, not any better or worse than what I might make at home using store-bought soyrizo. I wasn't unhappy with my meal, but I wasn't impressed. I'd rate it 3 stars on its own. 

My girlfriend's burrito was a different story. She orded the lime-seasoned prawn burrito, but the seasoning was so bland that she actually thought they'd given her the wrong burrito! I asked the (very polite and attentive) waitress if perhaps they'd prepared her the shrimp burrito with the butter-wine sauce by mistake, but it turns out it was the right burrito, just not a very good one.*

The other problem, besides flavor, was the number of prawns. This was an $11 burrito that had 4 smallish prawns in it. I don't expect it to be loaded up like a shrimp burrito, but I eat a lot of Mexican food and I know what $11 should buy me. I am not a diner with a sense of entitlement, I just don't want to feel ripped off. 4 tiny prawns just isn't gonna cut it in a huge burrito. It was basically a beans, rice and cheese burrito w/ a cameo appearance by some prawns.

The biggest surprise though, was the salsa. Papalote is renowned for their salsa. So I found it surprising that a Mexican place famous for its salsa DOESN'T GIVE YOU ANY SALSA WITH YOUR FOOD.... YOU HAVE TO BUY IT. **

I am, as my obnoxious use of capital letters might indicate, dead serious: Salsa with your chips is free, but you have to pay to have salsa with your food. 

You get a small (maybe 2 oz) cup of salsa with your chips. The place is popular, so you wait with that basket of chips for quite a while before your food comes. When your food arrives, it does not come with salsa. As it turns out, if you want salsa with your food you have two choices:

(1) Eat your chips without salsa, so you can save the salsa for your food. C'mon son. This might not be objectively unreasonable, but it's unreasonable in light of custom: what Mexican restaurant expects you to eat chips without salsa?

(2) Purchase more salsa to go with your food, at the rate of $0.50 per small cup.

Admittedly, $0.50 is not a big deal, but the idea that the only way to enjoy salsa with your food at this Mexican restaurant is to either pay extra or eat your chips without salsa just reeks of, dare I say it, arrogance. It's like they're so gassed up over people telling them how dope their salsa is that they think they're doing us a favor by letting us eat there. 

I get it. You're world-famous for your salsa. You sell the salsa separately in a jar. People would probably consume insane amounts of the salsa if you didn't regulate it somehow.... but is it going to kill you to give me one cup of salsa with my chips and one cup of salsa with my food? I mean, seriously, that just comes off as really, really cheap. I purchase a $30 fast-Mexican meal for two and have to pay extra to get the salsa? How is that cost not built into my $10 burrito?? 

This is the kind of disregard for customer perspective that causes once-great businesses to fail. Not saying I see Papalote failing anytime soon, but it was a *huge* turnoff for me and I probably won't eat there again because of that last straw. Two people can eat at Rubio's (which actually has very good food for fast-Mexican), spend $20 and enjoy several cups of their delicious salsas or free! The mind boggles.

Also, the salsa is tasty, but not something I would have thought to rave about if Papalote wasn't already well-hyped for its salsa. Despite really wanting to love my dining experience at Papalote, I walked away not understanding what the fuss is about. So disappointed.

______________

* I love my girlfriend, but I'm not the type to give a place a shitty review just because she had a bad experience (see my review of Sushi Raw if you have any doubts). That being said, her burrito was so skimpy on prawns that I was disappointed just *watching* her eat it. It was like watching someone pick the wrong door on a game show over and over again: bite after bite with not a prawn in sight.

** I KNOW!!

excerpts: Prawn burrito
w/ black beans was AWESOME.
Definitely order it "super.
prawn.author: Mel A.
prawn.review:
Prawn burrito  w/ black beans was AWESOME. Definitely order it "super."

Order extra salsa for sure...it has a smoked kick to it that makes it's very tasty!

I'm excited to try some of their other burritos & have heard the mole is killer.

excerpts: I decided to go with the prawn burrito
and I'm so glad that I did.
The prawns were so flavorful and delicious..
I was craving some more after I had finished off my burrito.
My only problemo with my meal was that I felt like there could have been more stuffing in the burrito.
I kept taking bite fulls of folded tortilla on one of the sides because there was nothing inside!
prawn.author: Kim-van T.
prawn.review:
Papalote's has been on my list of places to try not just because it was recently on Throwdown with Bobby Flay but because Kat C. has been raving about this place.

Hot damn that salsa is good.  So good I bought a jar to bring home to the bf (big ol' jar for less than  $5!). It's creamy, thick, and not too spicy - what do they put in that stuff!?!

I decided to go with the prawn burrito and I'm so glad that I did.  The prawns were so flavorful and delicious.. I was craving some more after I had finished off my burrito.  My only problemo with my meal was that I felt like there could have been more stuffing in the burrito.  I kept taking bite fulls of folded tortilla on one of the sides because there was nothing inside!  Sad day...

Papalote's is a bit pricey but it was a nice treat.  I'd come back - sparingly though.

excerpts: I ordered a prawn burrito, making it a super for only 99 cents.
I appreciated the tortilla choices (spinach, flour, whole wheat and Roma tomato), opting for the spinach, as well as the bean options (pinto, refried and black).
prawn.author: Bobbin W.
prawn.review:
I sifted through a bunch of hipster reviews during my SF research and noticed consistent high ratings for Papalote, adding it to my list of Mission Musts. After a rousing show at the Make-Out Room, my beau and I decided to grab a bite in the vicinity. And since it was dark, finding the San Buena Taco Truck was out of the question. So we booked it to Papalote and earned a spot as the last lucky party to score a table in the small dining area. A staff member brought us each our own handful of chips in two bowls, along with little containers of orange, creamy, spicy salsa--quite different from the tomato chunks I'm used to. 

I ordered a prawn burrito, making it a super for only 99 cents. I appreciated the tortilla choices (spinach, flour, whole wheat and Roma tomato), opting for the spinach, as well as the bean options (pinto, refried and black). I chose pinto, of course. 

I mean, the burrito was okay but not worth $10. The prawns, generously doled and flavorfully grilled, added a unique texture to the sour cream, guac and cheese. 

The atmosphere set Papalote apart. The artwork, a fuse between Picasso and Rivera, adorned the bright red walls. Flying frogs and dragons kept watch from the ceiling. The arched entryway between the ordering and dining area added architectural pizazz. Plus, the bathroom, covered in blue paint and graffiti, reminded me of a catwalk per its long, narrow shape and mirror in front of the commode above the sink. 

Because of the shrimp and tilapia filling options and unique decor, Papalote rises just a step above chains like Willy's.

excerpts: I was expecting a prawn in every bite but that big burrito was filled with other stuff.
The insides were not evenly separated either because I ended up eating a ton of rice in the beginning and then all the wet ingredients at the tailend.
I was expecting the grilled prawn burrito to be like the shrimp burrito at Chronic Tacos, which is BOMB.
Alas, that burrito cannot be replicated.
prawn.author: Tori Q.
prawn.review: This place is busy but there's a high turnover rate.  When we ordered the food, we didn't have any seats but by the time we got it, we were seated promptly.  My friend and I both got the burritos, which are huge.  I got the grilled prawns with a spinach tortilla.  It  was good when I ate it but now that I'm thinking back on it, there was way too much rice and not enough prawns.  I was expecting a prawn in every bite but that big burrito was filled with other stuff. The insides were not evenly separated either because I ended up eating a ton of rice in the beginning and then all the wet ingredients at the tailend.  I was expecting the grilled prawn burrito to be like the shrimp burrito at Chronic Tacos, which is BOMB.  Alas, that burrito cannot be replicated.

excerpts: Prawn burritos & tacos are good too, but my heart belongs to the soyrizo burrito - seriously one of the best vegetarian items in San Francisco.
prawn.author: Kimberly C.
prawn.review:
Dear Soyrizo burrito w/ refried black beans, 
I love you. I miss you. Thank goodness you haven't changed.  You are my favorite burrito in town. 

Satisfied my craving for this ol' fave when visiting last week.  It lived up to memory, as the did the famous secret-recipe orange-colored salsa.  Nom nom nom.  Yes they charge for extra servings of it, but I think it's worth it.  Prawn burritos & tacos are good too, but my heart belongs to the soyrizo burrito - seriously one of the best vegetarian items in San Francisco.

Chips are just ok & the 3 small chunks of jicama on the plate are just silly.

Papalote is quick, not too pricey & very tasty.  A no-fuss modern (not traditional) taqueria.

p.s. the reverse engineered Ersatz Papalote Salsa recipe on http://www.chow.com/recipes/10646 is yummy, but still fails at recreating the original.  I make it & enjoy it, but just don't compare it to the housemade anymore

excerpts: I ordered the Prawn, chicken adobo, and carne asada burritos for my family.
Me and my family members all agreed they were dry - rice and meat..
The burritos were ok, but I've definitely had better, like Castillo's (civil center).
Disappointed and not worth the $8 - $10 for each burrito.
You can definitely do better elsewhere.
prawn.author: Les Y.
prawn.review:
I had to check out Papalote because I saw them on Bobby Flay's throwdown. I ordered the Prawn, chicken adobo, and carne asada burritos for my family. Me and my family members all agreed they were dry - rice and meat.. The burritos were ok, but I've definitely had better, like Castillo's (civil center). Disappointed and not worth the $8 - $10 for each burrito. You can definitely do better elsewhere. 
However, I will say the salsa was very  good.

Sorry Papalote. Overpriced and over-rated.

excerpts: From the prawn tacos to the burritos, I've eaten enough now to say ENOUGH!
Since my last visit, they have renovated the area at the cash register.
As if it could not have gotten more awkwardly placed, the line now is forced out the door at a sharp angle.
Papalote's blinding non-CFL lighting (which creates an unnecessary heatwave in the dead of winter) and glossy red walls create an anxiety in me that only rivals that of an interrogation.
Because it is in close proximity to my friend's apartment, I reluctantly agreed to meet her there.
(Any excuse to see her.)
Miraculously, she was able to get 3 seats for all of us.
Last night, I had the prawn burrito.
I was not given chips or salsa or a napkin or cutlery or my drink.
I asked for all of these things, seeing that everyone else had them, and was told that "extra" chips & salsa were 55 cents.
Seriously?
I can get all the chips I want elsewhere and for free.
Once I explained to the guy that I never got my first round, he gave me some salsa.
I walked out of there having paid $14 for a burrito and a horchata.
I could have gone to El Farolito and bought dinner for both of us.
prawn.author: Shelley T.
prawn.review:
I have given Papalote my fair share of food trials. From the prawn tacos to the burritos, I've eaten enough now to say ENOUGH! Since my last visit, they have renovated the area at the cash register. As if it could not have gotten more awkwardly placed, the line now is forced out the door at a sharp angle. Papalote's blinding non-CFL lighting (which creates an unnecessary heatwave in the dead of winter) and glossy red walls create an anxiety in me that only rivals that of an interrogation. Because it is in close proximity to my friend's apartment, I reluctantly agreed to meet her there. (Any excuse to see her.) Miraculously, she was able to get 3 seats for all of us. Seating is at a premium.

Last night, I had the prawn burrito. I was not given chips or salsa or a napkin or cutlery or my drink. I asked for all of these things, seeing that everyone else had them, and was told that "extra" chips & salsa were 55 cents. Seriously? I can get all the chips I want elsewhere and for free. Once I explained to the guy that I never got my first round, he gave me some salsa. I walked out of there having paid $14 for a burrito and a horchata. I could have gone to El Farolito and bought dinner for both of us. My burrito was dry, pretty bland, and I only found the cheese  of the way through my meal (same goes for the guacamole). I slathered every bit of my tiny salsa cup on my burrito for flavor. The prawns were large... all (4?) of them. I spent the entire night in agony. I remebered now why I never go there: I get incredible stomach cramps from their food. I can't explain it - no one else seems to have this - but the amount of acid created is so painful that the last time I ate there, I needed to swallow Pepto with lidocaine just to get to sleep. 

I will now leave Papalote to the hipsters who frequent it. A guy who sat next to us was visiting from NY. I mentioned to him that this was not my favorite place and suggested that if he was here for any length of time, he should try the many other burrito places that the Mission has to offer. I suggested El Farolito and the couple next to us agreed and chimed in. The couple on the other side of us agreed as well. One thing could be said: Papalote brings people together.

excerpts: After ordering one "triple threat burrito" and one prawn burrito the kind lady sat us down at a table and gave us some chips with this very very good salsa.
prawn.author: DANNY B.
prawn.review:
This place was off the hook.. I was sitting at home not knowing about this place until i seen the place on Throw Down With Bobby Flay. After kicking Bobby Flay's butt my girlfriend and I decided to hit this place up for some Burritos. When we got there we noticed the place was not that big inside but it wasn't a problem because i've eaten in smaller places. After ordering one "triple threat burrito" and one prawn burrito the kind lady sat us down at a table and gave us some chips with this very very good salsa.

While waiting for our food i looked over to the table next to us and noticed the guy sitting at the next table was one of the owners that was on Throw Down With Bobby Flay he was conversating with one of the customers and it made me feel good that he took time to just sit down with one of his cusomers to shoot the breeze...

Our food came and we start eating and i must say that the food was very good. I am so proud to be from San Francisco where the mexican food is great and this place takes the cake when it comes to taste.

excerpts: Prawn tacos were amazing.
This is the kind of food that tastes good and makes you feel good too.
No overdoing with the lard.
prawn.author: Dina B.
prawn.review:
Prawn tacos were amazing.  This is the kind of food that tastes good and makes you feel good too.  No overdoing with the lard.  People were friendly, and there was a good vibe on a rainy Saturday afternoon.

Can't wait to go back!

excerpts: I miss you grilled Prawn Burrito!
prawn.author: Ashley J.
prawn.review:
I miss you grilled Prawn Burrito!

And roasted Salsa... Come to LA, and I will give you a dollar!!!

Refried Black Beans, lets make out.

excerpts: The fish tacos are fantastic, and I love the prawn quesadilla, rice and bean taco, fish quesadille (seriously the only time fish and cheese can be used together) and nachos.
prawn.author: Darcy V.
prawn.review:
I go here at least 3 times a week and as Nish pointed out, probably much more than that. Papalote means kite, and the restaurant (you can sit down) is cheerfully painted and hung with beautiful elaborate handmade kits that look like frogs, bugs, etc... and a world class collection of Latin and other music is playing at all times.
