It was filling, yet not too heavy, and I walked out feeling muy feliz. 

Also, their salsa is pretty tasty with a little bite to it. I bought a jar of fresh made salsa and 2 extra burritos (for the husband and parentals) to bring home. The guy at the counter was really nice. He recommended the fresh salsa vs. the jars on the counter. He also hooked it up with a frequent customer card and marked off 3 burritos because he knew my sis and I had also just shared one in the dining area.

excerpts: Make it a super with sour cream, guac, and cheese for only $1.
cheese.author: Jessica L.
cheese.review:
This restaurant has great vegetarian and vegan options.  The beans and rice are made vegan and they have 2 vegetable options and 3 tofu options.  The burritos are large and they do cross the $10 threshold but it is a lot of food.  

My boyfriend and I have a tradition of splitting a burrito once per week and earning a punch on our loyalty card for a free burrito.  Our favorites are grilled veggies (eggplant and zucchini) with whole black beans and marinated tofu (which has a perfectly firm texture) and whole pintos.  Make it a super with sour cream, guac, and cheese for only $1.  

The salsa is BOMB so we always get an extra side and sometimes a jar to take home!

excerpts: After a struggle to tear the paper bag in a way that would make it a suitable plate for the chips, I was only disappointed to find their spicy rendition of nacho cheese dip to be...
well, mediocre.
cheese.author: Mayank G.
cheese.review:
I found this place while just walking by it, something that's a little bit of a rarity for me to go in without checking yelp. The first thing I noticed was that the door only opens halfway since the sidewalk is on a slant, and for whatever reason that made me really excited to eat there.

LIke any good place, this place was full and had free water. Thank god for free water! It was nice and cold too. They take orders ridiculously fast and the cashier was very nice, so there wasn't much waiting in line time to decide what to get.

Thankfully this place was pretty standard Mexican so it wasn't too hard to go for the steak burrito to go. I don't live too far from here so I figured I'd rather eat it at home. The price point was pretty standard, although a lot of places like Taqueria Cancún are cheaper and (spoiler) better.

When I opened the bag and took out the well sized burrito I was pretty happy, but still nothing out of the ordinary so far. Underneath the burrito I realized that the nacho chips (which are complementary like many burrito places in SF) were just lying out at the bottom of the paper bag, which was kind of disappointing. After a struggle to tear the paper bag in a way that would make it a suitable plate for the chips, I was only disappointed to find their spicy rendition of nacho cheese dip to be... well, mediocre. But complaining about a complementary side, maybe I'm just spoilt.

The burrito, this is where my still to be four star rating for the place dropped to three. It wasn't bad by any regard, but since burritos are quite the large food to tackle, I like them to be good to the very last bite. Unfortunately the first of this one told me this was going to be a challenge, albeit not a hardest one. It was rolled somewhat loosely, I didn't how ridiculously thin the tortilla was, and the ingredients weren't causing the orgasm in my mouth that other burritos have caused me to expect. I actually even payed the extra dollar or two it takes to get a super burrito with the guac, something I usually love, but something was just missing.

Being in the mission, unless you're ridiculously hungry and right outside this place, I'd reccomend going to one of the many other burritos around.

excerpts: This dish comes with a lot of cheese melted on top of well marinated, spicy and juicy chorizo.
cheese.author: Julie J.
cheese.review:
Busy on a Wednesday, so I assume it is always busy! Beer only. 

We ordered the Chorizo con Queso to start! AMAZING...a must try! This dish comes with a lot of cheese melted on top of well marinated, spicy and juicy chorizo.  It was exceptional. 

The chips come salty, warm and crispy. It doesn't get better than that! 

I also ordered two fish tacos. They were massive! The flavor was subtle but fresh. 

Wished  I lived closer becuase I would come here more often!

excerpts: My friend and I waited patiently and ordered a Chile Verde Super Burrito (chicken simmered in chile verde with rice, black beans, guacamole, cheese and sour cream).
cheese.author: Lauren B.
cheese.review:
You can Papalome any day!

Ahem...moving on.  This place came highly recommended by many people.  So I went with high expectations.  The place already had a pretty good line at 6pm on a Thursday.  My friend and I waited patiently and ordered a Chile Verde Super Burrito (chicken simmered in chile verde with rice, black beans, guacamole, cheese and sour cream).

The burrito itself was fantastic, the guac tasted like it was whipped or something and the overall flavors of the burrito itself were delicious and filling, while using a minimal amount of oil so I didn't feel gross afterwards.

However - I did take away one star since my friend and I waited for 40 minutes and after we kept seeing others get their food, I went in to inquire about the burrito status since my hanger   pains were setting in. The guy at the counter laughed and was like "It looks like they lost your slip, no worries - ok?"

While it was not an issue per say, I was pissed because I was hungry and after all was said it done it took us 50 minutes to order and get our food. Not to mention the guy just laughed about it - not cool. Next time I will be calling ahead - since their burritos are too delicious to ignore.

excerpts: I got the prawn super burrito (with guacamole, cheese, sour cream) and rice, black beans, and salsa.
Since I let it sit for a minute, the bottom got all soggy
* (tee hee), so I had to fork-n-knife it; it felt so, so wrong.
cheese.author: Adena B.
cheese.review:
The boy and I were craving a burrito, so we stopped at the first place that had parking nearby (can you blame us? Damn you, Mission!)

PAPALOTAY! I just like saying it. It means "kite," right? Awesome.

We sat down in the cramped joint (make friends with your table neighbors!) with our respective Mexican beers and were immediately served up with some chips and creamy salsa. We each got burritos in a whole wheat tortilla and it completely changed the dynamic of what I'm used to, but not in a bad way: it was delicious!

I got the prawn super burrito (with guacamole, cheese, sour cream) and rice, black beans, and salsa. Since I let it sit for a minute, the bottom got all soggy* (tee hee), so I had to fork-n-knife it; it felt so, so wrong. The boy got the standard carne asada burrito, but was able to pick it up and eat it the proper way; he said it was excellent. 

All in all, very pleased with the quality of the food, but not really with the prices; with tip, I think I dropped a little less than $20 for a burrito and a beer. Worth it though, since the service was great, too.


*Most people came in to pick-up since they had called in. With the soggy-bottom debacle, I'm not sure if I'd be comfortable doing that. Besides, the line moved pretty quickly.

excerpts: (guac, sour cream, and cheese) and i usually get black beans and throw it into a spinach tortilla.
nomtastic.
cheese.author: Priya G.
cheese.review:
Can I say BEST BURRITO in san francisco? this place is so delicious i don't even know what to say about it. 

my go-to burrito here is the grilled veggie one - i just love the fresh vegetables that they use and it's good to always make it SUPER (guac, sour cream, and cheese) and i usually get black beans and throw it into a spinach tortilla. nomtastic. the other burritos that are good are soy riso and chicken. so so so safe and such a solid meal for about $8. if you're not a big eater, you can always save half of it for later, which makes an amazing meal or even better - amazing drunk food! (haha)

their special sauce is tasty and if you want more, i believe its $0.50 for each extra cup of it. i would get more - i usually have a cup for just the chips, and another cup just for my burrito.

thank you sf for the best burrito in the world!!!!!! love you.

excerpts: The Chorizo Nacho Plate - this plate had to say is kinda what saved face for the restuarant for me but there was some dislikes, shady on the guac, sourcream, and even cheese camon now folks you get lets
just say it is about maybe 3tsp of each sourcream & guac if you ask for more it is $1 more,
cheese.author: Clarence A.
cheese.review:
I've read the reviews, I've tried there food, honestly I don't even know how this spot got such a high star rating, I give this place a bare 3 stars only reason I didn't give it 2 stars was there sauce they offered, that orange spicy sauce you sprinkle or dip on everything.

Ok here is what we tried:
Ultimate Burrito also know as the Triple Threat i was told- grade D+ there is no taste, they got 3 types of meats carne asada which was tender and juicy, shredded chicken decent size cut not dry but no flavor, the shrimp I think there were like 4 or 5 in it but they pile them all on one side so when you whatever side you start on if you get the shrimp enjoy it you will probably get maybe 4-5 bites in then no more shrimp haha.

we also tried there shrimp quesidilla- super oily, dipping it in the orange sauce gives it some flavor eating it alone you will need salt

The Chorizo Nacho Plate - this plate had to say is kinda what saved face for the restuarant for me but there was some dislikes, shady on the guac, sourcream, and even cheese camon now folks you get lets just say it is about maybe 3tsp of each sourcream & guac if you ask for more it is $1 more, condiments $1 more horrible but taste wise of the nachos with the chorizo and beans all good.

next time your out there just get the chorizo nachos don't spend $20+ for a burrito, there are plenty other mexican restuarants in the bay area you can go to and get 2 of the meats added for about $5-$8 same price but not 3meats.

Only reason I visited this place was due to Bobby Flay and his throwdown sad to say folks been to Bobby Flay's resturant in Vegas food there is blah literally bland and expensive, there are several other spots you can get a decent burrito in the city, this unfortunately is not one of them, if you do go stick with the chorizo nachos and try to get some of that togo orange sauce

ultimate burrito/ triple threat - FAIL ** at best only 2 stars
quesidilla ** super oily no taste drench it in the orange sauce then it makes it *** 1/2
chorizo nachos **** only thing i liked that i tried but it does have its flaws
service *** they are kinda fast
price $ moderate all around the board all $8 except for the triple threat/ultimate burrito $20+
ambiance *** small but clean, tiles on everything

excerpts: that's a lot of cheese and fresh tortillas.
There is not much hope for you at that point.
The food is good.
The food is very, very good.
You, oh reader, must know this because you have already come to this page and you have come this far.
cheese.author: Annie M.
cheese.review:
You try to make good decisions in life, you try to be a good person. But then you are caught in a moment of weakness, after having flown across the country, jetlagged and slightly hungover. You arrive at Papalote with the intention of eating "something light" and just to "try it and see what the fuss is about" and then head to a fancy, heavy dinner. You arrive soon after it opens, around 11:30am, full of optimism and good intentions.

Then your dining partner orders a super burrito and all hell breaks loose. Soon you are ordering the chorizo con queso and a breakfast special and extra beans and you get the complimentary chips (2 bowls of them!) with that special salsa. You inhale the chips and then the chorizo con queso comes and my god that's a lot of cheese and fresh tortillas. There is not much hope for you at that point. The food is good. The food is very, very good. You, oh reader, must know this because you have already come to this page and you have come this far. Just travel a bit further and arrive at Papalote and make your own bad (but so good) consumption choices.

Long story short, we canceled our dinner plans and, after several hours of digesting, am still wondering how Papalote got the best of me. 

I can't wait to go back.

excerpts: It was a Chicken Asada Burrito with Cheese and Guacamole, practically a super no less.
cheese.author: Rebekah T.
cheese.review:
I'm not going to say it was the best burrito I've had, but I ate the whole damn thing! 

That's an not only a sign of a great burrito, it's also accomplishment. I never eat a whole burrito, not even on my hungriest day. It was a Chicken Asada Burrito with Cheese and Guacamole, practically a super no less. 

So I was told to get an "extra"salsa, which they will change extra for. I wish I would have known that it was going to be that great - I would have doubled up that order.

The wait was not long at all. I'm not bothered to wait for a few minutes to get hot, freshly prepared food - after all, I'd like to think of this as a healthier alternative to fast food joints.

excerpts: I ordered the Super (which is sour cream, cheese, guacamole for 99 cents extra)
The chicken wasn't too dry (which is good for me) and the extras were somewhat adequate, but for my personal taste I would've wanted more guacamole and cheese
:p
The tortilla itself was slightly crispy, not too soft at all which is what I'm used to.
cheese.author: Geraldine T.
cheese.review:
My bf was craving burritos ever since he moved to the east coast, so when we were visiting SF this past month, he wanted to check this place out. I ordered the Super (which is sour cream, cheese, guacamole for 99 cents extra) Pollo Burrito (grilled to order chicken breast) for about $8.50 plus tax. It was a hefty size. Not huge not small (maybe 6 or 7 in long, 4 in thick). The chicken wasn't too dry (which is good for me) and the extras were somewhat adequate, but for my personal taste I would've wanted more guacamole and cheese :p The tortilla itself was slightly crispy, not too soft at all which is what I'm used to. And the burrito was wrapped nicely, but if you aren't in the mood to pig out in public, they provide you with knife and fork to eat it more in a more domesticated fashion :p 

The ambiance: almost cramped. The ordering space is quite small. You walk in, and the registers are right there. There's a sign saying wait to be seated, but I don't think that should be there because you actually look for seating and seat yourself. It's cafeteria style seating. We went around 2-3pm ish and it was busy. We were lucky to find three spots open. 

When you sit, someone serves you and each of your party with yummy homemade? tortillas and spicy salsa. And if you don't feel like spending extra money on a soda, they offer "get it yourself" water and small washable cups in the corner. I can vouch that they're clean. And if you want your burrito to go, there's foil wrap next to the water. The service was nice. Friendly.

If I wasn't already full I would've devoured my burrito T_T

excerpts: I recommend paying the extra dollar for cheese, guac, and sour cream.
Fast service, cool vibe and clean.
Thanks, I'll be coming again.
cheese.author: Tim L.
cheese.review: Meals comes with free chips and a unique salsa. Sat by the window on  a hot day, let the cold breeze in, and sucked down a cold corona with my steak tacos. One meal is two tacos and they are bulky. I recommend paying the extra dollar for cheese, guac, and sour cream. Fast service, cool vibe and clean. Thanks, I'll be coming again.

excerpts: Cheese =
MELTED, I approve.
+ Black Beans =
Soft and flavorful, good job there!
cheese.author: Vivian C.
cheese.review:
My first excursion to Papalote today was pretty good.

This is actually 3.5 stars, rounded down because, well, 4 stars means it's got to be really solid, and Papalote's kind of there, but just not quite. 

Some observations, aite here we goes:

1. They take card.  Woot! For a moment, after I stepped in, I panicked because I thought I wouldn't be able to get a burrito since I hardly ever carry around cash.  But phew!  They do!  And then I said to myself, "Oh silly, of COURSE they take card!  Gringo burrito place, duh!"  

2. I got a chicken mole super burrito for $7.93.  The mole was pretty good, as was all the other fillings:
+ Cheese = MELTED, I approve.
+ Black Beans = Soft and flavorful, good job there!
+ Chicken = Shredded and tender perfect chompos for me to eats!  
+ Guac = Mush! Texture, flavor, aesthetically pleasing.  Who doesn't like avocados?
+ Rice = Soft, just right. 

3.  Good location, close to the 24th/Mission BART.  Even though I work in the FiDi, I can easily BART here and back during a lunch break and still have time to spare.  

4.  Hipster paradise indeed.  There were two very nice girls in front of me, with cute bags and flowy skirts and interesting hair.  Such a nice, appropriate place for the hipsters, hippies, and happy white people.  

5.  So, I tried their chips and salsa finally.  It's on that 7x7 "100 Things to Eat in SF" list.  There must be something wrong with my taste buds.  The chips were not that great, nothing special.  You want awesome chips?  Tropisueno's got awesome chips!  The salsa, however, was bangin'.  Unfortunately, I can't take the heat, and one tiny taste set my entire mouth on fire.  It was good, yes, but painful.  

So, why the 3.5 stars?  This review seems to suggest a solid 4, maybe more, right?  Well, I mean, I definitely LIKED my burrito, but it was just...not totally 100% there. . .  

You know what I mean?  Imagine meeting a person, or attending a class, and even though he/she/it is perfectly fine and nice and all, you're just not blown away.  

And you could go either way, go with it, or not.  That's kind of how I felt about Papalote after my meal.  Certainly a decent meal, but I'm not about to jump around recommending it to everyone I know.  

No, no, that shameless plugging is still reserved for my all-time favorite, El Farolito. 

But Papalote?  Eh, she's alright.

excerpts: Chicken adobo with garlic fried rice, avocado, cheese and sour cream.
Yes, please.
cheese.author: Jay F.
cheese.review: The Mexipino burrito is pretty damn good. Chicken adobo with garlic fried rice, avocado, cheese and sour cream. Yes, please.

excerpts: The additional($) ingredients are things like cheese and sour cream which come standard at most taquerias so the burritos that would be around $6 at those other places are $10 here.
I added cheese, sour cream and guacamole to my burrito and there was plenty of all three in it.
The burrito itself was flavorful and filling
cheese.author: David O.
cheese.review:
This place is a little confusing, but good. I didn't understand the menu right away as I was standing in line to order so I got nervous that I would be holding up the line while deciding. No pressure or anything. There's just always a line. The menu on the wall has some options on the left side such as "Veggie," "Grilled Veggie," and "Soyrizo". The next few columns to the right then have prices for exactly what dish you would like your first choice to be and then you move on to picking additional ingredients. The additional($) ingredients are things like cheese and sour cream which come standard at most taquerias so the burritos that would be around $6 at those other places are $10 here.

I got the soyrizo burrito partly because I heard bad things about the "Veggie" burrito here (Potato, carrot, mushroom) and partly because I wanted more flavor than a bland veggie burrito I've had at way too many other places. I added cheese, sour cream and guacamole to my burrito and there was plenty of all three in it. The burrito itself was flavorful and filling so I definitely wasn't disappointed with my choice.

So..the sauce. The sauce is slightly spicy, smokey, and delicious. Just had to throw in my opinion about the sauce everyone mentions, I guess. I might even buy the jars they sell and use it when I get burritos at other places :p

Overall I like this place. It's impossible to park around Valencia/Mission most of the time but if you can make it to this location it's worth it

excerpts: my bf wanted to eat there, got home (dumb me) and for my shrimp super burrito there was no shrimp, no cheese, no guacamole, and no sour cream.
cheese.author: Ali G.
cheese.review:
Been here a couple of times and
Problems:
1. First visit screwed up my order
2. Next visit screwed up my order
3. Tonight I had to get takeout bc my bf wanted to eat there, got home (dumb me) and for my shrimp super burrito there was no shrimp, no cheese, no guacamole, and no sour cream. 13 bucks for rice and beans?! FAIL

Done

excerpts: I regretted not paying the extra 99 cents to make it a "super" with guac, sour cream, and cheese.
I asked at the counter if I could have the super accoutrements on the side.
Initially they balked and wanted me to pay the $2.99 for a whole side of guacamole, but I talked them into giving me just a small side of guac for the 99 cents.
cheese.author: Kathleen M.
cheese.review:
Someone brought Papalote's salsa into my husband's work, and it was so good my husband wanted to seek out the mythical land of milk and honey, or rather, *salsa*, from which it came.

We arrived at Papalote at 2:30 on a Saturday afternoon and were lucky enough to only have to wait 3 minutes for a table. There was a line afterwards. The place is on the small side, and it's unclear if you're supposed to claim your own table or follow the "please wait to be seated" sign. There are pretty dragonfly artworks on the ceiling.

We started with the $1.50 chips and salsa. Unlike other places these aren't bottomless. The amount we were given was just under what we needed, especially given how great the salsa was. (The chips are pretty standard issue.) 

The salsa had a nice roasted flavor and was unlike any other salsa I've ever had. It was a light orange color and looked slightly creamy, though I can't imagine them adding cream to it. (Do they?) It was so good we went back a few hours later for some salsa to take home. For $6.50 you can get a full jar. Even though it's in a jar it's fresh salsa and it'll only last a few days.

We each got a pair of tacos for $4.95. One set had pollo (grilled chicken breast), the other carne asada (grilled steak). For some reason they don't let you mix and match your meats. The carne asada was a little chewy but had good flavor - did I detect lime and garlic? The chicken on the other hand looked like it was good quality, but it was bland. I regretted not paying the extra 99 cents to make it a "super" with guac, sour cream, and cheese. I asked at the counter if I could have the super accoutrements on the side. Initially they balked and wanted me to pay the $2.99 for a whole side of guacamole, but I talked them into giving me just a small side of guac for the 99 cents. Guac makes everything better.

Epilogue: The salsa was just as good at home. Still eating it...

excerpts: Stuffed to the gills with guac, cheese, rice, and beans.
cheese.author: Anna K.
cheese.review:
AH. SO GOOD!

I don't live in SF anymore, but when I come to visit, I love coming here. I got the fish burrito most recently, and it was amazing. Stuffed to the gills with guac, cheese, rice, and beans. Not only are their burritos enormous and filling, but they each come with an order of chips and salsa. And this salsa is some of the best salsa I've ever had: almost creamy in its texture, with a nice kick. 

And since Papalote's is located walking distance from Dolores Park, you  can grab your burrito, and then stroll over to Dolores Park and lounge in the (hopefully) sunny weather, watching the kids tumble on the newly-built jungle gym fantasy world, amidst the sunbathers and hipster locals. And then when you're done, (if you managed to finish this feast!) you can end your meal with a fresh ice cream cone from BiRite Creamery nearby. (I didn't finish my burrito, but it made a nice dinner for me later that day).

excerpts: It adds cheese, sour cream and guac.
I would get slapped if my mother heard me say "guac
" she'd thing "guacala" and that don't sound too appetizing.
I was eager and saw they bottled and sold their own tomato salse, hmmm must be guud.
cheese.author: Julie N.
cheese.review:
I was so excited for a burrito. Oh si, que rico me voy a tragar un burrito. The menu is pretty plain, choice of meat and 99 cents extra for "super" which seems worth it.  It adds cheese, sour cream and guac. I would get slapped if my mother heard me say "guac" she'd thing "guacala" and that don't sound too appetizing. I was eager and saw they bottled and sold their own tomato salse, hmmm must be guud. Chips and salsa was good, crunchy chips and mildly spiced sauce. Then the burrito came.. dun dun dun. 

Ay caramba, guacala!

The rice was dry as hell, ni de fiesta. "Arroz de fiesta" is spanish for party rice. Where people make big batches of tasteless, dry packed rice to serve at weddings and quincianeras. This wasn't even at their level. My carne asada was dry but my tortilla was hella on hit. I ran out of hot sauce, I requested more they charged me $1.10 for two small ass portions. WTF?! lol oh ya and the decor is awesome, the atmosphere feels mexican. There is mexican music blaring and dragon kites to match their red walls. I bet this place was one a chinese food take out and all they did was keep the loud red feng shui walls and flying dragon kites and call it tex mex. My horchata was ok a little sweet. They charged me for fucking salsa it's a spiced up taco bell trying to be a La Vics and a La Vics, it is not. Eh... In ADDITION the $22.50 was not worth the two burritos and one drink we purchased.

excerpts: The $6.50 Super silver-bullet had choice of beans, sour-cream, cheese, salsa and guacamole.
Most of the burritos are wrapped in aluminum foil, but since we ate in, the burrito was loose and placed on a plate.
cheese.author: Matt G.
cheese.review:
Being single and poor, niece snuck up at Matt's worksite to gain access to his uncle's wallet and have a decent meal. Matt needs a niece-repellant spray or something.

We had a craving for a burrito, and many of the taquerias in the Mission district is crowded, in which it's no-brainer to figure out during noon. 

We landed at yuppie-like Papalote, and thank goodness, there wasn't much of a line. As we're waiting in line, Matt went to the beverage, which is located on the right side, and grabbed 2 glass bottles of Coke, this jerk right behind me and say,

"Hey buddy, you lost your space in the line. Go back to the very end." 

After the unnecessary remark, Matt retaliated and returned back with a dirty look at him. You can tell easily that the Yuppie neighborhood didn't favor us. 

Matt ordered the Chili Verde (pork w/ green Serrano Sauce) Super Burrito. The $6.50 Super silver-bullet had choice of beans, sour-cream, cheese, salsa and guacamole. Most of the burritos are wrapped in aluminum foil, but since we ate in, the burrito was loose and placed on a plate. So Matt had to eat the wrapped boy with a fork and knife, like a sophisticated yuppie. 

Niece had a pair of delicate Pescado (fish) taco. The $5.95 meal comes delicate piece of buttered fish and salsa blanketed with a corn tortilla. She was so hungry, that she devoured the pair in record time and beating his uncle.

Our meal comes with complimentary Tortilla chip, which tasted exactly like Doritos.  

We were seated at bar-stool near the public lavatory on the left of the restaurant. As we're resting after a hearty meal, a lady finished her #2 and left her massive stench of odor over the entire restaurant and ruining ours and most of the patron's appetite.  

We had a good meal, depsite overcoming what happened in the beginning and the end.

excerpts: Took my nephews yesterday and was pleased we could dabble in the menu (bean and cheese burritos for the adventurous nephews, chicken al achiote with jicama salad for me).
And yes, the salsa is amazing!
Just spicy enough and clearly NOT from a jar.
So yes, will be going back to Papalote now that it's on my radar...
also while the place looks packed upon approach, there is someone helping seat people so even with our group of 5, it didn't take more than 5 minutes to get a table.
A good thing to remember...
cheese.author: Erin W.
cheese.review: Very fresh + fast Mexican food. Usually that's an oxymoron, not when it comes to Papalote. Took my nephews yesterday and was pleased we could dabble in the menu (bean and cheese burritos for the adventurous nephews, chicken al achiote with jicama salad for me). And yes, the salsa is amazing! Just spicy enough and clearly NOT from a jar. So yes, will be going back to Papalote now that it's on my radar...also while the place looks packed upon approach, there is someone helping seat people so even with our group of 5, it didn't take more than 5 minutes to get a table. A good thing to remember...

excerpts: and I saw unmelted shredded cheese on a shrimp burrito - questionable.
cheese.author: Kiristen R.
cheese.review:
The hype monster lives.

Hubs and I first heard about this place on the Bobby Flay showdown show. Hubs thinks that Bobby Flay is the biggest douche-bag that ever walked the earth so he definitely wanted to try the Triple Threat burrito since it beat Bobby Flay's green burrito.

After tasting for myself Papalote's famed Triple Threat burrito, I seriously doubt either:

Bobby Flay's cred as an Iron Chef 

or 

the crediblity of the judges

because that burrito was hella average.

The meats were nicely grilled but as a total burrito, it was average

AND

at $20, I expect to pay for quality, not quantity. The burrito is huge but if I wanted a large amount of average tasting burrito, I'd order 2 regular sized burritos.

The salsa is really good. The burrito is not worth a 2nd visit.

Oh and I saw unmelted shredded cheese on a shrimp burrito - questionable.

What the hell Bobby Flay?

excerpts: Recommend the classic vegetarian (with potatoes) with cheese, no rice, add guac, whole wheat tortilla
cheese.author: Michael O.
cheese.review:
Favorite burrito in SF, hands down.  I take friends here all the time when visiting.  A cross between legit Mexican and Mission hipster/funk.

Veggie burritos are great.  Recommend the classic vegetarian (with potatoes) with cheese, no rice, add guac, whole wheat tortilla

excerpts: The meat was freshly grilled and the cheese was melted perfectly.
High quality stuff.
It was served to us on our table but previous to that there was a legit orange sauce and chips.
I say legit because you could see the crushed tomatoes and pimentos in there.
Did I say this place was ZAGAT rated?
now it's BRIAN rated as well.
The burrito was a large size, mine was the "super" with guacamole, sour cream and cheese.
cheese.author: Brian C.
cheese.review:
Papalote in the heart of the Mission on 24th near the Bart station is a small place.  They do a pretty big takeout business because of their small dine in space and their dedicated register for those takeout customers.  Menu is pretty straightforward, either burrito, taco, quesadilla, all with a healthy choice of different meats, tortillas and sides.

I had the Carne asada that was voted and rated highly on 7 x 7 list of best Carne asada burritos in the city.  K had the shrimp burrito.  When we sat down, they brought us chips and salsa.  The salsa is this creamy roasted tomato salsa with a kick.  It was very different than I've tasted and was def a fan.  The burrito was a large size, mine was the "super" with guacamole, sour cream and cheese.  The Carne asada was actually very good, tender and tasty but the mush that they called rice ruined the burrito for me.  It just became this mix of poor textures. K was happy with her shrimp burrito and said it was flavorful, she didn't mind the rice as much as I did.

If I could take the Carne asada from papalote and put it into a el farolito burrito, I would be in heaven.  Since I can't, I'll have to settle for the dry meat at el farrolito because I definitely can't deal with the mushy rice at papalote

excerpts: Adding the salsa made it better, but maybe I wanted cheese or something.
cheese.author: Tim B.
cheese.review:
The salsa here is quite good - its more like a creamy spicy sauce that you eat with your chips, very unique and tasty.
 
Otherwise, I don't really feel like it's anything special. I've definitely had better mexican food. I had the carne asada and chili verde tacos. They come in litle corn tortillas with pico de gallo, lettuce, and meat. Both were OK... I just felt like something was missing. Adding the salsa made it better, but maybe I wanted cheese or something. My friends ordered their chicken and carne asada burritos. Again, nothing special. I tasted it and it didn't really have any outstanding flavor. 

I think the reason why its so liked is because it has interesting vegan options like soy chorizo and eggplant quesadillas. They also offer wheat tortillas.

excerpts: I had mine without the guacamole, cheese, and sour cream, but those options definitely add some flavor enhancements (and maybe a few calories).
Portions were very generous and service was friendly.
The housemade salsa was also excellent (think they charge $0.50 if you want extra).
cheese.author: Kent W.
cheese.review: Every time I drive by this restaurant there is a line out the door, so this past week we decided to give it a try.  It's a very casual environment, good for a weeknight dinner or lunch.  The food was very flavorful (we had the vegetarian options with tofu, but still great in taste).  I had mine without the guacamole, cheese, and sour cream, but those options definitely add some flavor enhancements (and maybe a few calories).  Portions were very generous and service was friendly.  The housemade salsa was also excellent (think they charge $0.50 if you want extra).

excerpts: Get it super with cheese, guac, and sour cream.
cheese.author: Jeffrey H.
cheese.review:
Hands down my favorite burrito joint in the city, and I have eaten my fair share of bean, rice, and meat in a tortilla.

Employing the golden ratio of guacamole to sour cream, Papalote combines fresh ingredients to create a superior taste experience. Unlike other taquerias whose burritos flavors are mushy and muddled, Papalote's burritos are flavorful and delicious - each ingredient stands out on it's own. 

A few tips:

1) My fav is the prawn burrito. Get it super with cheese, guac, and sour cream. 

2) The salsa is totes amazeballs. You can even buy a jar of it to take home. 

3) Call in your order 10 minutes in advance to have your order ready when you get there!

4) Even though it sounds enticing and delicious, forget the Triple Threat burrito on the menu.  It's $20 and has carne asade, prawns, and chicken, but is no larger than a normal burrito and not worth the premium price.  I suppose I'd pay a few bucks extra for the combination of meats, but it doesn't make sense to charge a ridiculous amount of money for a regular-sized burrito.  Maybe I ordered it on an off day, but it was the one and only time I've been disappointed with Papalote.

excerpts: , I got it super (with sour cream, cheese and guacamole).
I was delicious, but honestly not much different than Chipotle, except more expensive.
cheese.author: Kathleen M.
cheese.review: My first real Mission burrito. I went with the marinated tofu (with black beans) on the recommendation of the Burrito Eater, I got it super (with sour cream, cheese and guacamole). I was delicious, but honestly not much different than Chipotle, except more expensive. It comes with (warm) chips and salsa, but I didn't eat very many since I knew the burrito was going to be big, so it was kind of a waste. I would have rather paid extra for chips if I wanted them. I would be happy to eat here again, but there are so many other places I have to try, I wouldn't make a special trip to go here.

excerpts: The vast majority of burrito places, even here, seem to think that a vegetarian burrito means "beans and cheese only" (recipe for an evening of stink if I ever heard one).
Therefore, Papalote gets amazing ratings from half of the city purely for using vegetables.
cheese.author: Sydney H.
cheese.review:
3.5 stars, rounded down because of how long it takes to get a burrito to go on a Tuesday night.  Apparently, you can call ahead and pick it up right away, which is what I should have done.  It's pretty tiny, you have to wait even longer for a table.

My theory about Papalote's excellent ratings:  Roughly half of San Francisco is vegetarian, if not vegan.  The vast majority of burrito places, even here, seem to think that a vegetarian burrito means "beans and cheese only" (recipe for an evening of stink if I ever heard one).  Therefore, Papalote gets amazing ratings from half of the city purely for using vegetables.  Like, real, fresh vegetables, which is nice, but not as nice as the reviews make it out to be.

That said, their mole burrito is delicious, and it was almost worth the wait.  Since I wanted both meat and veggies in it, they charged me close to $13.  It was enough for two meals, but still...$13 for a burrito of any sort seems a bit excessive, no matter how delicious.

excerpts: (extra $1 for cheese/guacamole/sour cream).
cheese.author: Damon K.
cheese.review:
We saw this place, as many others have, on Throwdown With Bobby Flay. Seriously, how did he lose to the WAY OVERPRICED triple threat burrito? It's $20 fucking dollars, and I'm still pissed that I threw my money away there.  Over $40 for 3 people to eat at a glorified taqueria? UNFUCKINGBELIEVABLE. Fuck YOU papalote.  

Back to the triple threat burrito: it's big, but not even CLOSE to worth $20. It was dry, and totally unremarkable. And they want MORE money to make it palatable? (extra $1 for cheese/guacamole/sour cream). Best part about the food here is their house salsa.

The ONLY way I would ever come back here is if I somehow got addicted to burritos, went on a bender, and woke up in the dumpster in the alley next to Papalote with a burrito withdrawal. ONLY fucking way.

excerpts: I was SO not a fan of the Monterey Jack cheese - in cold state, not melted - that they sprinkle on everything.
Yuck.
I tried the fish taco - and the fish was fresh and not deep-fried, the lettuce was crisp - but the cheese, as much as I tried to take it all off, ruined it for me.
If I had asked for no cheese - I would have given it three stars too.
cheese.author: Grace K.
cheese.review:
Give me a break!

On a perfectly nice Sunday - we were chilling out at Revolution Cafe w/ some beers indulging in nice conversation, a great live band, and "people-watching" the most interesting, odd folks who thought it normal to shush people at a cafe.  The three of us all being foodies - talk of food was inevitable as dinner time approached us.

JB mentioned a burrito place that had recently been featured on "Throwdown with Bobby Flay".  Now, I like Bobby as a person more than a chef, and I do enjoy this show from time to time but I had missed this episode.  But my interest was piqued in learning that Bobby had lost to the "triple threat burrito" at Papalote, so we started walking to check the place out for dinner.

Well, as we expected, there was a massive line of people wanting to try the place that had beaten the Iron Chef.  As it turned out, there were more people waiting for their placed order than wanting to order, so we were able to squeeze right through to the counter.

All three of us wanted the Triple Threat.  
All three of us gawked at the price: $20.

TWENTY DOLLARS?
The first natural question was: how big is it?
Answer:  same size as the other burritos... that average out at about $7.50 in cost.

*(looking around the room to make sure I'm on earth)*

ON WHAT PLANET DOES THAT MAKE SENSE?????????

Same size - 1/3 portion of beef, chicken and shrimp....
Almost 3X in cost.

FOR WHAT?

Forget that!  Do I have "IDIOT" written on my forehead?

We scored seating in the restaurant within 10 minutes, and that was good since our wait for the regular burritos would be over 30 minutes.

Once seated, we just paid $30 for a plate of fish tacos and a beef/chicken burrito, with a beer and a diet coke.  Examining the receipt, it became clear that we had been charged for fish tacos, a beef burrito AND a chicken burrito.

(Annoying.)

The chips were decent, and their "special secret sauce" (salsa) was pretty good in concept but overly salted, and not quite what *I* want from "salsa".  Nonetheless, it was tasty.

The burritos arrive.
Regular size.
I was SO not a fan of the Monterey Jack cheese - in cold state, not melted - that they sprinkle on everything.  Yuck.  Took a bite of the chicken/beef burrito - and the only noteworthy thing was the chicken was well marinaded/seasoned.  The rest?  Unimpressive.  Overall, for the burrito, I'd have given it three stars.

I tried the fish taco - and the fish was fresh and not deep-fried, the lettuce was crisp - but the cheese, as much as I tried to take it all off, ruined it for me.  If I had asked for no cheese - I would have given it three stars too.

There's a MUCH better burrito to be had at El Metate for a fraction of the cost and even better ambiance with better drinks and service, too.  ($5 for a burrito there - try it!)

The experience of eating at Papalote, due to the hype, was worth it.  The company made the whole night fun.  Perhaps, if we had been insane enough to splurge $20 to eat a burrito - my assessment would be higher.  But for a $20 burrito, I expect it to give me wings, and based on other reviews - nobody sprouted wings and took off.  It's unfortunate for the owners as they'd be making a WHOLE lot more money off the recent coverage if they charged $10 for the Triple Threat instead of attempting to price gouge their customers for $20.  Whatever number of Triple Threats they are selling right now for $20, they could sell 10X that amount had they charged $10.  Do the math.

Coincidentally - upon arriving home later in the evening, the very episode of "Throwdown w/ Bobby Flay" came on TV and I watched it with the remnants of Papalote's burrito and fish taco in my stomach.

Bobby was as cute as ever, and based on ingredients alone, I'd have preferred his "green burrito".  That said, the two brothers were funny and seemed like nice guys.

They just happen to be out of their freakin' minds.

$20 for a BURRITO?
That's just insulting.

excerpts: I got a less than desirable plate of nachos with nothing but some cheese melted on top, a scattering of tomatoes, a smear of beans and overcooked shabby looking chicken pieces on top.
Oh, the triple-threat burrito, the one that was featured on the show, $20.
I asked how big it was because I was considering getting it.
It's the same size as a regular burrito.
Can anyone tell me if ANY regular sized burrito is worth that much money?
cheese.author: Blu n.
cheese.review:
I have a theory that when the food network visits a restaurant, they inevitably ruin the experience for everyone else because not only are your expectations higher, the restaurant gets a bloated ego and goes downhill.  

The food was overpriced.  I got a less than desirable plate of nachos with nothing but some cheese melted on top, a scattering of tomatoes, a smear of beans and overcooked shabby looking chicken pieces on top.  Oh, the triple-threat burrito, the one that was featured on the show, $20.  I asked how big it was because I was considering getting it.  It's the same size as a regular burrito.  Can anyone tell me if ANY regular sized burrito is worth that much money?  Me thinks not!

The wait staff left a sour taste in my mouth.  Apparently they've become so crowded a hostess needs to seat you.  Fast food or restaurant, they can't decide.  Someone brings out chips and salsa and the food to your table.  The salsa wasn't very fresh tasting.  The worst part, the food took about a half hour to come out.  I get faster service at legitimate sit down restaurants.  What's going on back there in the kitchen?

For an actual burrito experience, go to Farolito, or even Pancho Villa for crying out loud.  You'll spend half as much as come out with a feeling of satisfaction!

excerpts: Where were the prawns, the sour cream, the guacamole and cheese that comes with the "super?".
Turns out there were a few over cooked dried prawns in there.
But I never found the sour cream.
And I found a bit of mushy guacamole and cheese clumped at the bottom.
But mostly beans, and blandness.
cheese.author: Avi S.
cheese.review:
The last three burritos I ordered here were absolutely awful.  Today, I ordered a super prawn burrito and after the first 4 large bites, I returned to the store thinking I had recieved someone else's order.  Why?  Because all I got in each bite were BEANS.  Where were the prawns, the sour cream, the guacamole and cheese that comes with the "super?".
Turns out there were a few over cooked dried prawns in there.  But I never found the sour cream.  And I found a bit of mushy guacamole and cheese clumped at the bottom.  But mostly beans, and blandness.  Don't burritos usually have a tasty salsa as well?

Yuch.  I was truly disappointed, for the third time in a row.  Not sure what people like, maybe it's because it's kinda "granola" and that's what a certain mission crowd likes...

excerpts: The way I describe it is: it tastes like spicy nacho cheese doritos but in liquid form.
and I got nachos with carne asada, cheese, guacamole, and sour cream.
They had the perfect cheese to nachos ratio.
They didn't put too much cheese and the chips stayed crunchy.
It was a huge plate though, so if you get the nachos make sure you're with a friend.
cheese.author: Therese M.
cheese.review:
Papalote's was featured on the Food Network on "Throwdown with Bobby Flay," me and the boyfriend wanted to check it out because it was local. We went there with his family and it's a small restaurant, it was the weekend, so it was really crowded but we waited for a table.

When we sat down they served chips and salsa. OMG that salsa. It's not the kind of salsa you're used to with chopped tomatoes, cilantro, and what not. The salsa at papalote's is more like a sauce, but a HELLA good sauce. We spent like 20 minutes tasting it and trying to figure out what was in it. The way I describe it is: it tastes like spicy nacho cheese doritos but in liquid form. Haha.

Anyway, I got the carne asada burrito and it was full of flavor. I'm not sure how else to describe it. Everything is made to order and it tastes like all the ingredients are fresh.

One time I came here with my co-worker and I got nachos with carne asada, cheese, guacamole, and sour cream. They had the perfect cheese to nachos ratio. They didn't put too much cheese and the chips stayed crunchy. It was a huge plate though, so if you get the nachos make sure you're with a friend. =)

What sucks is that after you finish the free chips and salsa, you have to pay for more. It's not much, but I usually think that chips and salsa are free.

excerpts: Oh, and the huge burrito (which by the way, is an American invention) at the table next to me was burried under a mountain of mozzarella cheese.
Yech.
cheese.author: Deb J.
cheese.review:
I went to Papalote in the Mission District on a recent weekend visit.  It was recommended by the owner of the B&B where I was staying.  As this is San Francisco, I expected the food to be a bit more authentic and I was sorely disappointed.

The staff was friendly enough and the menu was readable.  My complaint?  First, we ordered taquitos and a side of rice and beans.  My partner ordered the carne asada (beef) taquitos and I ordered the chicken.  What we received were huge chunks of meat (we are used to shredded meat) and long strands of lettuce and huge chunks of tomato.  There was no flavor at all in the meat or chicken and the abundance of watery tomato and lettuce made the taquitos so watery that they dissolved the tortilla.

The horchata and strawberry drinks were watery and not at all flavorful.  I am used to taquitos that have double tortillas with shredded chicken or beef and topped with salsa and chopped cilantro and onion.  Not here.

I would not recommend this place, and when I told my friend who we were visiting, she said that the place was always full and that there were way better taquerias to be had along Mission Street.

So, to not be too mean, I gave this place two stars, but really would have given it one.  Oh, and the huge burrito (which by the way, is an American invention) at the table next to me was burried under a mountain of mozzarella cheese.  Yech.

excerpts: and a side of pinto beans, rice, eggplant, sourcream and cheese.
cheese.author: L P.
cheese.review:
I waltzed in with a friend early one Sunday evening. We went for a walk, saw Papalote, and thought sure, let's try it. 

AND WE DID. 

I had the grilled veggie burrito. I LOVE zucchini in my mexican food and this included it....And not just a few slices but it was STUFFED with zucchini...and a side of pinto beans, rice, eggplant, sourcream and cheese. My friend had the Mole/chicken burrito and she also enjoyed it...Although I think she enjoyed the strangely orange free salsa more. It WAS good after all. We left stuffed and pleased. Especially since when we arrived at 4 we walked right in and up to the cashier. Then when we left at 5ish there was a line out the door. We had the right burritos at the right time...with drinks for the right price...20 bucks. 

(By the way, this story took place approximately 5 hours ago. I decided to write this review promptly bc I also decided to promptly eat my burrito leftovers as soon as I got home....which is now....Also, it's even better cold. Yesssssss)

Go here and go early.

excerpts: Basically this is a must go for any fan of a good burrito, the only reason I gave it a 4 out of 5 was because the service was a little slow, they put cheese on my burrito when I asked them not too
and I spent $20 on a burrito that only had two prawns in it!
cheese.author: Nate J.
cheese.review:
About a week ago I was flipping through the channels and stopped on the Food Network like I always seem to.  I was enthralled to see that Throwdown with Bobby Flay was on and it was a restaurant near my house!  I quickly decided after seeing their triple threat the next time I am in San Francisco I have to go out of my way to try this out.

Today was the day I was finally making a trip to San Francisco and HAD to get down to the Mission District and try that burrito I saw only a few days later that had me eating half of my pantry.  Right when I walked up I knew this was going to be the real deal.  It had all the signs of a good local place; small "hole in the wall" vibe, local art on the walls  and most importantly a line out the door in the pouring rain!

Now to get to the point, I sat through the line and got to the register and realized the triple threat was $19.95 and thought to myself, "that sounds like a lot of money, it must be huge!".  After about waiting for 20 minutes I got my food and was a little underwhelmed at the size.  Yes it was big, but not "wow I spent $20 on a burrito big".  However, I was starving so I dove in and was immediately impressed with the quality of food that was in front of me.  My meat was juicy and very well seasoned and the salsa they put on it, as well as give you with chips, was addicting!

Basically this is a must go for any fan of a good burrito, the only reason I gave it a 4 out of 5 was because the service was a little slow, they put cheese on my burrito when I asked them not too and I spent $20 on a burrito that only had two prawns in it!

excerpts: And it's only 99 cents to add sour cream, guacamole, and cheese!
The staff is really friendly despite how busy they are and always wipe down the tables between guests.
cheese.author: Desiree L.
cheese.review:
I'm seriously pretty upset right now that I do not live in the city. I was hungover at my friends apartment and was way too lazy to even get up off the couch let alone leave the apartment to get food. 

We were watching Throwdown with Bobby Flay and this delicious looking burrito came up on the TV--The Triple Threat. I was hooked. I watched the entire show and was pumped when I found out these guys were based in San Francisco. 

I left the apartment immediately to find this place. The Triple Threat is HUGE (I think it should have been split among 3-4 people) and is $19.95. Sad. $20 burritos are always disappointing, but I couldn't not order it. It has prawns, chicken and beef in it. I was hesitant when I saw the chicken and I assumed it would be dry. It was not dry -- it was amazing instead.  

The salsa is amazing and I had to ask for my own because I didn't want to share anymore. It's spicy and is great on chips, the burrito, a plain flour tortilla....by the end I was just spooning it into my mouth. 

Their other burritos are very reasonably priced ($6-8) and the portions are also very large. And it's only 99 cents to add sour cream, guacamole, and cheese!  The staff is really friendly despite how busy they are and always wipe down the tables between guests. yay. 

Bobby Flay definitely has nothing on this place. I'm excited to go back.

excerpts: I have also tried the grilled veggie burrito (not that great as it had no guac, cheese, salsa or sour cream).
You can't go wrong with the quesadillas either!
Cute little spot
cheese.author: Niki V.
cheese.review: The sauce! The sauce is worth writing a million words for. You can also buy the jar of sauce which makes it that much better. I usually get the carne asada burrito and it's never failed to impress. I have also tried the grilled veggie burrito (not that great as it had no guac, cheese, salsa or sour cream). You can't go wrong with the quesadillas either! Cute little spot

excerpts: We also shared some chorizo and melted cheese---all of it fantastic!
cheese.author: Jerry M.
cheese.review:
After reading 40 million reviews, thought I'd give it a try. Went down with a friend of mine, and he had the carne asada quesadilla, while I had the carne asada burrito. We also shared some chorizo and melted cheese---all of it fantastic! The carne asada was well-cooked, and they didn't skimp like other places do. The cooks are working overtime and we could smell and see the other tables' dishes as they were brought out, with a lot of "What is that? I gotta get some of that!" comments. All of the other patrons were equally impressed. And if you're in the Mission, you better be authentic or you'll be exposed for the fraud you are. This place is the real deal.

If this is your first time there, on each table there is a bottle of salsa picante (the red) and salsa verde (the green). OMG. Warning: whatever drink you get, if you put the verde on your food, get two drinks. I put some serious water away washing that down. It was one of those types of meals where you know you'll pay for it later and you just don't care. It's that good. We'll definitely be back again.

excerpts: It was basically a beans, rice and cheese burrito w/ a cameo appearance by some prawns.
cheese.author: Jay S.
cheese.review:
An experience that has shaken my faith in the taste of my fellow San Franciscans. I just cannot understand the hype around this place. It wasn't bad, but I don't think I'd come back here- it's just not a good value.

I've tried Papalote's food before. I have vague memories of eating there before I lived in SF and I'd had their takeout at a friend's house before. I don't remember being blown away by it, but I don't remember hating it either. Then again, I'm from Socal, so Mexican food is one category in which SF tends to let me down.

Fast forward to last night. We get there and, though the wait was somewhat long, the staff was so friendly and attentive that it wasn't a bother at all. 

I ordered the soyrizo burrito (not particularly adventurous, but it's what I was in the mood for). It was just okay, not any better or worse than what I might make at home using store-bought soyrizo. I wasn't unhappy with my meal, but I wasn't impressed. I'd rate it 3 stars on its own. 

My girlfriend's burrito was a different story. She orded the lime-seasoned prawn burrito, but the seasoning was so bland that she actually thought they'd given her the wrong burrito! I asked the (very polite and attentive) waitress if perhaps they'd prepared her the shrimp burrito with the butter-wine sauce by mistake, but it turns out it was the right burrito, just not a very good one.*

The other problem, besides flavor, was the number of prawns. This was an $11 burrito that had 4 smallish prawns in it. I don't expect it to be loaded up like a shrimp burrito, but I eat a lot of Mexican food and I know what $11 should buy me. I am not a diner with a sense of entitlement, I just don't want to feel ripped off. 4 tiny prawns just isn't gonna cut it in a huge burrito. It was basically a beans, rice and cheese burrito w/ a cameo appearance by some prawns.

The biggest surprise though, was the salsa. Papalote is renowned for their salsa. So I found it surprising that a Mexican place famous for its salsa DOESN'T GIVE YOU ANY SALSA WITH YOUR FOOD.... YOU HAVE TO BUY IT. **

I am, as my obnoxious use of capital letters might indicate, dead serious: Salsa with your chips is free, but you have to pay to have salsa with your food. 

You get a small (maybe 2 oz) cup of salsa with your chips. The place is popular, so you wait with that basket of chips for quite a while before your food comes. When your food arrives, it does not come with salsa. As it turns out, if you want salsa with your food you have two choices:

(1) Eat your chips without salsa, so you can save the salsa for your food. C'mon son. This might not be objectively unreasonable, but it's unreasonable in light of custom: what Mexican restaurant expects you to eat chips without salsa?

(2) Purchase more salsa to go with your food, at the rate of $0.50 per small cup.

Admittedly, $0.50 is not a big deal, but the idea that the only way to enjoy salsa with your food at this Mexican restaurant is to either pay extra or eat your chips without salsa just reeks of, dare I say it, arrogance. It's like they're so gassed up over people telling them how dope their salsa is that they think they're doing us a favor by letting us eat there. 

I get it. You're world-famous for your salsa. You sell the salsa separately in a jar. People would probably consume insane amounts of the salsa if you didn't regulate it somehow.... but is it going to kill you to give me one cup of salsa with my chips and one cup of salsa with my food? I mean, seriously, that just comes off as really, really cheap. I purchase a $30 fast-Mexican meal for two and have to pay extra to get the salsa? How is that cost not built into my $10 burrito?? 

This is the kind of disregard for customer perspective that causes once-great businesses to fail. Not saying I see Papalote failing anytime soon, but it was a *huge* turnoff for me and I probably won't eat there again because of that last straw. Two people can eat at Rubio's (which actually has very good food for fast-Mexican), spend $20 and enjoy several cups of their delicious salsas or free! The mind boggles.

Also, the salsa is tasty, but not something I would have thought to rave about if Papalote wasn't already well-hyped for its salsa. Despite really wanting to love my dining experience at Papalote, I walked away not understanding what the fuss is about. So disappointed.

______________

* I love my girlfriend, but I'm not the type to give a place a shitty review just because she had a bad experience (see my review of Sushi Raw if you have any doubts). That being said, her burrito was so skimpy on prawns that I was disappointed just *watching* her eat it. It was like watching someone pick the wrong door on a game show over and over again: bite after bite with not a prawn in sight.

** I KNOW!!

excerpts: The prawns, generously doled and flavorfully grilled, added a unique texture to the sour cream, guac and cheese.
cheese.author: Bobbin W.
cheese.review:
I sifted through a bunch of hipster reviews during my SF research and noticed consistent high ratings for Papalote, adding it to my list of Mission Musts. After a rousing show at the Make-Out Room, my beau and I decided to grab a bite in the vicinity. And since it was dark, finding the San Buena Taco Truck was out of the question. So we booked it to Papalote and earned a spot as the last lucky party to score a table in the small dining area. A staff member brought us each our own handful of chips in two bowls, along with little containers of orange, creamy, spicy salsa--quite different from the tomato chunks I'm used to. 

I ordered a prawn burrito, making it a super for only 99 cents. I appreciated the tortilla choices (spinach, flour, whole wheat and Roma tomato), opting for the spinach, as well as the bean options (pinto, refried and black). I chose pinto, of course. 

I mean, the burrito was okay but not worth $10. The prawns, generously doled and flavorfully grilled, added a unique texture to the sour cream, guac and cheese. 

The atmosphere set Papalote apart. The artwork, a fuse between Picasso and Rivera, adorned the bright red walls. Flying frogs and dragons kept watch from the ceiling. The arched entryway between the ordering and dining area added architectural pizazz. Plus, the bathroom, covered in blue paint and graffiti, reminded me of a catwalk per its long, narrow shape and mirror in front of the commode above the sink. 

Because of the shrimp and tilapia filling options and unique decor, Papalote rises just a step above chains like Willy's.

excerpts: If you want some guacamole, sour cream,, and cheese in your burrito, you got to pay an extra 99 cents to get it super.
The burritos here are a little pricier than other places in the Mission (around $6.50 -$9 for a burrito) and they are not as big either...
BUT they are delicious...
cheese.author: Angela T.
cheese.review:
I have been to both Papalote locations, on Fulton and in the Mission. Both are great. They are well known for their salsa, which is REALLY good. The salsa is what makes Papalote really special. Like most other Mexican restaurants in the Mission, you get chips and salsa with your food. So while chips and salsa are just a plus to the burritos normally, I personally think the salsa is just as awesome and special as the burrito. 

Onto the burritos... They have more veggie options than other Mexican places. I have had a regular veggie burrito, with potatoes, mushrooms, and carrots. It was really good, but I do wish there had been more mushrooms in there. The potatoes and carrots had been cooked nice and soft but not mushy and seasoned well. I also tried the soyrizo which was also awesome. 

If you want some guacamole, sour cream,, and cheese in your burrito, you got to pay an extra 99 cents to get it super. The burritos here are a little pricier than other places in the Mission (around $6.50 -$9 for a burrito) and they are not as big either... BUT they are delicious...

excerpts: The cheese is good, the fresh salsa adds nice saltiness and acidity, the beans are tasty and the meat is cooked to order.
Quite simply, they are just awesome burritos.
cheese.author: Bryan M.
cheese.review:
Ok, we need to get a few things straight.  Papalote won all those Best Salsa/Best Upscale Tacqueria/Best Burrito awards for a reason.  Some of these reviews have it ass backwards - it's not made for the masses, it's just that the masses have spoken, and the verdict is DELICIOUS.  There's always a line out the door for a reason.

I just moved away from SF, and this is one of the spots I am missing the most. It's not "white people food", ffs, it's just not the most authentic Mexican in the area....but so what?  It's not like you can't score that if you really want it - but you come here for a reason, and that reason is the bomb-ass burritos.

And they are far from "flavorless", trust me.  The cheese is good, the fresh salsa adds nice saltiness and acidity, the beans are tasty and the meat is cooked to order.  Quite simply, they are just awesome burritos.  *Awesome*.

Not to mention the customary free chips and salsa, and to reiterate what everyone else already said - it's almost worth visiting just for the salsa (which does have plenty of kick, contrary to someone's bogus assertion that it's lacking...if you really want *any* Mexican food to be spicy, you have to add hot sauce, so that is kind of irrelevant anyways).

*Note:  the salsa does not, I repeat NOT taste anything like "liquid Doritos".  Good God.  The unique consistency in the "orange sauce" salsas in California are due to the addition of sour cream.

I'd usually be a bit more judicious with the stars and give this 4, but the service is always friendly and they never messed up an order in 2 years of constant high-volume take out.

excerpts: Did I make it SUPER for $0.99 and add sour cream, cheese, and guacamole inside?
DUH.
cheese.author: Brett W.
cheese.review:
Ladies. Gentlemen. I have been defeated.

In one corner you've got B: A vertically challenged underweight, but with years of burrito-eating experience.

In the other corner you've got Papalote: A Mexican grill that packs an unassumingly heavy punch.

This was the talk of the group for my San Fran veteran friends*. Luckily, I have a really smart morning routine: I oversleep, shower eventually, and drink my breakfast in the form of coffee. So by the time Papalote rolled around, Papa was storving!

I went for a classic grilled chicken burrito. Did I make it SUPER for $0.99 and add sour cream, cheese, and guacamole inside? DUH. As if that was even a legitimate question.

But first they give everyone their own bowl of chips and salsa. Because everyone is obsessed with the salsa, I'm just going to reiterate the fanatic declarations and agree: It is probably the best salsa I've had yet. I wanted to pick-pocket it and douse a little on all of my meals. 

Then, the burrito the size of my torso was set in front of me. My eyes said, "YES. YES. YES. GO!" Halfway through my stomach said, "Boo, you've got to give it a rest." 

I got about 3/4ths of the way finished with the appearance of my coaches--fork and knife--but not even they could help me with the big win.

Yet it has never felt so good to lose. 
__________

* I was a newbie. But I really did leave my heart in San Francisco . . . My appetite too.

excerpts: The food was delicious, but what I really liked about the place was that you could get the 99 cent upgrade which loads the burrito with Guac, sour cream, and cheese.
cheese.author: Mike H.
cheese.review:
On our weekend in the city, my friend Tron said we had to eat here. He said it was on the food network, I was in.

We waited 30 min for it to open, and to my surprise they did not serve Carnitas! Pork is a staple of mine, so I switched to the carne asada burrito.

The food was delicious, but what I really liked about the place was that you could get the 99 cent upgrade which loads the burrito with Guac, sour cream, and cheese. I have paid over two dollars for avocado at other places before.

The orange salsa was the other wild card - it was unique with a lot of different levels of flavors. Other early birds there were coming in just to buy orders of the salsa - check it out!

excerpts: That inspired me to try the soyrizo burrito (with cheese and grilled mushrooms).
I have one word for you..
DAMN.
That was THE best non-meat burrito I've ever had
cheese.author: erica c.
cheese.review:
First off, let me just say that the "salsa," or whatever their creamy hot sauce is called, was AMAZING.  It was spicy, creamy and loaded with flavor.  I damn near ate my whole basket of chips to get to the last drop of that sauce.  :-)

Second, while I DO eat meat, I was a vegetarian for 10 years.  That inspired me to try the soyrizo burrito (with cheese and grilled mushrooms).  I have one word for you..  DAMN.  That was THE best non-meat burrito I've ever had and I love Pancho Villa's tofu.

My girlfriend had a carne asada and grilled shrimp burrito which she devoured (all 100 pounds of her).  Needless to say, she enjoyed hers, too.

We met the owner, Miguel,  who also gave us a sample of his chicken adobo (over rice), which is a burrito meat option (and quite popular, I hear).  While I thought that to be somehow wrong, I have to admit that the adobo was absolutely delicious.   It was SO tender.

The eating area is small but the tables do clear quickly.  And while their prices may be on the high side, I'm definitely one who believes in getting what you pay for... and we certainly did.

Miguel, thank you for your hospitality.  You'll definitely be seeing me again.

P.S.  My 9-year old son proclaims Papalote to be his favorite  - and he's eaten a quite a few burritos, living in South City.  :-)

excerpts: Today ordered a mole tofu burrito with brown rice, refried black beans, cheese, pico de gallo and whole wheat tortilla.
The ingredients blended perfectly.
The tofu was fresh and firm.
And the mole was homey, not overpowering, a rich but thin, hearty gravy that brought everything together.
My kids love the food here, but since we never make it here before sunset, I tend to just order take out for us to eat on the drive home.
The neighborhood isn't necessarily bad, just not family friendly.
And while the staff are fantastic, in the evenings, the customers tend to be grown ups having grown up conversations over alcohol.
cheese.author: Mark X.
cheese.review: I am vegetarian, mostly vegan, so I am not the best person to rate authentic/traditional Mexican food, which in my experience, is generally not vegetarian or vegan friendly.  That said, I have tried dozens of mom+pop burrito places throughout CA, and Papalote is in a league of their own, light years ahead of the rest.  Today ordered a mole tofu burrito with brown rice, refried black beans, cheese, pico de gallo and whole wheat tortilla.  The ingredients blended perfectly.  The tofu was fresh and firm.  And the mole was homey, not overpowering, a rich but thin, hearty gravy that brought everything together.  My kids love the food here, but since we never make it here before sunset, I tend to just order take out for us to eat on the drive home.  The neighborhood isn't necessarily bad, just not family friendly.  And while the staff are fantastic, in the evenings, the customers tend to be grown ups having grown up conversations over alcohol.

excerpts: It was delicious, all of the meat was tender (pollo, carne asada, prawns), flavorful and perfectly seasoned - a definite highlight, and the black bleans, rice, cheese and guacamole were extremely complementary.
cheese.author: Burrito M.
cheese.review:
Dinner at Papalote for Cinco de Mayo.

We ordered the famous Triple Threat Burrito ($20!) and it did not disappoint.  It was delicious, all of the meat was tender (pollo, carne asada, prawns), flavorful and perfectly seasoned - a definite highlight, and the black bleans, rice, cheese and guacamole were extremely complementary.  I thought it was kind of expensive for a burrito, but this is a must try - at least once - especially since they whooped Booby Flay's ass at his own genre on Throwdown with this burrito.

We also ordered the chips and salsa - the salsa was REALLY good, very spicy, but the chips - meh, not so much.  I like my chips thick and bursting with roasted corn flavor,  these were thin and kinda pathetic, most were broken into small pieces by the time we got home with our meal.

By the way, one of the brother/owners was in the house while we were there and the guy really cares about customer service.  It was literally a madhouse inside and he was really diligent about keeping people calm and the line moving.

Tip: Order ahead on the phone and drop by for pickup, we ordered take out in the restaurant and ended up waiting 20-30 minutes before our food was ready.  Not sure if the crowd was due to Cinco d Mayo, or if it's normally like this.  In any case, they have a separate and shorter line for phone orders.

excerpts: and I think it's because they added some cheese to it.
It's also spicer and I love that..
Note that your order comes with a serving of chips n salsa
but if you want more if that awesome salsa they'll charge you
a dollar(I think) for it..
cheese.author: Jun Kang C.
cheese.review:
Had to check this place out after they won the thrown down with Bobbly Flay on the food network.

I've to say the burritos were pretty good but not the best I ever had. 

However I'll definitely return here for 2 things: their salsa and chips and their strawberry aqua fresca!

Their salsa is different from your standard salsa. It is creamier and I think it's because they added some cheese to it. It's also spicer and I love that.. Note that your order comes with a serving of chips n salsa but if you want more if that awesome salsa they'll charge you a dollar(I think) for it.. Worth it though! 

Yes I love their strawberry aqua fresca. It taste really fresh and I like how you can taste the strawberry bits and seeds in it!

At the end of the day it's worth checking out the place at least once. One word of warning. If you're driving here in a Friday night good luck. Parking is difficult to find so drop your friend off to go order (40 min wait on fri nights) while you find a parking spot

excerpts: Me, I always go for the Soyrizo burrito SUPER (with sour cream, guacamole and cheese, the only way to go!)
cheese.author: Bill H.
cheese.review:
As a couple of vegetarians who still hanker for some tasty Mexican food (we come from New Mexico), Papalote was a great discovery. We ate at the restaurant the first time, but it's almost always packed -- a testament to their tasty menu -- so we've become devoted taker-outers.

Me, I always go for the Soyrizo burrito SUPER (with sour cream, guacamole and cheese, the only way to go!) and she always gets the marinated tofu (super, of course).

For us to-go fans, that the burritos come with a bag of chips and their awesome salsa is icing on the cake. And the nachos are bad-ass.

A few of their dishes aren't so super -- like the overly oily-cheesey queso dishes -- but on the whole, you can't go wrong. Parking ain't easy (is it ever in this city?), which makes take out an even better option.

excerpts: TWWICMT suggested that I try some black beans in my carne asada burrito with beans and cheese only (#2) and ya know what, it was a wonderful suggestion.
cheese.author: Jason B.
cheese.review:
This place is good. A friend of mine who lives in San Fran (Warren, who plays drums for Tussle and probably a bunch of other lame bands - just kidding!) took me (and The Woman Who I'm Currently Married To) to this joint. The burritos were pretty damn good. TWWICMT suggested that I try some black beans in my carne asada burrito with beans and cheese only (#2) and ya know what, it was a wonderful suggestion. I think Warren had a veggie burrito because he's one of "those kind." You know what I mean: they don't eat meat because Jesus told him not to via a text message while he was watching Goonies on DVD three years ago. It wasn't even the special edition, just the crappy pan and scan version!

I'm hitting this place up when I come back. You hear that Warren?

excerpts: I was completely stuffed after eating the 2 overly stuffed carne asada tacos loaded with sour cream, cheese, lettuce, tomatoes, and avocado.
The salsa was just hot enough and had a great creamy texture.
yum.
cheese.author: Jackie L.
cheese.review:
You only get 2 tacos? That was my question to my friend upon arrival. 
As a petite girl - I do love Mexican food..and quantity is important. 

I was completely stuffed after eating the 2 overly stuffed carne asada tacos loaded with sour cream, cheese, lettuce, tomatoes, and avocado. The salsa was just hot enough and had a great creamy texture. yum.

excerpts: My burrito was dry, pretty bland, and I only found the cheese  of the way through my meal (same goes for the guacamole).
I slathered every bit of my tiny salsa cup on my burrito for flavor.
The prawns were large... all (4?) of them.
I spent the entire night in agony.
I remebered now why I never go there
: I get incredible stomach cramps from their food.
cheese.author: Shelley T.
cheese.review:
I have given Papalote my fair share of food trials. From the prawn tacos to the burritos, I've eaten enough now to say ENOUGH! Since my last visit, they have renovated the area at the cash register. As if it could not have gotten more awkwardly placed, the line now is forced out the door at a sharp angle. Papalote's blinding non-CFL lighting (which creates an unnecessary heatwave in the dead of winter) and glossy red walls create an anxiety in me that only rivals that of an interrogation. Because it is in close proximity to my friend's apartment, I reluctantly agreed to meet her there. (Any excuse to see her.) Miraculously, she was able to get 3 seats for all of us. Seating is at a premium.

Last night, I had the prawn burrito. I was not given chips or salsa or a napkin or cutlery or my drink. I asked for all of these things, seeing that everyone else had them, and was told that "extra" chips & salsa were 55 cents. Seriously? I can get all the chips I want elsewhere and for free. Once I explained to the guy that I never got my first round, he gave me some salsa. I walked out of there having paid $14 for a burrito and a horchata. I could have gone to El Farolito and bought dinner for both of us. My burrito was dry, pretty bland, and I only found the cheese  of the way through my meal (same goes for the guacamole). I slathered every bit of my tiny salsa cup on my burrito for flavor. The prawns were large... all (4?) of them. I spent the entire night in agony. I remebered now why I never go there: I get incredible stomach cramps from their food. I can't explain it - no one else seems to have this - but the amount of acid created is so painful that the last time I ate there, I needed to swallow Pepto with lidocaine just to get to sleep. 

I will now leave Papalote to the hipsters who frequent it. A guy who sat next to us was visiting from NY. I mentioned to him that this was not my favorite place and suggested that if he was here for any length of time, he should try the many other burrito places that the Mission has to offer. I suggested El Farolito and the couple next to us agreed and chimed in. The couple on the other side of us agreed as well. One thing could be said: Papalote brings people together.

excerpts:
A generous serving of chips topped w/ cheese, sauce, and egg and served w/ beans and rice on the side
- Chile Verde burrito - a fat burrito, enough for two people.
cheese.author: Amy H.
cheese.review:
Chilaquiles!

After walking by a few months ago and seeing someone chow down on a huge plate of nachos through the window, I knew I had to come back and check this place out sometime. I actually had no idea it was featured on Throwdown until the day before we went.

We arrived at 11:45am and it was totally dead. But our friends weren't here yet so we walked around the corner for a cup of coffee. 20 minutes later we walked back and there was a huge line out the door. 

So it's definitely not worth all the hype but the food is still pretty decent, and it's not your typical greasy Mexican joint like one would expect.
