But the chile verde burrito with refried beans. OH MY GOODNESS.  Flavorful and addictive.  Even the leftovers tasted wonderful.  It is really messy because the chile verde is really wet so I just dug right in with a fork and knife instead.

Frequent burrito card so why not come back more.

Order and pay at the cash register and then you sit with a number and they bring your food.  One of the cash registers is for phone orders only so if you're doing takeout, it's pretty easy.

Bathroom on the far side of the restaurant.

And head down the street to Arizemendi for a little after meal scone ;-)

excerpts: After the lunch, we left the chips and salsa out and people snacked all afternoon.
I am looking forward to working with them again in the future.
chips and salsa.author: Jana B.
chips and salsa.review: I organized Papalote to cater a lunch for a company event. We planned in advance but had last minute adjustments, which they happily accommodated. They were lovely to work with. The food arrived hot, clearly labeled, and well organized. I went with their build-your-own burrito option. The salsa was a hit! After the lunch, we left the chips and salsa out and people snacked all afternoon. I am looking forward to working with them again in the future.

excerpts: I eat here often simply to get the chips and salsa that come with every order.
I believe you can also buy the salsa in grocery stores like Whole Foods.
Yum!
chips and salsa.author: Brandon G.
chips and salsa.review: The burritos are pretty solid, but the salsa...the salsa is next level good. I eat here often simply to get the chips and salsa that come with every order. I believe you can also buy the salsa in grocery stores like Whole Foods. Yum!

excerpts: , I started buying it in stores to use for chips and salsa at home!
chips and salsa.author: Ezra B.
chips and salsa.review:
Best salsa I've EVER HAD!!!

Man it's so good, I started buying it in stores to use for chips and salsa at home!

The burritos are pretty good here, too :) I tried the soyrizo one and LOVED IT. I'm sold!

excerpts:
Before You Die 2012

#46 Chips and Salsa at Papalote
My first question to myself was how good can the chips and salsa really be or was this just another fill in item.
After deliberating where to go, we decided to go to Papalote for their chips and salsa.
While browsing their menu online I noticed something odd.
Everyone on Yelp kept posting pictures of the Triple Threat Burrito however I saw it no where on the menu.
chips and salsa.author: Eddie W.
chips and salsa.review:
7x7 100 Things To Eat In SF Before You Die 2012

#46 Chips and Salsa at Papalote

My first question to myself was how good can the chips and salsa really be or was this just another fill in item. Well I finally was able to have my answer this past week. 

After deliberating where to go, we decided to go to Papalote for their chips and salsa. While browsing their menu online I noticed something odd. Everyone on Yelp kept posting pictures of the Triple Threat Burrito however I saw it no where on the menu. Turns out it is their signature item that was featured on Bobby Flay's show Throwdown. 

Basically its a huge burrito stuffed with steak, chicken and shrimp however you do need to pay $1 extra to make it super. To me it is weird that isn't included in the price but ok. My friend and I agreed to split the burrito plus get chips, extra salsa and two beers. We both ended up paying $18 for just that so keep that in mind. 

For what its worth, the salsa is unlike any other salsa I have had. From color, consistency and all the way down to flavor there is a complexity to their salsa that is well worth trying. The chips did not appear to be anything out of the ordinary but I would recommend trying the salsa at least one time. 

The steak was sensational, the best I have had so far from any mexican restaurant. It was juicy, flavorful and fork tender. I would gladly go back for their carne asada burrito. 

Chicken was fine, good portion and seasoned adequately but no real highs or lows.

As for the shrimp, the addition of the 4 pieces felt a little underwhelming, and left me wondering why was it even in there to begin with. The quality was good and cooked well but didn't find it be a valid "threat".

Overall Thoughts

Salsa is delicious and well worth trying as well as the carne asada but be warned Papalote isn't a cheap grab and go burrito kind of place

excerpts: I can probably just keep chips and salsa and end up eating my fingers.
Would love to try other salsa options
chips and salsa.author: Nikhil A.
chips and salsa.review:
Amazing home made salsa and tons of delicious vegetarian options. Huge portions and don't miss the pickle jar on the corner. 
I can probably just keep chips and salsa and end up eating my fingers. Would love to try other salsa options

excerpts: also has A+ chips and salsa.
chips and salsa.author: Kate T.
chips and salsa.review:
i always judge a burrito place on its vegetarian burritos. why?

a) it's cheaper. and if i eat a bad burrito, i don't want to spend a lot.

b) It makes sure i confirm that there is good tortillas, fresh vegetables, and a good cheese:bean:rice ratio without the meat seasoning distractions.

c) if i like it, it will be even better when i come back and get a meat burrito.

but papalote broke these rules and made my favorite vegetarian burrito- it has so many good vegetables and potatoes!! so good. 

also has A+ chips and salsa.

excerpts: It was nice to get free chips and salsa while waiting for our food.
As I've already mentioned, the salsa is bomb!!!
The chips, on the other hand, I didn't really care for.
They were kinda stale.
Then burritos came.
chips and salsa.author: Delani D.
chips and salsa.review:
Salsa!!!!! Oh my!!!! Soooooo good.

I was just watching on the travel channel the other day  a show about the best burritos in the country and Papalote was in it. I kept thinking about how bad I wanted to try their burritos. Well, it just so happen that we went up to the bay this weekend for my bf's DJ gigs and one of them was at the mission district. Since we were in the area, I couldn't pass up the chance. 

We got there around 8pm, an hour before closing time. It was nice to get free chips and salsa while waiting for our food. As I've already mentioned, the salsa is bomb!!! The chips, on the other hand, I didn't really care for. They were kinda stale. Then burritos came. I had the tofu mole burrito with refried black beans, wrapped in spinach tortilla and upgraded to super for just 99 cents! Super means they add sour cream, guacamole and cheese. I got mine without the sour cream. The burrito was delicious! That mole sauce was one of the best I've ever tried. Although, I wish I would've gotten whole black beans instead of refried because everything in my burrito was mushy. 

Burrito was devoured and I couldn't move for half an hour. Will definitely be back here next time I'm in SF.

excerpts: Sat down after ordering food, and the waiter immediately came with chips and salsa.
Chips were a bit stale, and while their salsa was good, I don't think it was as amazing as it's hyped up to be.
Don't get me wrong -
I did still really like it
chips and salsa.author: Pooja S.
chips and salsa.review:
Went here for dinner and really loved it! I think it's hard to be creative / differentiated with Mexican food, and Papalote managed to be. It's a small place and I would not pick coming here for the ambiance / if you want an intimate setting. Also really difficult if you have a large group because it's so small, and usually pretty crowded. I got pretty lucky and got a table in under 10 minutes. 

Sat down after ordering food, and the waiter immediately came with chips and salsa. Chips were a bit stale, and while their salsa was good, I don't think it was as amazing as it's hyped up to be. Don't get me wrong - I did still really like it, just think it is as good as other salsas I've tried. 

The burritos are HUGE and super filling!! Portion size is great, and I thought the price was pretty good! I wasn't feeling adventurous enough to try the veggie burrito (has carrots, potatoes and mushroom), so I got the soyrizo burrito (rice and beans with soy chorizo) and made it a super (add guacamole, sour cream and cheese for just $0.99 more!) with a spinach tortilla. I'm not usually a fan of fake meat, but I loved the soyrizo!! Would get it again for sure. It's a little spicy, so difficult to eat with their salsa which also has a bit of a kick. I came with someone who got the same thing without the soyrizo, which was still really good but I like the soyrizo add-on more! The waiter was also really great; we didn't realize that water was self-serve (oops) and we asked him for water, and he still went to get it for us. 
One of my favorite burritos in the city for sure!

excerpts: Other than that I enjoyed the complementary chips and salsa and horchata!
chips and salsa.author: Aimee W.
chips and salsa.review: The shrimp tacos were delicious but the fish tacos could have been better. The fish was a bit soggy. Other than that I enjoyed the complementary chips and salsa and horchata!

excerpts: I could have eaten that guac with a spoon... and I did because we ordered sides of guac, chips and salsa.
All were magically delicious.
My spinach tortilla wasn't as pronounced in flavor as I expected/hoped for, but there was so much going on on my plate that it wasn't that big of a deal.
In a city that hypes its burrito prowess, Papalote is legit.
I'd, gladly, come here again.
chips and salsa.author: Johnny T.
chips and salsa.review:
Beyond being an incredibly fun name to say,* the fine folks at Papalote are churning out tasty fare that may not be 100% authentic but it's mighty tasty to gringo tongues throughout the Bay area. I ate my burrito whilst sitting on a couch and drinking wine. No, that's not their set up (although, it's a winning idea; give me some commission on it), I ate from (my friends' home). Take out is the way to avoid the crazy lines and unwashed masses.

You'll also need time to prepare for the order because there are many options available to you: meat, super or not, type of tortilla, beans... this ain't your average slop-it-together-burrito joint. As for me: chicken (the mole version is very nicely seasoned; oftentimes the meat of a burrito is an afterthought. Not here), of course, super (cheese and double guac, hold the sour cream), spinach tortilla, and refried black beans. First off, the burrito (super!) was huge. It took all my fatty power and a lot of time to finish it. Come here hungry. Secondly, it's all about the guac. Like I mentioned earlier, the meat tasted great alone but pair it up with that guacamole? Goodness gracious. Delicious. I could have eaten that guac with a spoon... and I did because we ordered sides of guac, chips and salsa. All were magically delicious. My spinach tortilla wasn't as pronounced in flavor as I expected/hoped for, but there was so much going on on my plate that it wasn't that big of a deal. In a city that hypes its burrito prowess, Papalote is legit. I'd, gladly, come here again. I just made myself hungry writing this review.

*You just said it, didn't you?

excerpts: The chips and salsa they serve prior to bringing your food were not that great.
The chips were very hard (almost stale)
so I just assume that they don't make their own chips but take them out of a bag.
The food was really good, though.
That's why I'm giving this place 4 stars despite the ambience.
chips and salsa.author: Mihaela P.
chips and salsa.review:
I saw this place on TV and decided to give it a try. Not gonna lie, the place itself was not the cleanest and there was not enough room to move around. I definitely felt a bit claustrophobic when it got full. 
The chips and salsa they serve prior to bringing your food were not that great. The chips were very hard (almost stale) so I just assume that they don't make their own chips but take them out of a bag. 
The food was really good, though. That's why I'm giving this place 4 stars despite the ambience. I had a veggie burrito and my boyfriend had carne asada nachos. We ate everything lol

excerpts: Once seated, they will bring you chips and salsa (it more looks like a slightly thick, smooth orangey sauce)...
chips and salsa.author: Gaby C.
chips and salsa.review:
*I would actually rate this place 3.5 stars if I could, but since I can't, I'm going to have to round down in this instance*

So, I've been wanting to try this place since it was featured and won on a Throwdown with Bobby Flay episode years ago... Then, I wanted to try it even more when I read an article recently that named this place the Best Burrito in America.... I can't tell you the excitement I had inside- it was overwhelming.

Of course, the place was packed inside. It's a very small, cozy place with only a few tables... The seating is somewhat communal style, where you may or may not have to share the same table with other parties... It has a cool, vibe to it- fits right in in the Mission neighborhood.

You order at the front counter and then are asked to wait outside until they are able to seat your party. 

Obviously I ordered the $19.95 Triple Threat Burrito (Don't worry- I shared this with one other person) as that's the very burrito that beat out Bobby Flay and was mentioned in the article... P.s. It's an extra $0.99 for guacamole ... Why wouldn't a $20 burrito already have guacamole in it? (That extra $0.99 is actually for cheese, sour cream and guacamole but I don't eat cheese or sour cream) 

Once seated, they will bring you chips and salsa (it more looks like a slightly thick, smooth orangey sauce)... The chips are mediocre, but the salsa is really unique tasting and really yummy! 

The burrito was served very shortly after. It's huge! Thank goodness we decided to share.  So the burrito was really good... Really, really good... Probably the best meat I've ever had in a burrito- the pieces of steak and chicken are lean and big and juicy and flavorful; very different from many Mexican food places where the meat is always greasy, minced to an oblivion and full of weird, chewy and fatty bites where you aren't quite sure what you just put in your mouth (icky)... The shrimp is grilled to perfection and also bursting with flavor... All the meats are cooked to order and you really could taste the freshness in the cooking- it keeps you excited for each and every bite that you take.

Overall, I really enjoyed my meal... The high quality of the meat is definitely the highlight of this place.... But to me, they really need to improve their chip recipe and the fact that this place isn't what you would consider to be typical "Mexican taqueria style" food threw me off a little from what I was expecting... Also, in my opinion, America's best burrito is definitely not going to have black beans inside it. 

Okay, so maybe it's not the best burrito in my book, but I would say this place is definitely worth a try if you're in the area. 

Note: This place has tons of vegetarian options which was really cool to me.

excerpts: Comes with a small bowl of chips and salsa on side.
I would definitely come back here next time I am in the Mission.
Also, not at all crowded at 3pm on a Monday!
Seems reasonably priced for what you are getting (granted bc
it's SF, when you add tax tip and a beer the prices get high).
chips and salsa.author: Kristi P.
chips and salsa.review: Suprisingly good veggie burrito here. I got the standard veggie one, with potatoes, carrots, and mushrooms. I love mushrooms and have never seen them in a burrito so I got this one. I'm often skeptical of potatoes in a burrito, but these were fresh cut, as were the carrots, and large chunks full of flavor. I love that you can pick what kind of rice, beans and wrap that you want. The papalote's salsa is amazing! I upgraded to get cheese/sour cream/guac and it was the perfect combo. Comes with a small bowl of chips and salsa on side.  I would definitely come back here next time I am in the Mission. Also, not at all crowded at 3pm on a Monday! Seems reasonably priced for what you are getting (granted bc it's SF, when you add tax tip and a beer the prices get high).

excerpts: We sure enjoyed our burrito, chips and salsa!!
chips and salsa.author: Maile N.
chips and salsa.review:
***500th review written by Maile N***

:)  YUM!!  I was in the area and asked my facialist for lunch recommendations nearby after my appointment.  She mentioned Papalote and I had heard it of it, plus she recommended the fish burrito - I was totally intrigued so I wandered over.  I decided to get one to eat there and one to go to take home for my bf to try.  I had a feeling he would totally love me for it!  

I got a Mexican Coke - love!!  The chips and that salsa they bring over (and they also pack it in your to-go order) ROCKS!!!   I'm not sure what's in it, tomatoes, other vegetables mixed in and spices all blended together.  They should bottle it and sell it because I want more!!  The burrito was big, and packed with black beans, tomatoes, fish, etc. - yum!!  I could only eat half of it so I went home with 1-1/2 fish burritos for me and my bf to share, plus more of those yummy chips and *salsa*!  We sure enjoyed our burrito, chips and salsa!!  

We live clear across town from the Mission location and really wish a Papalote was closer - maybe the other location is closer.  Either way, we are definitely going to go back to have more fish burritos and to try their other items.  Gracias!!

excerpts: I would recommend ordering an additional side of chips and salsa (1.69) if you want more salsa.
chips and salsa.author: Sid P.
chips and salsa.review:
Very good, savory, and delicious food. I came here with a friend for lunch. There are many choices for Vegans and Vegetarians. I ended up ordering Super Soyrizo burrito (10+). There was a serving of complementary chips and home mad creamy salsa. The salsa was very good (50 cents for extra sauce). I would recommend ordering an additional side of chips and salsa (1.69) if you want more salsa.

The soyrizo burrito was good. It was very saucy/juicy and well structured (almost no dripping). You could taste all the flavors and it was full of it. I would try out other options (breakfast burrito :) when I am around. Try regular burrito if you don't want too many ingredients. It is little bit more pricey then other places in the neighborhood.  However, it is still worth a try.

excerpts: On to the chips and salsa.
The salsa is pretty awesome.
It tasted like a fire-roasted tomato-based red salsa, but is a little creamy too.
The chips were standard.
chips and salsa.author: Corey C.
chips and salsa.review:
My first burrito in the Mission District!  Papalote was the first recommendation given to me when venturing into this mecca of big burrito lovers.  I'm not going to just meekly accept the assumption that all burritos from this area are better than anywhere else without validating this myself though.    

Going on a picturesque Sunday evening in August, it was surprisingly not too packed.  I have had longer waits at Chipotle.  The clientele here included mainly tourists and hipsters, here because of their devotion to a good burrito.  

Papalote is REALLY proud of the fact that their "Triple Threat" (steak, chicken, shrimp) burrito beat Iron Chef Bobby Flay's.  It's prominently advertised and mentioned by Papalote groupies.  And they charge $20.  I asked a friend who is a Papalote devotee if she wanted to split it, but was told it's not really that big.  But still $20?  Yeah, no thanks.

So you order at Papalote by telling them what you want, getting a number, taking it to your table, and waiting for them to bring it out.  I ordered the chicken burrito and got a Horchata too.  On to the chips and salsa.  The salsa is pretty awesome.  It tasted like a fire-roasted tomato-based red salsa, but is a little creamy too.  The chips were standard.  The horchata was a tad sweet for my taste.

The burrito came out after roughly 10 minutes.  Time to dig in!  Wait . . . no foil and it's on a plate?  Surely I don't have to eat this burrito with knife and fork? That's a little too formal for me, so I used my hands and picked it up.  First bite and I liked the flavor of the burrito.  The chicken seemed shredded.  A little dry.  As I continued to eat it, it was good, but it did not wow me or fill me up at the end of the meal.  A good burrito.  Add a little salsa as you eat the burrito and it's better.  But this experience has inspired me to try other joints in the Mission for my next visit.  Maybe find some friends to go on a Mission burrito crawl.

excerpts: Love the food chips and salsa are great.
chips and salsa.author: Lisa L.
chips and salsa.review: Love the food chips and salsa are great. Shrimp tacos are hands down the best sautéed in white wine sauce and butter.

excerpts: I won't be ordering anything but chips and salsa going forward.
It's really a shame they don't bring the whole package; even mediocre Mexican with that salsa would make them a go-to spot for me.
chips and salsa.author: Justin L.
chips and salsa.review: Their salsa is excellent and unique, but everything else I've tried is bad.  I've gotten tacos several times which have ranged from "would be subpar in the Midwest" to "undercooked pork".  I won't be ordering anything but chips and salsa going forward.  It's really a shame they don't bring the whole package; even mediocre Mexican with that salsa would make them a go-to spot for me.

excerpts: The chips and salsa was extremely good!!
chips and salsa.author: Arnieliz S.
chips and salsa.review:
This mexican grill is super yummy!! I forgot the name of what I got but i know it's what they recommend to their customers. The burrito was very good and the size was huge! I could have split it with 3 other people.

The chips and salsa was extremely good!! The best I've had so far!! 

The place is pretty small but very artsy!!

Great food!!

excerpts: The chips and salsa were great, and the burritos were really good.
We all got super burritos, and I got the adobe super burrito.
It was fresh and delicious.
I'd have no hesitation recommending someone to cube here for the food.
chips and salsa.author: Carolyn S.
chips and salsa.review:
Solid burrito joint and fantastic place to get salsa. 

First- the salsa. That's why I mainly come here now. They have 3 kinds - Serrano (the mildest), habernero (the hottest), and the house salsa (also decently spicy, but so good!). I've tried all the salsa and it's fantastic. Now I make sure to always have a couple jets stocked at home to have whenever I get a takeaway burrito (from anywhere!). So yeah, definitely try their salsa, and then take some to go. 

As for the food, I came here first with some friends to get burritos for lunch. Let's face it, this place is small! And at lunch on a Saturday, it was busy. It definitely felt cramped as we are waiting in line and then being shuffled to a table. One of their workers was coordinating seating to for people at the right tables so everyone could sit. That being said, there was enough room, we didn't have to wait, and the tables were plenty spacious. 

The chips and salsa were great, and the burritos were really good. We all got super burritos, and I got the adobe super burrito. It was fresh and delicious. I'd have no hesitation recommending someone to cube here for the food.

excerpts:
, i can see if they justified charging 7.50 for their chips and salsa, since that is what its known for, but burrito for almost 8 bucks, no way

2) got our order wrong, we made it clear, one carne and one soyrizo, said it twice.
chips and salsa.author: Long C.
chips and salsa.review:
I came here for 2 reasons, 1) after reading about it on the paper (or was it yahoo, i forget), and 2) because my friend recommended it

I know this place is known for there salsa, and yes they get props for their salsa, it was quite delicious, though personally i'd still prefer the fresh stuff over the "processed" salsa (i dont know if its processed or if they just intentionally make it into a mush/mash consistency)

Yes this place makes solid burritos, but then again, i don't think i've ever eaten a bad burrito, actually, i dont think i've ever eaten bad mexican food, its just one thing that is hard to mess up

we order one carne asada burrito and one soyrizo burrito

the soyrizo tasted an awful lot like the frozen chorizo breakfast burrito you can buy at trader joes for 4 dollars, im being serious. the carne asada was good, the meat was fresh and probably one of the better carne asada meats i've seen in a burrito 

so why do they only get 3 stars?

1) 7.50 for a burrito, too expensive, i can see if they justified charging 7.50 for their chips and salsa, since that is what its known for, but burrito for almost 8 bucks, no way

2) got our order wrong, we made it clear, one carne and one soyrizo, said it twice. what the waiter brought us was two soyrizos, then had the audacity to show us the receipt, which clearly stated 2 soyrizo (but come on, are you telling me that the lady who punched it into the computer didnt make any mistake?) 

3) salsa and chip portion was alright, but when i asked for a bit more salsa for my burrito, and the waiter said an extra 50 cents, sorry, thats 50 cents im not willing to pay for something that other restaurants give out for free in unlimited portions

in summation, this is san francisco, where burrito joints and food trucks litter almost every street corner, i have definitely had better burritos elsewhere, dont know what the hype is all about

excerpts: Chips and salsa at Papalote on the Big Eat list.
chips and salsa.author: Rhoda G.
chips and salsa.review:
46. Chips and salsa at Papalote on the Big Eat list.

I came with a friend and we were pretty hungry. I decided to get the carne asada entree that came with beans and rice. Also I got extra tortillas. All of it was really good. We did order the salsa and chips. That salsa is AWESOME! My friend decided to buy a jar of it. I could only eat half of my meal and got the rest to go because I was full, but I couldn't stop eating the salsa and chips.

excerpts: Plus, the burritos come with chips and salsa.
chips and salsa.author: Pamela S.
chips and salsa.review:
Why is it so hard to get burritos like this in NYC? Totally reasonably priced, lots of meat, lots of flavor. Plus, the burritos come with chips and salsa. Yum. 

-1 star because they're a victim of their own success; it's annoying to have to wait 15 minutes for a burrito.

excerpts: The burrito came with chips and salsa.
The chips were a little bland and the salsa was too mild for this spice-loving girl.
Given that Papalote is right down the street from me I will probably give it another try, but I can't say I'll be craving this burrito
chips and salsa.author: Angela C.
chips and salsa.review: I had high expectations for Papalote given the 1800+ reviews. However, I was pretty underwhelmed with my burrito. I ordered the Carne Asada burrito with no beans and made it super. The rice was mushy and the filling was not evenly distributed throughout the burrito. Some bites were all rice, some bites were all steak, some were all guac. The burrito came with chips and salsa. The chips were a little bland and the salsa was too mild for this spice-loving girl. Given that Papalote is right down the street from me I will probably give it another try, but I can't say I'll be craving this burrito like I do the Carne Asada San Francisco style at Tacko.

excerpts: Their chips and salsa is good.
Their house salsa is definitely their specialty.
They sell them in jars at the restaurant.
chips and salsa.author: Elaine Y.
chips and salsa.review:
After hearing all the reviews about this place and seeing it on Bobby Flay's show, thought it was time to give this place a try. I might have hyped this place up too much and I was a little bit disappointed. One mistake I made was to order something that the reviews were suggesting. Papalote is known for their Triple Threat Burrito and have high reviews on the prawn burrito, but I went with the Marinated Tofu. Typical me for always doing something different from the general population. The burrito was good, but it wasn't as good as the regular chicken burritos that I have had elsewhere. It feels like it's missing some sauce. It was really nice that Papalote is so generous with their ingredients and packed the burrito with beans, rice, sour cream, gracamole, and meat, but it tasted a bit on the dry side.

Their chips and salsa is good. Their house salsa is definitely their specialty. They sell them in jars at the restaurant. If I were to return, I will stick with what people like and try the prawn burrito.

excerpts: She also brought back some chips and salsa.
The burritos have lots of good flavor with a good amount of meat.
The salsa is soooo good!
My sister said it was made with habanero peppers but it wasn't too too spicy for me.
Next time I'm definitely going to buy a jar.
chips and salsa.author: Charlene P.
chips and salsa.review: We were going over to my sister's place in SF for lunch and she picked up some food from here for us to try.  I've always heard this place was really good and I couldn't wait to try it.  My husband and I got carne asada super burritos and my sister got the mexipino super burrito.  She also brought back some chips and salsa.  The burritos have lots of good flavor with a good amount of meat.  The salsa is soooo good!  My sister said it was made with habanero peppers but it wasn't too too spicy for me.  Next time I'm definitely going to buy a jar.

excerpts: The chips and salsa came first and it took about 15 minutes to get our burritos.
I would only return for the chips and salsa.
Other than that, Papalote is WAY OVERYHYPED and OVERPRICED.
chips and salsa.author: Cherylynn N.
chips and salsa.review:
My sleep cycle is all messed up...I get more rest on the weekends sleeping for 3 hours than on the weeknights sleeping for 6 hours. Erm, must be the alkie? :X  

It's 1 AM on Thursday Morning and while I should be "attempting" to sleep, my eyes are glued to  an episode of "Throwdown w/ Bobby Flay". For 26 minutes, my mouth was salivating at the thought of meeting the "Triple Threat" one day; needless to say, it was another sleepless night. *sigh*

My friends and I came here yesterday at 12ish and luckily, we came at just the right time before it started getting busy.

FOOD:
*Chips & Salsa (#46 on the 7x7 list): The chips were slightly warm, thin, and crisp with just the right amount of salt. Ahhhhh, the salsa....the BEST freaking salsa EVER! The salsa was emulsified to perfect creamy consistency. As it hits your palette and moves around your mouth, you can taste all the fresh ingredients (the charred tomatoes, garlic, onion, chilies, and cilantro) sink into your taste buds. It had the perfect blend of savory, smokiness, acidity, and fiery kick to it! This is the ONLY thing that lives up to the HYPE!

*Triple Threat (super w/ sour cream & guac): HOLY MOLEY! $20 for a freaking burrito?!?!? The burrito was a regular size burrito that you would find from any taqueria. It was generously filled with rice, chicken, carne asada, and shrimp. The rice was al-dente and the chicken breast, carne asada, and shrimp were perfectly grilled, well-seasoned, and tender. The sour cream and guac are a must as it added a slight tartness and creaminess to balance out all the flavors.

*Ode to Poleng Adobe Burrito: FAIL! If you're expecting the garlicy, peppery soysauce vinegary taste that makes your lips pucker type of Adobo, you will be sadly disappointed. The chicken lacked all the components of what an adobo should be and was not well-seasoned. Errr, where was the garlic friend rice? The rice used was the standard burrito rice. The tortilla was the only thing that stood out. It was different from the typical tortilla used; it was crisp and flaky. All in all, the burrito lacked any real flavor and was quite dry b/c there was no sauce or salsa in it).

DRINKS:
Papalote has a selection of sodas, juices, and Mexican beer. I have to note that their refrigeration system was not working properly yesterday as our drinks were room temperature.

PRICES:
WAY OVERPRICED! A regular burrito is about $8 and an extra $1 to make it super (sour cream and guac). The size of their regular burritos are quite small (approx 7' and 2.5' in diameter) compared to other taquerias in The Mission.

Although the Triple Threat was good; it was NO where near a $20 good! To me, Mexican food is just like Chinese food; you shouldn't have to pay much to get good-tasting food. And, I really think the "hype" has allowed Papalote to capitalize on its customers by charging such ludicrous prices. 

SERVICE:
Order your food at the counter, grab a number, and the server will being you your order when it's ready. The chips and salsa came first and it took about 15 minutes to get our burritos.    

AMBIANCE: 
Very funky hipster type feel with the bright red walls with colorful panting and reggae music playing in the background. 

PARKING: 
Difficult street parking around Valencia and Mission streets. However, Guerrero street seemed to have some available non-metered spots. 

Would I return? I would only return for the chips and salsa. Other than that, Papalote is WAY OVERYHYPED and OVERPRICED. I say bottle the salsa and bring it with you to the other taquerias like Pancho Villa or El Toro where you can get a freshly grilled steak and shrimp burrito for 2/3 of the price.

excerpts: Chips and salsa - this is on the 7x7 100 things to try list.
chips and salsa.author: Alice C.
chips and salsa.review:
From the "That's what she said" joke potential to the succulent flavor, I love [almost] everything about meat.

So you can imagine what I'm about to say is very difficult, but it's also a testimony to how skilled Papalote is at making a healthier alternative not taste like feet.

That being said, the best thing I've tried on this menu is actually the soyrizo (soy chorizo)!  I tried a piece of the soyrizo quesadilla, and was very pleasantly surprised.  It was well seasoned, and the texture was not weird.  I think this dish will be my go-to from now on!

OTHER DISHES I'VE TRIED:
1. Chips and salsa - this is on the 7x7 100 things to try list.  The salsa was really good and different than any other salsa I've tasted, but I still think the soyrizo was more stand-out.
2. Carne asada fajitas - huge portion, and came with lots of veggies including eggplant.  Awesome!
3. Carne asada burrito - 2 days later and reheated via microwave...and STILL tasty!
4. Jicama salad - usually comes on the side with your meal, and refreshingly delicious!  

LIKES:
1. Large portions 
2. Leftovers still tasty 2 days later
3. Lots of veggie alternatives
4. Seems more health conscious than the average taqueria

DISLIKES:
1. Dine in was crowded...you'd probably be annoyed/displeased if you're claustrophobic.  You can phone in orders though.
2. Prices are a bit higher than what you'd expect to find at other Mexican places in the Mission - the steak fajitas were $13.95!  (and I think the carne asada at both El Farolitos is tastier...but then you can just get the soyrizo!)

excerpts: Free chips and salsa which is a plus in my book.
chips and salsa.author: Lauren H.
chips and salsa.review: First off, their sauce is aweeesome.. I was sweating. Free chips and salsa which is a plus in my book. I ordered the chicken salad with the cilantro sauce. Yummy! It is one of the hardiest salads I have ever eaten. You'll be full guaranteed. We ordered the shrimp and streak super burrrito. Delicious! Its large. Massive food coma afterwards no doubt. Last note, the triple threat is not made for 1!

excerpts: I also got complementary chips and salsa with the order.
chips and salsa.author: Terri L.
chips and salsa.review:
My friends and I were in the city early. We decided early on what we needed to eat for later so we wouldn't go super hungry. My friend wanted to try Papalote for their burritos. My other friend said that they were featured on a show by Bobby Flay on the Food Network and Papalote won the challenge....... Ok. Let's go! The food must be really good then.

Just a few weeks ago, I was walking up the hill on 24th. I remember seeing Papalote. There was no sign..... It looks like they are renovating... the only way to find this place if you had the address because there was a paper on the window with the address... The inside looked like it was being renovated as well.

When we entered, we ordered at front. One of my friends wanted In-N-Out instead, so we ordered to-go.... but one of my friend's burrito took 20 minutes to be finished, so my other friend had to order from here. We also decided to stay and eat at the restaurant because we were not going anywhere else for a while, and we were STARVING.

I ordered a rice and bean burrito on a whole wheat tortilla. I was super happy to see the have the whole wheat option. Not many places I go to have that option of tortillas. It was a pretty good size. Not too big or small. Well... it was actually too big for me. I ended up saving a third of it for later. I also got complementary chips and salsa with the order.

About the salsa.... OMG IT WAS SO GOOD! It wasn't too spicy, but it had enough of a kick for me to enjoy it. It was perfect.

By the way, my burrito was really good, but it wasn't super tasty. The pinto beans I had were kind of dry. I can see myself coming here for a burrito... but not anytime soon... Or at least when I come back to the city one day. I don't live here... :(

I was really satisfied with the burrito. I was happy after eating it. If that ever happens with my meal, I'm so coming back.

The dining area is SUPER small and crowded. There is a wait if you want to eat here. I'd rather take it to go, but for the experience, it is best if you stay here. I really liked the feel of the restaurant.

I totally recommend coming here for a burrito. Yummy! :)

excerpts: So, I tried their chips and salsa finally.
It's on that 7x7
"100 Things to Eat in SF" list.
There must be something wrong with my taste buds.
The chips were not that great, nothing special.
You want awesome chips?
Tropisueno's got awesome chips!
The salsa, however, was bangin'.
Unfortunately, I can't take the heat, and one tiny taste set my entire mouth on fire.
chips and salsa.author: Vivian C.
chips and salsa.review:
My first excursion to Papalote today was pretty good.

This is actually 3.5 stars, rounded down because, well, 4 stars means it's got to be really solid, and Papalote's kind of there, but just not quite. 

Some observations, aite here we goes:

1. They take card.  Woot! For a moment, after I stepped in, I panicked because I thought I wouldn't be able to get a burrito since I hardly ever carry around cash.  But phew!  They do!  And then I said to myself, "Oh silly, of COURSE they take card!  Gringo burrito place, duh!"  

2. I got a chicken mole super burrito for $7.93.  The mole was pretty good, as was all the other fillings:
+ Cheese = MELTED, I approve.
+ Black Beans = Soft and flavorful, good job there!
+ Chicken = Shredded and tender perfect chompos for me to eats!  
+ Guac = Mush! Texture, flavor, aesthetically pleasing.  Who doesn't like avocados?
+ Rice = Soft, just right. 

3.  Good location, close to the 24th/Mission BART.  Even though I work in the FiDi, I can easily BART here and back during a lunch break and still have time to spare.  

4.  Hipster paradise indeed.  There were two very nice girls in front of me, with cute bags and flowy skirts and interesting hair.  Such a nice, appropriate place for the hipsters, hippies, and happy white people.  

5.  So, I tried their chips and salsa finally.  It's on that 7x7 "100 Things to Eat in SF" list.  There must be something wrong with my taste buds.  The chips were not that great, nothing special.  You want awesome chips?  Tropisueno's got awesome chips!  The salsa, however, was bangin'.  Unfortunately, I can't take the heat, and one tiny taste set my entire mouth on fire.  It was good, yes, but painful.  

So, why the 3.5 stars?  This review seems to suggest a solid 4, maybe more, right?  Well, I mean, I definitely LIKED my burrito, but it was just...not totally 100% there. . .  

You know what I mean?  Imagine meeting a person, or attending a class, and even though he/she/it is perfectly fine and nice and all, you're just not blown away.  

And you could go either way, go with it, or not.  That's kind of how I felt about Papalote after my meal.  Certainly a decent meal, but I'm not about to jump around recommending it to everyone I know.  

No, no, that shameless plugging is still reserved for my all-time favorite, El Farolito. 

But Papalote?  Eh, she's alright.

excerpts:
(Chips and Salsa rated separately would receive 4.5 / 5 star rating)

Still, the chips and salsa alone earned Papalote 2 of their 3 stars.
chips and salsa.author: Kyle S.
chips and salsa.review:
2.7 / 5 (Chips and Salsa rated separately would receive 4.5 / 5 star rating)

If you're a vegan or a vegetarian, I guess this place would suffice, but because I demand flavor, value and nourishment when I indulge in a burrito, Papalote goes a sad 0-3.

It's not all bad though, Papalote's salsa does provide diners with an exquisite way to spice up their otherwise lackluster food.  If their chips were a little saltier, I would have given their chips & salsa combo 'legend' status.  Still, the chips and salsa alone earned Papalote 2 of their 3 stars.

The real problem with Papalote is that it doesn't deliver the awesome burrito experience that one expects when spending $9 on a burrito IN THE MISSION!!  Taste is blah, care and attention to detail is minimal at best (my burrito completely fell apart after 2 bites), and the ambience is just a little too earthy / yuppy for it to be a true burrito joint.

Long story short, unless you're an herbivore, there is no reason to go to Papalote when El Farolito, La Taqueria and every other delicious Mission burrito is a minutes walk away.

excerpts: Everything comes with a side of tortilla chips and salsa.
So as we found out today, it's not totally worth it to spend $5.75 for an smallish bowl of guacamole and more of the same chips.
chips and salsa.author: Joanne G.
chips and salsa.review:
Go to Papalote for their clean and spacious seating area, some seriously amazing salsa, and fresh made guacamole.  Their burritos are pretty standard, but once you add the salsa and guac, they shoot up into the realm of heavenly.  Also nice that you can choose what type of beans and tortilla you'd like in your burrito or quesadilla.  

Everything comes with a side of tortilla chips and salsa.  So as we found out today, it's not totally worth it to spend $5.75 for an smallish bowl of guacamole and more of the same chips.  Next time I'm going to just go ahead and order the guacamole as a side dish, or maybe even upgrade my burrito for $0.99.

No, not exactly the most authentically Mexican taqueria in the Mission, but who claimed that it was?  The food is still mighty tasty, especially with that salsa.

excerpts: I appreciate the complimentary chips and salsa.
The prices aren't that cheap for food that isn't that good.
For the same price/type of food I'd just go to Chipotle and leave the restaurant a happy camper.
chips and salsa.author: Zachary S.
chips and salsa.review:
I don't know what all the buzz is about.

I've come twice and both times I walked away disappointed. The space is cute but a bit cramped and gets very crowded if there are just a few people eating.  I ordered a chicken burrito both times. The portion was generous but the chicken lacked flavor. The whole burrito lacked kick and seemed very flat. I appreciate the complimentary chips and salsa. The prices aren't that cheap for food that isn't that good. For the same price/type of food I'd just go to Chipotle and leave the restaurant a happy camper.

excerpts: We started with the $1.50 chips and salsa.
Unlike other places these aren't bottomless.
The amount we were given was just under what we needed, especially given how great the salsa was.
chips and salsa.author: Kathleen M.
chips and salsa.review:
Someone brought Papalote's salsa into my husband's work, and it was so good my husband wanted to seek out the mythical land of milk and honey, or rather, *salsa*, from which it came.

We arrived at Papalote at 2:30 on a Saturday afternoon and were lucky enough to only have to wait 3 minutes for a table. There was a line afterwards. The place is on the small side, and it's unclear if you're supposed to claim your own table or follow the "please wait to be seated" sign. There are pretty dragonfly artworks on the ceiling.

We started with the $1.50 chips and salsa. Unlike other places these aren't bottomless. The amount we were given was just under what we needed, especially given how great the salsa was. (The chips are pretty standard issue.) 

The salsa had a nice roasted flavor and was unlike any other salsa I've ever had. It was a light orange color and looked slightly creamy, though I can't imagine them adding cream to it. (Do they?) It was so good we went back a few hours later for some salsa to take home. For $6.50 you can get a full jar. Even though it's in a jar it's fresh salsa and it'll only last a few days.

We each got a pair of tacos for $4.95. One set had pollo (grilled chicken breast), the other carne asada (grilled steak). For some reason they don't let you mix and match your meats. The carne asada was a little chewy but had good flavor - did I detect lime and garlic? The chicken on the other hand looked like it was good quality, but it was bland. I regretted not paying the extra 99 cents to make it a "super" with guac, sour cream, and cheese. I asked at the counter if I could have the super accoutrements on the side. Initially they balked and wanted me to pay the $2.99 for a whole side of guacamole, but I talked them into giving me just a small side of guac for the 99 cents. Guac makes everything better.

Epilogue: The salsa was just as good at home. Still eating it...

excerpts: Not only are their burritos enormous and filling, but they each come with an order of chips and salsa.
chips and salsa.author: Anna K.
chips and salsa.review:
AH. SO GOOD!

I don't live in SF anymore, but when I come to visit, I love coming here. I got the fish burrito most recently, and it was amazing. Stuffed to the gills with guac, cheese, rice, and beans. Not only are their burritos enormous and filling, but they each come with an order of chips and salsa. And this salsa is some of the best salsa I've ever had: almost creamy in its texture, with a nice kick. 

And since Papalote's is located walking distance from Dolores Park, you  can grab your burrito, and then stroll over to Dolores Park and lounge in the (hopefully) sunny weather, watching the kids tumble on the newly-built jungle gym fantasy world, amidst the sunbathers and hipster locals. And then when you're done, (if you managed to finish this feast!) you can end your meal with a fresh ice cream cone from BiRite Creamery nearby. (I didn't finish my burrito, but it made a nice dinner for me later that day).

excerpts: Chips and salsa was good, crunchy chips and mildly spiced sauce.
chips and salsa.author: Julie N.
chips and salsa.review:
I was so excited for a burrito. Oh si, que rico me voy a tragar un burrito. The menu is pretty plain, choice of meat and 99 cents extra for "super" which seems worth it.  It adds cheese, sour cream and guac. I would get slapped if my mother heard me say "guac" she'd thing "guacala" and that don't sound too appetizing. I was eager and saw they bottled and sold their own tomato salse, hmmm must be guud. Chips and salsa was good, crunchy chips and mildly spiced sauce. Then the burrito came.. dun dun dun. 

Ay caramba, guacala!

The rice was dry as hell, ni de fiesta. "Arroz de fiesta" is spanish for party rice. Where people make big batches of tasteless, dry packed rice to serve at weddings and quincianeras. This wasn't even at their level. My carne asada was dry but my tortilla was hella on hit. I ran out of hot sauce, I requested more they charged me $1.10 for two small ass portions. WTF?! lol oh ya and the decor is awesome, the atmosphere feels mexican. There is mexican music blaring and dragon kites to match their red walls. I bet this place was one a chinese food take out and all they did was keep the loud red feng shui walls and flying dragon kites and call it tex mex. My horchata was ok a little sweet. They charged me for fucking salsa it's a spiced up taco bell trying to be a La Vics and a La Vics, it is not. Eh... In ADDITION the $22.50 was not worth the two burritos and one drink we purchased.

excerpts: Pretty dissapointing entrees after enjoying the one-of-a-kind chips and salsa.
chips and salsa.author: Tom H.
chips and salsa.review: Pretty dissapointing entrees after enjoying the one-of-a-kind chips and salsa.  My chicken burrito was really dry-the beans were a bit undercooked and had no sauce--they must have just rinsed them off in water after cooking.  There was a small pile of pico de gallo at the very END of my burrito!  Clearly this place doesn't care and seem to just be trying to ride out their past glory with bare minimum effort.

excerpts: They serve it fresh with a side of your own chips and salsa.
We all shared an order of chips and salsa, on top of the side of chips and salsa that they already give each individual order.
The salsa is SO good.
My friend talked me into buying a jar of it on my way home, one of the best decisions I made all day.
It's fresh with a definite kick, so beware if you're sensitive to spice.
chips and salsa.author: Emily S.
chips and salsa.review:
Just go.

Seriously.

So, if you like delicious tacos and burritos and oh, fresh salsa, then Papalote is your kind of place. The first time I came here for lunch I had the soyrizo tacos which were fantastic. They serve it fresh with a side of your own chips and salsa. 

After going there for lunch this afternoon with some friends, I decided it was time to write a review. Today I went with the grilled veggie burrito, which was delicious. My only complaint is that it was loaded with black beans, which I requested, I just wish there had been more of the grilled zucchini and eggplant. Oh well, it was still deliciously satisfying. We all shared an order of chips and salsa, on top of the side of chips and salsa that they already give each individual order. The salsa is SO good. My friend talked me into buying a jar of it on my way home, one of the best decisions I made all day. It's fresh with a definite kick, so beware if you're sensitive to spice. Also, highly recommend getting your burrito/taco to-go and enjoying it in Dolores Park when the weather's nice.

Side note, they also serve Mexican cokes (pure cane sugar=the real stuff) as well as a wide range of cold beers to enjoy with your delicious Mexican entree of choice.

excerpts: After ordering a burrito, chips and salsa and a couple of tacos, I decided to take a seat.
The rice and bean burrito was excellent, as were the chips and salsa (the 7x7 item).
chips and salsa.author: Jason P.
chips and salsa.review:
The food network combined with the 7x7 list almost forced me to come here on my last SF visit.  After ordering a burrito, chips and salsa and a couple of tacos, I decided to take a seat.  It was amusing that even the lady behind the counter noticed the feast that I ordered and told the food runner how the number of people at our table was less than the number of entrees ordered in Spanish.  

The rice and bean burrito was excellent, as were the chips and salsa (the 7x7 item).  The marinated tofu tacos lacked taste.  I really wish I had opted for the soyrizo, but my stomach was recovering still and I did not feel the need to risk it.  Next time, soyrizo will be my taco filling of choice!

excerpts: So my husband said the chips and salsa were good.
Fortunately for us there was no wait.
None at all.
We were the first people there when they opened.
We actually got there before the place opened.
So no complaints on a wait from me.
I think it's one of those things you have to do when in San Fransisco go to the Mission district for  a burrito.
I did
so I can take it off my bucket list now.
chips and salsa.author: Pinky And The B.
chips and salsa.review:
I was thrilled to try a burrito in the Mission district. The burrito itself didn't thrill me but it was good probably better than I have had anywhere else.  I am not a huge burrito fan but can enjoy them from time to time. 
I think I had a fish burrito and he had pork. 
In general I don't have chips when I go to a cheap Mexican place because most of the chips are recycled and other people might have touched them. I know it's weird but unless I am starving I do not go for the chips. So my husband said the chips and salsa were good. 
Fortunately for us there was no wait. None at all. We were the first people there when they opened. We actually got there before the place opened. So no complaints on a wait from me. 
I think it's one of those things you have to do when in San Fransisco go to the Mission district for  a burrito. I did so I can take it off my bucket list now. :)

excerpts: When we sat down, they brought us chips and salsa.
The salsa is this creamy roasted tomato salsa with a kick.
It was very different than I've tasted and was def a fan.
chips and salsa.author: Brian C.
chips and salsa.review:
Papalote in the heart of the Mission on 24th near the Bart station is a small place.  They do a pretty big takeout business because of their small dine in space and their dedicated register for those takeout customers.  Menu is pretty straightforward, either burrito, taco, quesadilla, all with a healthy choice of different meats, tortillas and sides.

I had the Carne asada that was voted and rated highly on 7 x 7 list of best Carne asada burritos in the city.  K had the shrimp burrito.  When we sat down, they brought us chips and salsa.  The salsa is this creamy roasted tomato salsa with a kick.  It was very different than I've tasted and was def a fan.  The burrito was a large size, mine was the "super" with guacamole, sour cream and cheese.  The Carne asada was actually very good, tender and tasty but the mush that they called rice ruined the burrito for me.  It just became this mix of poor textures. K was happy with her shrimp burrito and said it was flavorful, she didn't mind the rice as much as I did.

If I could take the Carne asada from papalote and put it into a el farolito burrito, I would be in heaven.  Since I can't, I'll have to settle for the dry meat at el farrolito because I definitely can't deal with the mushy rice at papalote

excerpts: The reason for four stars instead of five: Our burritos came with chips and salsa, and while the salsa is heaven, I thought the chips were just "okay."
Also, this location is pretty tiny with limited seating and customers were packed in there like sardines.
chips and salsa.author: Carrie T.
chips and salsa.review:
I recently went here for the first time and I fell in LOVE with the salsa. I am pretty I would drink a large glass of it if I could. 

This place is super vegan friendly, they have quite a few different options. I had the soyrizo burrito (husband had the carne asada and he was it was absolutely delicious). I love that you can have a choice of beans at this place (all of which are vegan). I had the black refried. 

I think I could say this is the BEST burrito I have EVER had. 

The reason for four stars instead of five: Our burritos came with chips and salsa, and while the salsa is heaven, I thought the chips were just "okay."  Also, this location is pretty tiny with limited seating and customers were packed in there like sardines. We arrived just in time to grab the last two seats. 

I'm still dreaming about that salsa.

excerpts: It comes with (warm) chips and salsa, but I didn't eat very many since I knew the burrito was going to be big, so it was kind of a waste.
I would have rather paid extra for chips if I wanted them.
I would be happy to eat here again, but there are so many other places I have to try, I wouldn't make a special trip to go here.
chips and salsa.author: Kathleen M.
chips and salsa.review: My first real Mission burrito. I went with the marinated tofu (with black beans) on the recommendation of the Burrito Eater, I got it super (with sour cream, cheese and guacamole). I was delicious, but honestly not much different than Chipotle, except more expensive. It comes with (warm) chips and salsa, but I didn't eat very many since I knew the burrito was going to be big, so it was kind of a waste. I would have rather paid extra for chips if I wanted them. I would be happy to eat here again, but there are so many other places I have to try, I wouldn't make a special trip to go here.

excerpts: Seating is very limited but once you get a seat, they bring you a bowl of chips and salsa.
The salsa is addictive.
So good.
chips and salsa.author: Chung N.
chips and salsa.review:
Seating is very limited but once you get a seat, they bring you a bowl of chips and salsa. The salsa is addictive. So good. So very good.

And I must say, sometimes I have cravings for nachos and this place really hits the spot. I highly recommend the nachos - it's flavorful, the chips have a great texture, and did I mention the salsa? I did? OK, yeah, it's great!

excerpts: I will be back to try their 'regular' food and their chips and salsa.
chips and salsa.author: Eileen H.
chips and salsa.review:
Disclaimer:  This review is for the Adobo burrito ONLY!  

So some of my coworkers had been hyping up this Adobo burrito for awhile, and one day I decided to get one for myself because I love the 'idea' of it.

Well, let's just say it left many things to be desired, namely the adobo flavor.  It really tasted like bland adobo.  Plus it really would have been better with Filipino-style garlic rice.  I also think pork, like shredded carnitas-type meat would have worked better.  

I'm not writing Papalote off completely, I just had such high hopes for the adobo burrito.  I will be back to try their 'regular' food and their chips and salsa.

excerpts: While waiting i was brought some chips and salsa.
chips and salsa.author: Anthony D.
chips and salsa.review:
excited to check this place out after finding out it beat out bobby flaw on throwdown, i made the journey to experience 'the best burrito' in san francisco last sunday. BAD IDEA!

what a waste of time and hype. First off, the 'triple threat' cost $20, seriously, 20 bucks for a damn burrito, not in this life time. 

So, instead i was torn between the mole burrito or the chile verde. Per the cashiers recommendation, i chose the chili verde. While waiting i was brought some chips and salsa. 

Heard the salsa was great, what a disappointment. It is the better type, i think habanero; however, it just wasnt anything special. If you want a real good orange salsa, try Iguana in SJ, definitely the best. I mean my friends mom could make a better one in her sleep, and she probably has.

Back to the point. well i was given the salsa with some chips, which were store bought (not the great house made ones at REAL mexican restaurants). Once my burrito arrived I asked for some more salsa, since I used the other on the chips they gave me. The worker told me I only get 1 salsa per order and I would have to pay if I wanted any more!! ARE YOU SERIOUS?!? Youre telling me the salsa that came with my chips was the only salsa I got to use for both my super burrito and my dipping my chips? WAT A JOKE! 

any other legitimate mexican restaurant usually hands salsa out like its halloween or even keeps them in self serve so you can basically dip your burrito in before you eat, lol. Not this place, their are like the salsa nazis for some bland lame duck salsa. 

Havent even gotten to the burrito. So, i could barely even taste the green chili and the pork was rather dry and cut too large. I mean i have had chili verde cut that large before but usually its been simmered in sauce so long that it just melts in your mouth, not this one. Felt like I was eating over cooked chicken. 

Only good marking this place gets is they allow the option of getting spinach tortillas and whole black beans. Although, DEFINITELY NOT worth $9 PLUS, the extra cost of salsa!!

BOOOO!

excerpts:
(boyfriend agrees with all this by the way)

however, i do like that the chips and salsa came free with the burrito.
if it wasnt for the chips and salsa, i dont think i would even give 2 stars.
chips and salsa.author: L M.
chips and salsa.review:
i couldnt bring myself to give more than 2 stars. HOW DID THIS PLACE EVER BEAT BOBBY FLAY? like many others, i was interested in trying this place out when i found out that this place beat bobby flay's throwdown. 

my boyfriend and i shared the triple threat burrito which has steak, chicken, and shrimp for $19.95 and boy do i feel cheated! i've had much better burritos elsewhere for less than half of that. the shrimp was overcooked so it was a little tough and rubbery but i did like that it tasted grilled. i didnt have any chicken in my half of the burrito. and the steak had me feeling a bit greasy. i appreciate good carne asada in a burrito but the beef was a bit chewy and too greasy for my taste. (boyfriend agrees with all this by the way)

however, i do like that the chips and salsa came free with the burrito. and i appreciate the cashier for telling me they come with the burrito so i didnt have to pay for an extra one. the salsa was delicious too. if it wasnt for the chips and salsa, i dont think i would even give 2 stars.

excerpts: I usually don't eat chips and salsa but this salsa was to die for!
chips and salsa.author: Nikkie P.
chips and salsa.review:
I had the chili verde super burrito. The pork was really good.  I usually get carnitas but they didn't have it on their menu, but this was definitely better than any chili verde I've had...moist and juicy without being saucy.  And OMG the salsa with chips!!  I usually don't eat chips and salsa but this salsa was to die for! And they sure do give you a lot of guacamole. 

All in all I say it's good food, a little bit pricey for Mexican, and barely any seating so take out is probably best.

excerpts: Someone brings out chips and salsa and the food to your table.
The salsa wasn't very fresh tasting.
The worst part, the food took about a half hour to come out.
I get faster service at legitimate sit down restaurants.
chips and salsa.author: Blu n.
chips and salsa.review:
I have a theory that when the food network visits a restaurant, they inevitably ruin the experience for everyone else because not only are your expectations higher, the restaurant gets a bloated ego and goes downhill.  

The food was overpriced.  I got a less than desirable plate of nachos with nothing but some cheese melted on top, a scattering of tomatoes, a smear of beans and overcooked shabby looking chicken pieces on top.  Oh, the triple-threat burrito, the one that was featured on the show, $20.  I asked how big it was because I was considering getting it.  It's the same size as a regular burrito.  Can anyone tell me if ANY regular sized burrito is worth that much money?  Me thinks not!

The wait staff left a sour taste in my mouth.  Apparently they've become so crowded a hostess needs to seat you.  Fast food or restaurant, they can't decide.  Someone brings out chips and salsa and the food to your table.  The salsa wasn't very fresh tasting.  The worst part, the food took about a half hour to come out.  I get faster service at legitimate sit down restaurants.  What's going on back there in the kitchen?

For an actual burrito experience, go to Farolito, or even Pancho Villa for crying out loud.  You'll spend half as much as come out with a feeling of satisfaction!

excerpts:
THREE reasons why I walked into Papalote:
(1) The SF 7x7 listed their "chips and salsa" as a place to try before you die.
Hmmmmm!!?

?!
(2) According to the Food Network, their "Triple Threat" burrito beat out Bobby Flay's burrito.
Bobby Flay???
Quite impressive!!!
chips and salsa.author: Joy A.
chips and salsa.review:
THREE reasons why I walked into Papalote:
(1) The SF 7x7 listed their "chips and salsa" as a place to try before you die. Hmmmmm!!???!
(2) According to the Food Network, their "Triple Threat" burrito beat out Bobby Flay's burrito.  Bobby Flay??? Quite impressive!!!  
(3) They serve "Chicken Adobo" burritos. Huh, really???!!!!

How do they measure up???
(1) Chips and salsa- BIG THUMBS UP!!!  I really liked it. I couldn't stop munchin' on them.  The salsa was fresh & chunky, and the orange color reminded me of La Vic's delicious salsa. (Try La Vic's orange sauce; buy the bottle even!)
(2) The "Triple Threat" burrito was jam packed w/ flavorful shrimp, chicken, and steak. It was really good, but I have to question it costing $20!!??  For that price, it should have been GYYY-normous, but wasn't.  
(3) I give it up to them for having a mix-breed type of BURRITO: half Filipino/half Mexican. Was it good? Sure it was, but I wonder why it appeared "off-menu". (I'm glad my girlfriend told me about it.)

TIP for those doing the 7x7 list: Anthony's cookies & Mitchell's Ice Cream are a hop, skip, jump away. =)

excerpts: Free chips and salsa when you sit down
but the salsa isn't just your ordinary tomatoes and spices-
instead it's more creamy and bursting with flavors (though pretty spicy).
Huge burritos overflowing with ingredients. !!!
chips and salsa.author: Luthien N.
chips and salsa.review:
There are a lot of burrito places in the Mission but I generally wish I would've saved my money and just made a burrito at home rather than spending my money on such an underwhelming meal.  Papalote was the first place so far that hasn't left me feeling like that and I intend to go back frequently.  Reasons it was different than the others: 
1. HUGE menu that encompasses vegans, vegetarians (GREAT tofu!), and people who love lots of meat.
2. Awesome mole- not spicy, so it might not satisfy some people, but it is so creamy and rich I don't see how anyone could complain. 
3. Free chips and salsa when you sit down but the salsa isn't just your ordinary tomatoes and spices- instead it's more creamy and bursting with flavors (though pretty spicy). 
4. Huge burritos overflowing with ingredients. !!! (I just got really hungry writing this and want to go now)

I'd probably go for 5 stars except that I wish there was more seating (though we only waited for less than 10 minutes for a seat, I felt like we were rushed towards the end when they clearly needed our table) and to add sour cream to a burrito is $2.25 (probably the only expensive thing on the menu but i really love my sour cream).

excerpts: When we sat down they served chips and salsa.
OMG that salsa.
It's not the kind of salsa you're used to with chopped tomatoes, cilantro, and what not.
The salsa at papalote's is more like a sauce, but a HELLA good sauce.
We spent like 20 minutes tasting it and trying to figure out what was in it.
What sucks is that after you finish the free chips and salsa, you have to pay for more.
It's not much, but I usually think that chips and salsa are free.
chips and salsa.author: Therese M.
chips and salsa.review:
Papalote's was featured on the Food Network on "Throwdown with Bobby Flay," me and the boyfriend wanted to check it out because it was local. We went there with his family and it's a small restaurant, it was the weekend, so it was really crowded but we waited for a table.

When we sat down they served chips and salsa. OMG that salsa. It's not the kind of salsa you're used to with chopped tomatoes, cilantro, and what not. The salsa at papalote's is more like a sauce, but a HELLA good sauce. We spent like 20 minutes tasting it and trying to figure out what was in it. The way I describe it is: it tastes like spicy nacho cheese doritos but in liquid form. Haha.

Anyway, I got the carne asada burrito and it was full of flavor. I'm not sure how else to describe it. Everything is made to order and it tastes like all the ingredients are fresh.

One time I came here with my co-worker and I got nachos with carne asada, cheese, guacamole, and sour cream. They had the perfect cheese to nachos ratio. They didn't put too much cheese and the chips stayed crunchy. It was a huge plate though, so if you get the nachos make sure you're with a friend. =)

What sucks is that after you finish the free chips and salsa, you have to pay for more. It's not much, but I usually think that chips and salsa are free.

excerpts: The price for the burrito was absolutely reasonable, throw in the chips and salsa
chips and salsa.author: Laura S.
chips and salsa.review:
I came for a burrito and I left happy. It sounds as though other reviewers may have come looking for something else - a religious experience, a revelation, a culinary come-to-Jesus moment. I did not have one of them. But I did have a seriously good burrito. 

I was in a rush so I got my burrito to-go, so I may not have had the full Papalote experience. The place was very crowded, even at 2 in the afternoon. It's a small space. If you're going for a sit-down meal, my guess is that you could have a wait, and you're going to be in a small room at a little table. If you're getting your order to go, you'll do some shuffling as people move past you carrying food and trying to pay for their orders. These things should not surprise anybody, you went out in search of a tiny delicious burrito place, right?

As this was my second lunch, I didn't have room to try more than one burrito. I went for the chili verde (pork). I am lame and do not like sour cream or guac, so I did not go super. If you are not lame, I hear you should do so. I was pleasantly surprised to find some wicked good salsa and tortilla chips in the bottom of my bag when I got on the BART. The price for the burrito was absolutely reasonable, throw in the chips and salsa and I'm a happy tourist!

Make sure to hit one of the bakeries in the area on your way home to complete the experience.

excerpts: On to the food, the chips and salsa are addictive.
I don't usually go for spicy anything, but these are addictive.
Unfortunately, they don't have bottomless chips and kind of give a dinky serving, but that's OK
chips and salsa.author: Clarisse C.
chips and salsa.review:
Rub-A-Dub-Dub thanks for the grub!

Adobo Burrito is now available all day, every day! Holla!!

Parking can be a bit of a b*tch, but if anything you can call ahead for an order and leave someone in the car with the hazards on.

If you insist on eating there, you'll have to be willing to wait. Fortunately for us, we didn't have to wait very long at all. The line was long itself, but the seating process went smooth because they actually seat you! Unlike many other places that make you fight for seats and don't even wipe down the tables!

Anyways, the owner was there the night we came and I think he was doing more interviews, especially because the Throwdown with Bobby Flay will be airing soon.

On to the food, the chips and salsa are addictive. I don't usually go for spicy anything, but these are addictive. Unfortunately, they don't have bottomless chips and kind of give a dinky serving, but that's OK, I didn't want to fill up on chips anyway....

We waited maybe 15 minutes after ordering to finally get our Adobo Burrito. 1. I love adobo...chicken, pork, whatever. I love adobo and my mom's adobo is hard to match. 2. I love Mexican rice...but I only love it when it has the right amount of flavor to it.

So what does that mean? This burrito is delicious! It's neither overwhelming in each category and they compliment each other well. Then again I could have scorched my tongue from not being able to wait to bite in and the meat was still freshly hot-tot-tot.

The rice is flavorful, I half expected it to be straight up white garlic rice for some reason. The chunks of meat aren't too adobo-ey, but still taste good. If anything, it can have more flavor.

I took half of my burrito home, although they aren't too big in size, but I ended up eating it as soon as I got home and it tasted a bit better because I let the juices soak in.

There's not a doubt in my mind that the other burritos/dishes here are really good.

Sidenote: This is not a drunk food establishment, they close @ 9 or 10.

excerpts: Foodwise, first we got the chips and salsa.
Off to a great start.
Good chips, tasty and complex salsa.
Nice and spicy, too, but maybe a touch too much for the average person.
Also not impressed they charge for another bowl of corn chips.
chips and salsa.author: Adam G.
chips and salsa.review:
The sibbies were in town and had seen the episode of Throwdown, of course.  I'd been curious to try out the famous burrito also, but knew I wasn't going to spend the $ on it on my own.  Cue Papalote for dinner tonight.  

First off, the place is tiny.  Not in a bad way, but just in the way that you need to know before going there assuming you can just sit down.  Even fewer seats than El Farolito around the corner.  

Foodwise, first we got the chips and salsa.  Off to a great start.  Good chips, tasty and complex salsa.  Nice and spicy, too, but maybe a touch too much for the average person.  Also not impressed they charge for another bowl of corn chips.  Boo for that one.

Next up: the Triple Threat.  Of course that's what we had to try.  It arrives taking up more of a plate than is reasonable for a burrito.  But that's what it should do for $20.  And yes, it did take ~15 minutes to arrive, but that's ok in my book, since it was clear everything was freshly cooked.  Again, not your average burrito.  We had to taste each element independently, and each was fantastic on its own.  The shrimp were nicely spiced and well cooked.  The chicken was not too salty (a frequent problem I've noticed with seasoned chicken), and the steak was simple but awesome.  Guacamole was also very good, as were the refried beans.

So on the whole, we enjoyed the food, were astounded at the size of the portion, and would likely come back again.  We would likely not be getting the Triple Threat, though...especially not for $20.  Carne Asada burritos, on the other hand....

excerpts: They also include chips and salsa now with the burrito
so that's a double win!
chips and salsa.author: Jeffrey L.
chips and salsa.review:
They have greatly stepped up their game on the Adobo Burrito. The chicken is much more flavorful, giving you a full blast of the adobo flavor you've come to know and love. Not like the first time when I went, the chicken was dry and it only had a little hint of adobo flavor. Definitely check it out and only try it at the 24th street location.

They also include chips and salsa now with the burrito so that's a double win!

excerpts: Believe the hype - the chips and salsa are both amazing.
chips and salsa.author: valerie t.
chips and salsa.review:
Believe the hype - the chips and salsa are both amazing.  

I got the carne asada burrito and it's everything a burrito should be - meaty, hearty, devilishly delicious, and messy (if not eaten with a fork).  arrived at around 7pm on a Saturday night.  It was busy, but we were able to get a small table for two.  

The place is small but fun (and pretty clean), and the music was hip and upbeat.  There were some pretty cool artwork that hung around as well.  

Definitely worth a second visit.  If I can get someone to split with me, I'd like to try the triple threat burrito.

excerpts: The employees were polite... and the chips and salsa?
No words.
My only regret is the salsa they sell is too big to be a carry on liquid!
chips and salsa.author: Jessi L.
chips and salsa.review: A friend recommended this place as a must-have during our girls' weekend in San Francisco, and we were not disappointed! The burritos and quesadillas were absolutely to die for - fresh and with wonderful ingredients. The employees were polite... and the chips and salsa? No words. My only regret is the salsa they sell is too big to be a carry on liquid!

excerpts: The chips and salsa, which is served by the bowl to each person, is unmissable.
Easily one of the best salsas I've had.
It's smokey, garlicy and has enough kick to leave a little warmth in the back of the throat.
chips and salsa.author: Amanda D.
chips and salsa.review:
The ingredients are fresh, and the options come by the dozen. Meat options are plentiful and unique. The menu has so many different options for any vegan, vegetarian, or good 'ole meat eater like myself. I personally loved the whole wheat tortilla option for no extra charge. It was the first time I had heard of a Chicken Mole option for a burrito - and it did not disappoint! 

However, the best part of the meal cannot be overlooked. The chips and salsa, which is served by the bowl to each person, is unmissable. Easily one of the best salsas I've had. It's smokey, garlicy and has enough kick to leave a little warmth in the back of the throat. So good.

The only downside I saw was the Triple Threat's price. Why, El Papalote, do you have a $20 burrito on your menu if it is roughly the same size as your other normal priced ones? I get that is filled with good meat, but damn! You better get a whole pound of shrimp in there for that price. 

I'd def. come back to El Papalote! Especially after beating Bobby Flay.

excerpts: The chips and salsa was on the list of 100 things to try before you die.
And I am glad I am able to check this one off, there is something really good about the salsa.
I know they make it with roasted tomatoes but there is something else there, that I can't put my finger on it.
I guess I will just use it to lick the salsa container clean.
chips and salsa.author: Eve C.
chips and salsa.review: The chips and salsa was on the list of 100 things to try before you die. And I am glad I am able to check this one off, there is something really good about the salsa. I know they make it with roasted tomatoes but there is something else there, that I can't put my finger on it. I guess I will just use it to lick the salsa container clean.

excerpts:
refried beans, no carnitas = sad aimee :(

good agua fresca and chips and salsa.
chips and salsa.author: Aimee B.
chips and salsa.review:
just went here for take-out friday night.  super popular place, but i'm personally not sure why.  i guess i like greasy taqueria style mexican food, while is on the healthier side.  no lard in the vegan(!) refried beans, no carnitas = sad aimee :(

good agua fresca and chips and salsa.

waited about 20 min for 2 burritos, which kinda sucked.

excerpts: Like most other Mexican restaurants in the Mission, you get chips and salsa with your food.
So while chips and salsa are just a plus to the burritos normally, I personally think the salsa is just as awesome and special as the burrito.
chips and salsa.author: Angela T.
chips and salsa.review:
I have been to both Papalote locations, on Fulton and in the Mission. Both are great. They are well known for their salsa, which is REALLY good. The salsa is what makes Papalote really special. Like most other Mexican restaurants in the Mission, you get chips and salsa with your food. So while chips and salsa are just a plus to the burritos normally, I personally think the salsa is just as awesome and special as the burrito. 

Onto the burritos... They have more veggie options than other Mexican places. I have had a regular veggie burrito, with potatoes, mushrooms, and carrots.
